<h1 class="firstHeading" id="firstHeading" lang="en">New York City</h1>
<div class="mw-body-content" id="bodyContent">
<div class="noprint" id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
<div id="contentSub"></div>
<div class="mw-jump" id="jump-to-nav">
					Jump to:					<a href="#mw-head">navigation</a>, 					<a href="#p-search">search</a>
</div>
<div class="mw-content-ltr" dir="ltr" id="mw-content-text" lang="en"><div class="mw-parser-output"><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">"NYC" and "New York, New York" redirect here. For other uses, see <a class="mw-disambig" href="/wiki/New_York_City_(disambiguation)" title="New York City (disambiguation)">New York City (disambiguation)</a>; <a class="mw-disambig" href="/wiki/NYC_(disambiguation)" title="NYC (disambiguation)">NYC (disambiguation)</a>; and <a class="mw-disambig" href="/wiki/New_York,_New_York_(disambiguation)" title="New York, New York (disambiguation)">New York, New York (disambiguation)</a>.</div>

<td style="text-align:right;font-size:115%;padding-top: 0.6em;">
<div class="plainlinks hlist navbar mini">
<ul>
<li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:Regions_of_New_York" title="Template:Regions of New York"><abbr title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li>
<li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:Regions_of_New_York" title="Template talk:Regions of New York"><abbr title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li>
<li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Regions_of_New_York&amp;action=edit"><abbr title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li>
</ul>
</div>
</td>

<p>The <b>City of New York</b>, often called <b>New York City</b> or simply <b>New York</b>, is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_United_States_cities_by_population" title="List of United States cities by population">most populous city</a> in the <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">United States</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2014NYCest2_9-0"><a href="#cite_note-2014NYCest2-9">[9]</a></sup> With an estimated 2016 population of 8,537,673<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2016Estimate_7-1"><a href="#cite_note-2016Estimate-7">[7]</a></sup> distributed over a land area of about 302.6 square miles (784 km<sup>2</sup>),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-10"><a href="#cite_note-10">[10]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-11"><a href="#cite_note-11">[11]</a></sup> New York City is also the <a href="/wiki/List_of_United_States_cities_by_population_density" title="List of United States cities by population density">most densely populated</a> major city in the United States.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-density_12-0"><a href="#cite_note-density-12">[12]</a></sup> Located at the southern tip of the <a href="/wiki/U.S._state" title="U.S. state">state</a> of <a href="/wiki/New_York_(state)" title="New York (state)">New York</a>, the city is the center of the <a href="/wiki/New_York_metropolitan_area" title="New York metropolitan area">New York metropolitan area</a>, one of the most populous <a href="/wiki/Urban_agglomeration" title="Urban agglomeration">urban agglomerations</a> in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-13"><a href="#cite_note-13">[13]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-14"><a href="#cite_note-14">[14]</a></sup> A <a href="/wiki/Global_city" title="Global city">global power city</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-15"><a href="#cite_note-15">[15]</a></sup> New York City exerts a significant impact upon commerce, finance, media and entertainment, art, fashion, research, technology, education, politics, and sports, its fast pace<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FastPaceNYC1_16-0"><a href="#cite_note-FastPaceNYC1-16">[16]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-17"><a href="#cite_note-17">[17]</a></sup> defining the term <i><a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/New_York_minute" title="wikt:New York minute">New York minute</a></i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NewYorkMinuteDefinition_18-0"><a href="#cite_note-NewYorkMinuteDefinition-18">[18]</a></sup> Home to the <a href="/wiki/Headquarters_of_the_United_Nations" title="Headquarters of the United Nations">headquarters of the United Nations</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-19"><a href="#cite_note-19">[19]</a></sup> New York is an important center for <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/International_diplomacy" title="International diplomacy">international diplomacy</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-20"><a href="#cite_note-20">[20]</a></sup> and has been described as the cultural, financial, and <a href="/wiki/Media_(communication)" title="Media (communication)">media</a> capital<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-21"><a href="#cite_note-21">[21]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-22"><a href="#cite_note-22">[22]</a></sup> of the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cultura1_23-0"><a href="#cite_note-cultura1-23">[23]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-culture2_24-0"><a href="#cite_note-culture2-24">[24]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-culture3_25-0"><a href="#cite_note-culture3-25">[25]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-culture4_26-0"><a href="#cite_note-culture4-26">[26]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WorldEconomicAndFinancialSuperCenter_27-0"><a href="#cite_note-WorldEconomicAndFinancialSuperCenter-27">[27]</a></sup></p>
<p>Situated on <a href="/wiki/New_York_Harbor" title="New York Harbor">one of the world's largest natural harbors</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-28"><a href="#cite_note-28">[28]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-29"><a href="#cite_note-29">[29]</a></sup> New York City consists of five <a href="/wiki/Boroughs_of_New_York_City" title="Boroughs of New York City">boroughs</a>, each of which is a separate <a href="/wiki/List_of_counties_in_New_York" title="List of counties in New York">county of New York State</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-30"><a href="#cite_note-30">[30]</a></sup> The five boroughs – <a href="/wiki/Brooklyn" title="Brooklyn">Brooklyn</a>, <a href="/wiki/Queens" title="Queens">Queens</a>, <a href="/wiki/Manhattan" title="Manhattan">Manhattan</a>, <a href="/wiki/The_Bronx" title="The Bronx">The Bronx</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Staten_Island" title="Staten Island">Staten Island</a> – were consolidated into a single city in 1898.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-31"><a href="#cite_note-31">[31]</a></sup> The city and its metropolitan area constitute the premier gateway for legal <a href="/wiki/Immigration_to_the_United_States" title="Immigration to the United States">immigration to the United States</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Immigrants2014est_32-0"><a href="#cite_note-Immigrants2014est-32">[32]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Immigrants2013est_33-0"><a href="#cite_note-Immigrants2013est-33">[33]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Immigrants2012est_34-0"><a href="#cite_note-Immigrants2012est-34">[34]</a></sup> and as many as 800 languages are spoken in New York,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-35"><a href="#cite_note-35">[35]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-800source2_36-0"><a href="#cite_note-800source2-36">[36]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-800source3_37-0"><a href="#cite_note-800source3-37">[37]</a></sup> making it the most linguistically diverse city in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-800source2_36-1"><a href="#cite_note-800source2-36">[36]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-38"><a href="#cite_note-38">[38]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-39"><a href="#cite_note-39">[39]</a></sup> New York City is home to more than 3.2 million residents born outside the United States,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYCForeignBorn_40-0"><a href="#cite_note-NYCForeignBorn-40">[40]</a></sup> the world's largest <a href="/wiki/Foreign_born#Cities_with_largest_foreign_born_populations" title="Foreign born">foreign-born population</a> of any city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYCHighestForeignBorn_41-0"><a href="#cite_note-NYCHighestForeignBorn-41">[41]</a></sup> By 2016 estimates, the New York City metropolitan region remains by a significant margin the most populous in the United States, as defined by both the <a href="/wiki/List_of_Metropolitan_Statistical_Areas" title="List of Metropolitan Statistical Areas">Metropolitan Statistical Area</a> (MSA), 20.2 million residents,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MetroEst_4-1"><a href="#cite_note-MetroEst-4">[4]</a></sup> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_Combined_Statistical_Areas" title="List of Combined Statistical Areas">Combined Statistical Area</a> (CSA), 23.7 million residents.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CombinedEst_5-1"><a href="#cite_note-CombinedEst-5">[5]</a></sup> In 2013, the MSA produced a <a href="/wiki/Gross_metropolitan_product" title="Gross metropolitan product">gross metropolitan product</a> (GMP) of nearly US$1.39 trillion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-42"><a href="#cite_note-42">[42]</a></sup> In 2012, the CSA<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-43"><a href="#cite_note-43">[43]</a></sup> generated a GMP of over US$1.55 trillion. NYC's MSA and CSA <a href="/wiki/Gross_domestic_product" title="Gross domestic product">GDP</a> are higher than the GDPs of all but 11 and 12 countries, respectively.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-44"><a href="#cite_note-44">[44]</a></sup></p>
<p>New York City traces its origin to its 1624 founding in <a href="/wiki/Lower_Manhattan" title="Lower Manhattan">Lower Manhattan</a> as a trading post by colonists of the <a href="/wiki/Dutch_Republic" title="Dutch Republic">Dutch Republic</a> and was named <a href="/wiki/New_Amsterdam" title="New Amsterdam">New Amsterdam</a> in 1626.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-u-s-history.com_45-0"><a href="#cite_note-u-s-history.com-45">[45]</a></sup> The city and its surroundings came under English control in 1664<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-u-s-history.com_45-1"><a href="#cite_note-u-s-history.com-45">[45]</a></sup> and were renamed <i>New York</i> after King <a href="/wiki/Charles_II_of_England" title="Charles II of England">Charles II of England</a> granted the lands to his brother, the <a href="/wiki/James_II_of_England" title="James II of England">Duke of York</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-46"><a href="#cite_note-46">[46]</a></sup> New York served as the <a href="/wiki/List_of_capitals_in_the_United_States#Former_national_capitals" title="List of capitals in the United States">capital of the United States</a> from 1785 until 1790.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-senate_47-0"><a href="#cite_note-senate-47">[47]</a></sup> It has been the country's largest city since 1790.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-48"><a href="#cite_note-48">[48]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Statue_of_Liberty" title="Statue of Liberty">Statue of Liberty</a> greeted millions of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Immigrants" title="Immigrants">immigrants</a> as they came to the Americas by ship in the late 19th and early 20th centuries<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-49"><a href="#cite_note-49">[49]</a></sup> and is a symbol of the United States and its democracy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-50"><a href="#cite_note-50">[50]</a></sup> In the 21st century, New York has emerged as a global node of <a href="/wiki/Innovation" title="Innovation">creativity</a> and <a href="/wiki/Entrepreneurship" title="Entrepreneurship">entrepreneurship</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-VentureCapitalNY1_51-0"><a href="#cite_note-VentureCapitalNY1-51">[51]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Social_tolerance" title="Social tolerance">social tolerance</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SocialToleranceNY1_52-0"><a href="#cite_note-SocialToleranceNY1-52">[52]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Sustainability" title="Sustainability">environmental sustainability</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EnvironmentalSustainabilityNY1_53-0"><a href="#cite_note-EnvironmentalSustainabilityNY1-53">[53]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EnvironmentalSustainabilityNY2_54-0"><a href="#cite_note-EnvironmentalSustainabilityNY2-54">[54]</a></sup> and as a world symbol of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Freedom" title="Freedom">freedom</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cultural_diversity" title="Cultural diversity">cultural diversity</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-55"><a href="#cite_note-55">[55]</a></sup></p>
<p>Many <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lists_of_New_York_City_Landmarks" title="Lists of New York City Landmarks">districts and landmarks</a> in New York City have become well known, and the city received a record 61 million tourists in 2016,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYCTouristCount_56-0"><a href="#cite_note-NYCTouristCount-56">[56]</a></sup> hosting three of the world's ten most visited tourist attractions in 2013.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ann_Shields_57-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ann_Shields-57">[57]</a></sup> Several sources have ranked New York the most photographed city in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-58"><a href="#cite_note-58">[58]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-59"><a href="#cite_note-59">[59]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Times_Square" title="Times Square">Times Square</a>, iconic as the world's "heart"<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TransformingTimesSquare_60-0"><a href="#cite_note-TransformingTimesSquare-60">[60]</a></sup> and its "Crossroads",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-61"><a href="#cite_note-61">[61]</a></sup> is the brightly illuminated hub of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Broadway_Theater_District" title="Broadway Theater District">Broadway Theater District</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-62"><a href="#cite_note-62">[62]</a></sup> one of the world's busiest <a href="/wiki/Pedestrian" title="Pedestrian">pedestrian intersections</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Joshua_Pramis_63-0"><a href="#cite_note-Joshua_Pramis-63">[63]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-64"><a href="#cite_note-64">[64]</a></sup> and a major center of the world's <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Entertainment_industry" title="Entertainment industry">entertainment industry</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-65"><a href="#cite_note-65">[65]</a></sup> The names of many of the city's <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bridges_and_tunnels_in_New_York_City" title="Bridges and tunnels in New York City">bridges</a>, <a href="/wiki/1916_Zoning_Resolution" title="1916 Zoning Resolution">tapered</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tallest_buildings_in_New_York_City" title="Tallest buildings in New York City">skyscrapers</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-66"><a href="#cite_note-66">[66]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_New_York_City_parks" title="List of New York City parks">parks</a> are known around the world. Anchored by <a href="/wiki/Wall_Street" title="Wall Street">Wall Street</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Financial_District,_Manhattan" title="Financial District, Manhattan">Financial District</a> of Lower Manhattan, New York City has been called both the most economically powerful city and the leading financial center of the world,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WorldEconomicAndFinancialSuperCenter_27-1"><a href="#cite_note-WorldEconomicAndFinancialSuperCenter-27">[27]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WorldFinanceCapitalForeignPolicy_67-0"><a href="#cite_note-WorldFinanceCapitalForeignPolicy-67">[67]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EconomicallyPowerful2015_68-0"><a href="#cite_note-EconomicallyPowerful2015-68">[68]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-69"><a href="#cite_note-69">[69]</a></sup> and the city is home to the world's two <a href="/wiki/List_of_stock_exchanges" title="List of stock exchanges">largest stock exchanges</a> by total <a href="/wiki/Market_capitalization" title="Market capitalization">market capitalization</a>, the <a href="/wiki/New_York_Stock_Exchange" title="New York Stock Exchange">New York Stock Exchange</a> and <a href="/wiki/NASDAQ" title="NASDAQ">NASDAQ</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYSElargest_70-0"><a href="#cite_note-NYSElargest-70">[70]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYSEhighestcap_71-0"><a href="#cite_note-NYSEhighestcap-71">[71]</a></sup> Manhattan's <a href="/wiki/Real_estate" title="Real estate">real estate</a> market is among the most expensive in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-72"><a href="#cite_note-72">[72]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-73"><a href="#cite_note-73">[73]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Chinatown,_Manhattan" title="Chinatown, Manhattan">Manhattan's Chinatown</a> incorporates the highest concentration of Chinese people in the Western Hemisphere,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-74"><a href="#cite_note-74">[74]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-75"><a href="#cite_note-75">[75]</a></sup> with multiple signature Chinatowns developing across the city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-76"><a href="#cite_note-76">[76]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-77"><a href="#cite_note-77">[77]</a></sup> Providing continuous 24/7 service,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-twentyfour_78-0"><a href="#cite_note-twentyfour-78">[78]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Subway" title="New York City Subway">New York City Subway</a> is one of the most extensive <a href="/wiki/Rapid_transit" title="Rapid transit">metro</a> systems worldwide, with 472 stations in operation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-79"><a href="#cite_note-79">[79]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-80"><a href="#cite_note-80">[80]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-81"><a href="#cite_note-81">[81]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/List_of_colleges_and_universities_in_New_York_City" title="List of colleges and universities in New York City">Over 120 colleges and universities</a> are located in New York City, including <a href="/wiki/Columbia_University" title="Columbia University">Columbia University</a>, <a href="/wiki/New_York_University" title="New York University">New York University</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Rockefeller_University" title="Rockefeller University">Rockefeller University</a>, which have been ranked among the top 35 in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-82"><a href="#cite_note-82">[82]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-83"><a href="#cite_note-83">[83]</a></sup></p>
<p></p>

<p></p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_New_York_City" title="History of New York City">History of New York City</a></div>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_New_York_City" title="Timeline of New York City">Timeline of New York City</a></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">Etymology</span></h3>
<p>In 1664, the city was named after then <a href="/wiki/Duke_of_York" title="Duke of York">Duke of York</a>, and future King of England <a href="/wiki/James_II_of_England" title="James II of England">James II</a>. James had been named by his older brother <a href="/wiki/Charles_II_of_England" title="Charles II of England">Charles II</a> as <a href="/wiki/Proprietary_colony" title="Proprietary colony">proprietor</a> of the former territory of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/New_Netherlands" title="New Netherlands">New Netherlands</a> and its main city of <a href="/wiki/New_Amsterdam" title="New Amsterdam">New Amsterdam</a>, which had recently been seized from the Dutch.</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_history">Early history</span></h3>
<p>During the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wisconsinan_glaciation" title="Wisconsinan glaciation">Wisconsinan glaciation</a>, the New York City region was situated at the edge of a large <a href="/wiki/Ice_sheet" title="Ice sheet">ice sheet</a> over 1,000 feet in depth. The ice sheet scraped away large amounts of soil, leaving the <a href="/wiki/Bedrock" title="Bedrock">bedrock</a> that serves as the geologic <a href="/wiki/Foundation_(engineering)" title="Foundation (engineering)">foundation</a> for much of New York City today. Later on, movement of the ice sheet would contribute to the separation of what are now <a href="/wiki/Long_Island" title="Long Island">Long Island</a> and <a href="/wiki/Staten_Island" title="Staten Island">Staten Island</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-84"><a href="#cite_note-84">[84]</a></sup></p>
<p>In the <a href="/wiki/Pre-Columbian_era" title="Pre-Columbian era">precolonial era</a>, the area of present-day New York City was inhabited by various bands of <a href="/wiki/Algonquian_peoples" title="Algonquian peoples">Algonquian</a> tribes of <a href="/wiki/Native_Americans_in_the_United_States" title="Native Americans in the United States">Native Americans</a>, including the <a href="/wiki/Lenape" title="Lenape">Lenape</a>, whose homeland, known as <a href="/wiki/Lenapehoking" title="Lenapehoking">Lenapehoking</a>, included Staten Island; the western portion of Long Island, including the area that would become Brooklyn and Queens; Manhattan; the Bronx; and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lower_Hudson_Valley" title="Lower Hudson Valley">Lower Hudson Valley</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-85"><a href="#cite_note-85">[85]</a></sup></p>
<p>The first documented visit by a European was in 1524 by <a href="/wiki/Giovanni_da_Verrazzano" title="Giovanni da Verrazzano">Giovanni da Verrazzano</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Florence" title="Florence">Florentine</a> explorer in the service of the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_France" title="Kingdom of France">French crown</a>, who sailed his ship <i><a href="/wiki/La_Dauphine" title="La Dauphine">La Dauphine</a></i> into <a href="/wiki/New_York_Harbor" title="New York Harbor">New York Harbor</a>. He claimed the area for France and named it <i>Nouvelle Angoulême</i> (<a href="/wiki/New_Angoul%C3%AAme" title="New Angoulême">New Angoulême</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-rodgers_86-0"><a href="#cite_note-rodgers-86">[86]</a></sup></p>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:The_Purchase_of_Manhattan_Island.png"><img alt="A pen drawing of two men in 16th-century Dutch clothing presenting an open box of items to a group of Native Americans in feather headdresses stereotypical of plains tribes." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1050" data-file-width="1600" height="144" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/The_Purchase_of_Manhattan_Island.png/220px-The_Purchase_of_Manhattan_Island.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/The_Purchase_of_Manhattan_Island.png/330px-The_Purchase_of_Manhattan_Island.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/The_Purchase_of_Manhattan_Island.png/440px-The_Purchase_of_Manhattan_Island.png 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:The_Purchase_of_Manhattan_Island.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
<a href="/wiki/Peter_Minuit" title="Peter Minuit">Peter Minuit</a> is credited with the purchase of the island of Manhattan in 1626.</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>A <a href="/wiki/Spanish_Empire" title="Spanish Empire">Spanish</a> expedition led by captain <a href="/wiki/Est%C3%AAv%C3%A3o_Gomes" title="Estêvão Gomes">Estêvão Gomes</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_people" title="Portuguese people">Portuguese</a> sailing for <a href="/wiki/Charles_V,_Holy_Roman_Emperor" title="Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor">Emperor Charles V</a>, arrived in <a href="/wiki/New_York_Harbor" title="New York Harbor">New York Harbor</a> in January 1525 aboard the purpose-built <a href="/wiki/Caravel" title="Caravel">caravel</a> <i>La Anunciada</i> and charted the mouth of the Hudson River, which he named <i>Río de San Antonio</i> (Saint Anthony's River). Heavy ice kept him from further exploration, and he returned to <a href="/wiki/Spain" title="Spain">Spain</a> in August. The <a href="/wiki/Padr%C3%B3n_Real" title="Padrón Real">Padrón Real</a> of 1527, the first scientific map to show North America's east coast continuously, was informed by Gomes' expedition and labeled the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Northeastern_U.S." title="Northeastern U.S.">Northeastern U.S.</a> as <i>Tierra de Esteban Gómez</i> in his honor.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-87"><a href="#cite_note-87">[87]</a></sup></p>
<p>In 1609, the <a href="/wiki/English_people" title="English people">English</a> explorer <a href="/wiki/Henry_Hudson" title="Henry Hudson">Henry Hudson</a> rediscovered the region when he sailed his ship the <i><a href="/wiki/Halve_Maen" title="Halve Maen">Halve Maen</a></i> ("Half Moon" in <a href="/wiki/Dutch_language" title="Dutch language">Dutch</a>) into New York Harbor while searching for the <a href="/wiki/Northwest_Passage" title="Northwest Passage">Northwest Passage</a> to the <a href="/wiki/Orient" title="Orient">Orient</a> for the <a href="/wiki/Dutch_East_India_Company" title="Dutch East India Company">Dutch East India Company</a>. He proceeded to sail up what the Dutch would name the <a href="/wiki/North_River_(Hudson_River)" title="North River (Hudson River)">North River</a> (now the <a href="/wiki/Hudson_River" title="Hudson River">Hudson River</a>), named first by Hudson as the <i>Mauritius</i> after <a href="/wiki/Maurice,_Prince_of_Orange" title="Maurice, Prince of Orange">Maurice, Prince of Orange</a>. Hudson's <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/First_mate" title="First mate">first mate</a> described the harbor as "a very good Harbour for all windes" and the river as "a mile broad" and "full of fish."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hudsonnni_88-0"><a href="#cite_note-hudsonnni-88">[88]</a></sup> Hudson sailed roughly 150 miles north,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-89"><a href="#cite_note-89">[89]</a></sup> past the site of the present-day <a href="/wiki/Albany,_New_York" title="Albany, New York">Albany</a>, in the belief that it might be an oceanic <a href="/wiki/Tributary" title="Tributary">tributary</a> before the river became too shallow to continue.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hudsonnni_88-1"><a href="#cite_note-hudsonnni-88">[88]</a></sup> He made a ten-day exploration of the area and claimed the region for the Dutch East India Company. In 1614, the area between <a href="/wiki/Cape_Cod" title="Cape Cod">Cape Cod</a> and <a href="/wiki/Delaware_Bay" title="Delaware Bay">Delaware Bay</a> would be claimed by the <a href="/wiki/Netherlands" title="Netherlands">Netherlands</a> and called <i>Nieuw-Nederland</i> (<a href="/wiki/New_Netherland" title="New Netherland">New Netherland</a>).</p>
<p>The first non-Native American inhabitant of what would eventually become New York City was <a href="/wiki/Juan_(Jan)_Rodriguez" title="Juan (Jan) Rodriguez">Juan Rodriguez</a> (transliterated to Dutch as Jan Rodrigues), a merchant from <a href="/wiki/Captaincy_General_of_Santo_Domingo" title="Captaincy General of Santo Domingo">Santo Domingo</a>. Born in <a href="/wiki/Santo_Domingo" title="Santo Domingo">Santo Domingo</a> of <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_people" title="Portuguese people">Portuguese</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ethnic_groups_of_Africa" title="Ethnic groups of Africa">African</a> descent, he arrived in Manhattan during the winter of 1613–1614, trapping for pelts and trading with the local population as a representative of the Dutch. <a href="/wiki/Broadway_(Manhattan)" title="Broadway (Manhattan)">Broadway</a>, from 159th Street to 218th Street in <a href="/wiki/Upper_Manhattan" title="Upper Manhattan">Upper Manhattan</a>, is named Juan Rodriguez Way in his honor.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-90"><a href="#cite_note-90">[90]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-91"><a href="#cite_note-91">[91]</a></sup></p>
<div class="thumb tleft">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:GezichtOpNieuwAmsterdam.jpg"><img alt="A painting of a coastline dotted with red roof houses and a windmill, with several masted ships sailing close to shore under blue sky." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="4964" data-file-width="7276" height="150" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/GezichtOpNieuwAmsterdam.jpg/220px-GezichtOpNieuwAmsterdam.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/GezichtOpNieuwAmsterdam.jpg/330px-GezichtOpNieuwAmsterdam.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/GezichtOpNieuwAmsterdam.jpg/440px-GezichtOpNieuwAmsterdam.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:GezichtOpNieuwAmsterdam.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
<a href="/wiki/New_Amsterdam" title="New Amsterdam">New Amsterdam</a>, centered in the eventual <a href="/wiki/Lower_Manhattan" title="Lower Manhattan">Lower Manhattan</a>, in 1664, the year <a href="/wiki/England" title="England">England</a> took control and renamed it "New York".</div>
</div>
</div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Dutch_rule">Dutch rule</span></h3>
<p>A permanent European presence in New Netherland began in 1624 – making New York the 12th <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_North_American_cities_by_year_of_foundation" title="List of North American cities by year of foundation">oldest continuously occupied</a> European-established settlement in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Continental_United_States" title="Continental United States">continental United States</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-92"><a href="#cite_note-92">[92]</a></sup> – with the founding of a Dutch <a href="/wiki/Fur_trade" title="Fur trade">fur trading</a> settlement on <a href="/wiki/Governors_Island" title="Governors Island">Governors Island</a>. In 1625, construction was started on a <a href="/wiki/Citadel" title="Citadel">citadel</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fort_Amsterdam_(New_Amsterdam)" title="Fort Amsterdam (New Amsterdam)">Fort Amsterdam</a> on Manhattan Island, later called <i>Nieuw Amsterdam</i> (New Amsterdam).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-93"><a href="#cite_note-93">[93]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Tolerance_94-0"><a href="#cite_note-Tolerance-94">[94]</a></sup> The colony of New Amsterdam was centered at the site which would eventually become Lower Manhattan. In 1626, the Dutch colonial Director-General <a href="/wiki/Peter_Minuit" title="Peter Minuit">Peter Minuit</a>, acting as charged by the <a href="/wiki/Dutch_West_India_Company" title="Dutch West India Company">Dutch West India Company</a>, purchased the island of Manhattan from the <i>Canarsie</i>, a small Lenape band,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-95"><a href="#cite_note-95">[95]</a></sup> for 60 <a href="/wiki/Dutch_guilder" title="Dutch guilder">guilders</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-96"><a href="#cite_note-96">[96]</a></sup> (about $1,000 in 2006).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-97"><a href="#cite_note-97">[97]</a></sup> A disproved legend claims that Manhattan was purchased for $24 worth of glass beads.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-98"><a href="#cite_note-98">[98]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-99"><a href="#cite_note-99">[99]</a></sup></p>
<p>Following the purchase, New Amsterdam grew slowly.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-npsnetherland_100-0"><a href="#cite_note-npsnetherland-100">[100]</a></sup> To attract settlers, the Dutch instituted the <a href="/wiki/Patroon" title="Patroon">patroon system</a> in 1628, whereby wealthy Dutchmen ("patroons", or patrons) who brought 50 colonists to New Netherland would be awarded swathes of land, along with local political autonomy and rights to participate in the lucrative fur trade. This program had little success.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-locnetherland_101-0"><a href="#cite_note-locnetherland-101">[101]</a></sup></p>
<p>Since 1621, the Dutch West India Company had operated as a monopoly in New Netherland, on authority granted by the <a href="/wiki/States_General_of_the_Netherlands" title="States General of the Netherlands">Dutch States General</a>. In 1639–1640, in an effort to bolster economy growth, the Dutch West India Company relinquished its monopoly over the fur trade, leading to growth in the production and trade of food, timber, tobacco, and slaves (particularly with the <a href="/wiki/Netherlands_Antilles" title="Netherlands Antilles">Dutch West Indies</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-npsnetherland_100-1"><a href="#cite_note-npsnetherland-100">[100]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nahcnetherland_102-0"><a href="#cite_note-nahcnetherland-102">[102]</a></sup></p>
<p>In 1647, <a href="/wiki/Peter_Stuyvesant" title="Peter Stuyvesant">Peter Stuyvesant</a> began his tenure as the last <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Director-General_of_New_Amsterdam" title="Director-General of New Amsterdam">Director-General</a> of New Netherland. During his tenure, the population of New Amsterdam grew from 2,000 to 8,000. Stuyvesant has been credited with improving law and order in the colony; however, he also earned a reputation as a despotic leader. He instituted regulations on liquor sales, attempted to assert control over the <a href="/wiki/Dutch_Reformed_Church" title="Dutch Reformed Church">Dutch Reformed Church</a>, and blocked other religious groups (including <a href="/wiki/Quakers" title="Quakers">Quakers</a>, <a href="/wiki/Judaism" title="Judaism">Jews</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Lutheranism" title="Lutheranism">Lutherans</a>) from establishing houses of worship.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nyhsstuyvesant_103-0"><a href="#cite_note-nyhsstuyvesant-103">[103]</a></sup> The Dutch West India Company would eventually attempt to ease tensions between Stuyvesant and residents of New Amsterdam.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nnistuyvesant_104-0"><a href="#cite_note-nnistuyvesant-104">[104]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="English_rule">English rule</span></h3>
<p>In 1664, unable to summon any significant resistance, Stuyvesant surrendered New Amsterdam to English troops led by Colonel <a href="/wiki/Richard_Nicolls" title="Richard Nicolls">Richard Nicolls</a> without bloodshed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nyhsstuyvesant_103-1"><a href="#cite_note-nyhsstuyvesant-103">[103]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nnistuyvesant_104-1"><a href="#cite_note-nnistuyvesant-104">[104]</a></sup> The terms of the surrender permitted Dutch residents to remain in the colony and allowed for religious freedom.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lehrmanstuyvesant_105-0"><a href="#cite_note-lehrmanstuyvesant-105">[105]</a></sup> The English promptly renamed the fledgling city "New York" after the <a href="/wiki/James_II_of_England" title="James II of England">Duke of York</a> (the future King James II of England).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-106"><a href="#cite_note-106">[106]</a></sup> The transfer was confirmed in 1667 by the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Breda_(1667)" title="Treaty of Breda (1667)">Treaty of Breda</a>, which concluded the <a href="/wiki/Second_Anglo-Dutch_War" title="Second Anglo-Dutch War">Second Anglo-Dutch War</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-107"><a href="#cite_note-107">[107]</a></sup></p>
<p>On August 24, 1673, during the <a href="/wiki/Third_Anglo-Dutch_War" title="Third Anglo-Dutch War">Third Anglo-Dutch War</a>, Dutch captain <a href="/wiki/Anthony_Colve" title="Anthony Colve">Anthony Colve</a> seized the colony of New York from England at the behest of <a href="/wiki/Cornelis_Evertsen_the_Youngest" title="Cornelis Evertsen the Youngest">Cornelis Evertsen the Youngest</a> and rechristened it "New Orange" after <a href="/wiki/William_III_of_England" title="William III of England">William III</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Prince_of_Orange" title="Prince of Orange">Prince of Orange</a>. The Dutch would soon return the island to England under the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Westminster_(1674)" title="Treaty of Westminster (1674)">Treaty of Westminster</a> of November 1674.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-108"><a href="#cite_note-108">[108]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-109"><a href="#cite_note-109">[109]</a></sup></p>
<p>Several intertribal wars among the Native Americans and some <a href="/wiki/Epidemic" title="Epidemic">epidemics</a> brought on by contact with the Europeans caused sizable population losses for the Lenape between the years 1660 and 1670.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-110"><a href="#cite_note-110">[110]</a></sup> By 1700, the Lenape population had diminished to 200.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-111"><a href="#cite_note-111">[111]</a></sup> New York experienced several <a href="/wiki/Yellow_fever" title="Yellow fever">yellow fever</a> epidemics in the 18th century, losing ten percent of its population to the disease in 1702 alone.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-112"><a href="#cite_note-112">[112]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-113"><a href="#cite_note-113">[113]</a></sup></p>
<p>New York grew in importance as a <a href="/wiki/Port" title="Port">trading port</a> while under <a href="/wiki/British_Empire" title="British Empire">British rule</a> in the early 1700s. It also became a center of <a href="/wiki/Slavery" title="Slavery">slavery</a>, with 42% of households holding slaves by 1730, more than any other city other than <a href="/wiki/Charleston,_South_Carolina" title="Charleston, South Carolina">Charleston, South Carolina</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-114"><a href="#cite_note-114">[114]</a></sup> Most slaveholders held a few or several domestic slaves, but others hired them out to work at labor. Slavery became integrally tied to New York's economy through the labor of slaves throughout the port, and the banks and shipping tied to the <a href="/wiki/Southern_United_States" title="Southern United States">American South</a>. Discovery of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/African_Burying_Ground" title="African Burying Ground">African Burying Ground</a> in the 1990s, during construction of a new <a href="/wiki/Federal_judiciary_of_the_United_States" title="Federal judiciary of the United States">federal courthouse</a> near <a href="/wiki/Foley_Square" title="Foley Square">Foley Square</a>, revealed that tens of thousands of Africans had been buried in the area in the colonial years.</p>
<p>The 1735 trial and acquittal in Manhattan of <a href="/wiki/John_Peter_Zenger" title="John Peter Zenger">John Peter Zenger</a>, who had been accused of <a href="/wiki/Seditious_libel" title="Seditious libel">seditious libel</a> after criticizing colonial governor <a href="/wiki/William_Cosby" title="William Cosby">William Cosby</a>, helped to establish the <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_the_press" title="Freedom of the press">freedom of the press</a> in North America.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-zenger_115-0"><a href="#cite_note-zenger-115">[115]</a></sup> In 1754, <a href="/wiki/Columbia_University" title="Columbia University">Columbia University</a> was founded under charter by <a href="/wiki/George_II_of_Great_Britain" title="George II of Great Britain">King George II</a> as King's College in Lower Manhattan.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-116"><a href="#cite_note-116">[116]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="American_Revolution">American Revolution</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:BattleofLongisland.jpg"><img alt="Colonial era soldiers stand and kneel while firing muskets at and advancing enemy. Behind them is a mounted soldier with a bayonet and behind them is a large flag." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2589" data-file-width="3918" height="145" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/BattleofLongisland.jpg/220px-BattleofLongisland.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/BattleofLongisland.jpg/330px-BattleofLongisland.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/BattleofLongisland.jpg/440px-BattleofLongisland.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:BattleofLongisland.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
The <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Long_Island" title="Battle of Long Island">Battle of Long Island</a>, the largest battle of the <a href="/wiki/American_Revolution" title="American Revolution">American Revolution</a>, took place in <a href="/wiki/Brooklyn" title="Brooklyn">Brooklyn</a> in 1776.</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Stamp_Act_Congress" title="Stamp Act Congress">Stamp Act Congress</a> met in New York in October 1765 as the <a href="/wiki/Sons_of_Liberty" title="Sons of Liberty">Sons of Liberty</a> organized in the city, skirmishing over the next ten years with British troops stationed there. The <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Long_Island" title="Battle of Long Island">Battle of Long Island</a>, the largest battle of the <a href="/wiki/American_Revolutionary_War" title="American Revolutionary War">American Revolutionary War</a>, was fought in August 1776 entirely within the modern-day borough of Brooklyn. After the battle, in which the Americans were defeated, the British made the city their military and political base of operations in North America. The city was a haven for <a href="/wiki/Loyalist_(American_Revolution)" title="Loyalist (American Revolution)">Loyalist</a> refugees and escaped slaves who joined the British lines for freedom newly promised by the Crown for all fighters. As many as 10,000 escaped slaves crowded into the city during the British occupation. When the British forces <a href="/wiki/Evacuation_Day_(New_York)" title="Evacuation Day (New York)">evacuated</a> at the close of the war in 1783, they transported 3,000 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Freedmen" title="Freedmen">freedmen</a> for resettlement in <a href="/wiki/Nova_Scotia" title="Nova Scotia">Nova Scotia</a>. They resettled other <a href="/wiki/Freedman" title="Freedman">freedmen</a> in England and the <a href="/wiki/Caribbean" title="Caribbean">Caribbean</a>.</p>
<p>The only attempt at a peaceful solution to the war took place at the <a href="/wiki/Conference_House" title="Conference House">Conference House</a> on Staten Island between American <a href="/wiki/Delegate" title="Delegate">delegates</a>, including <a href="/wiki/Benjamin_Franklin" title="Benjamin Franklin">Benjamin Franklin</a>, and British general <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lord_Howe" title="Lord Howe">Lord Howe</a> on September 11, 1776. Shortly after the British occupation began, the <a href="/wiki/Great_Fire_of_New_York_(1776)" title="Great Fire of New York (1776)">Great Fire of New York</a> occurred, a large conflagration on the <a href="/wiki/West_Side_(Manhattan)" title="West Side (Manhattan)">West Side</a> of Lower Manhattan, which destroyed about a quarter of the buildings in the city, including <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Trinity_Church_(New_York_City)" title="Trinity Church (New York City)">Trinity Church</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-117"><a href="#cite_note-117">[117]</a></sup></p>
<p>In 1785, the assembly of the <a href="/wiki/Congress_of_the_Confederation" title="Congress of the Confederation">Congress of the Confederation</a> made New York the national capital shortly after the war. New York was the last capital of the U.S. under the <a href="/wiki/Articles_of_Confederation" title="Articles of Confederation">Articles of Confederation</a> and the first capital under the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Constitution" title="United States Constitution">Constitution of the United States</a>. In 1789, the first President of the United States, <a href="/wiki/George_Washington" title="George Washington">George Washington</a>, was inaugurated; the first <a href="/wiki/United_States_Congress" title="United States Congress">United States Congress</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States" title="Supreme Court of the United States">Supreme Court of the United States</a> each assembled for the first time, and the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Bill_of_Rights" title="United States Bill of Rights">United States Bill of Rights</a> was drafted, all at <a href="/wiki/Federal_Hall" title="Federal Hall">Federal Hall</a> on Wall Street.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-118"><a href="#cite_note-118">[118]</a></sup> By 1790, New York had surpassed <a href="/wiki/Philadelphia" title="Philadelphia">Philadelphia</a> as the largest city in the United States.</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Nineteenth_century">Nineteenth century</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Hippolyte_Sebron_-_Rue_De_New-York_En_1840.jpg"><img alt="A painting of a snowy city street with horse-drawn sleds and a 19th-century fire truck under blue sky" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="505" data-file-width="742" height="150" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/Hippolyte_Sebron_-_Rue_De_New-York_En_1840.jpg/220px-Hippolyte_Sebron_-_Rue_De_New-York_En_1840.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/Hippolyte_Sebron_-_Rue_De_New-York_En_1840.jpg/330px-Hippolyte_Sebron_-_Rue_De_New-York_En_1840.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/Hippolyte_Sebron_-_Rue_De_New-York_En_1840.jpg/440px-Hippolyte_Sebron_-_Rue_De_New-York_En_1840.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Hippolyte_Sebron_-_Rue_De_New-York_En_1840.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
<a href="/wiki/Broadway_(Manhattan)" title="Broadway (Manhattan)">Broadway</a> follows the Native American <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wickquasgeck" title="Wickquasgeck">Wickquasgeck</a> Trail through Manhattan.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-119"><a href="#cite_note-119">[119]</a></sup></div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Under New York State's gradual <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Abolition_of_slavery_in_the_USA" title="Abolition of slavery in the USA">abolition</a> act of 1799, children of slave mothers were to be eventually liberated but to be held in <a href="/wiki/Indentured_servitude" title="Indentured servitude">indentured servitude</a> until their mid-to-late twenties.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-120"><a href="#cite_note-120">[120]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-121"><a href="#cite_note-121">[121]</a></sup> Together with slaves freed by their masters after the Revolutionary War and escaped slaves, a significant free-black population gradually developed in Manhattan. Under such influential <a href="/wiki/Founding_Fathers_of_the_United_States" title="Founding Fathers of the United States">United States founders</a> as <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Hamilton" title="Alexander Hamilton">Alexander Hamilton</a> and <a href="/wiki/John_Jay" title="John Jay">John Jay</a>, the <a href="/wiki/New_York_Manumission_Society" title="New York Manumission Society">New York Manumission Society</a> worked for abolition and established the <a href="/wiki/African_Free_School" title="African Free School">African Free School</a> to educate black children.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Divided_122-0"><a href="#cite_note-Divided-122">[122]</a></sup> It was not until 1827 that slavery was completely abolished in the state, and free blacks struggled afterward with discrimination. New York interracial abolitionist activism continued; among its leaders were graduates of the African Free School. The city's black population reached more than 16,000 in 1840.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-123"><a href="#cite_note-123">[123]</a></sup></p>
<p>In the 19th century, the city was transformed by development relating to its status as a trading center, as well as by European <a href="/wiki/Immigration" title="Immigration">immigration</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-124"><a href="#cite_note-124">[124]</a></sup> The city adopted the <a href="/wiki/Commissioners%27_Plan_of_1811" title="Commissioners' Plan of 1811">Commissioners' Plan of 1811</a>, which expanded the city <a href="/wiki/Grid_plan#Early_United_States" title="Grid plan">street grid</a> to encompass all of Manhattan. The 1825 completion of the <a href="/wiki/Erie_Canal" title="Erie Canal">Erie Canal</a> through <a href="/wiki/Central_New_York" title="Central New York">central New York</a> connected the Atlantic port to the agricultural markets and commodities of the North American interior via the <a href="/wiki/Hudson_River" title="Hudson River">Hudson River</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Great_Lakes" title="Great Lakes">Great Lakes</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-125"><a href="#cite_note-125">[125]</a></sup> Local politics became dominated by <a href="/wiki/Tammany_Hall" title="Tammany Hall">Tammany Hall</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Political_machine" title="Political machine">political machine</a> supported by <a href="/wiki/Irish_diaspora" title="Irish diaspora">Irish</a> and <a href="/wiki/German_diaspora" title="German diaspora">German immigrants</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-126"><a href="#cite_note-126">[126]</a></sup></p>
<p>Several prominent American <a href="/wiki/Writer" title="Writer">literary figures</a> lived in New York during the 1830s and 1840s, including <a href="/wiki/William_Cullen_Bryant" title="William Cullen Bryant">William Cullen Bryant</a>, <a href="/wiki/Washington_Irving" title="Washington Irving">Washington Irving</a>, <a href="/wiki/Herman_Melville" title="Herman Melville">Herman Melville</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rufus_Wilmot_Griswold" title="Rufus Wilmot Griswold">Rufus Wilmot Griswold</a>, <a href="/wiki/John_Keese" title="John Keese">John Keese</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nathaniel_Parker_Willis" title="Nathaniel Parker Willis">Nathaniel Parker Willis</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Edgar_Allan_Poe" title="Edgar Allan Poe">Edgar Allan Poe</a>. Public-minded members of the contemporaneous business elite lobbied for the establishment of <a href="/wiki/Central_Park" title="Central Park">Central Park</a>, which in 1857 became the first landscaped park in an American city.</p>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mulberry_Street_NYC_c1900_LOC_3g04637u_edit.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2067" data-file-width="2800" height="162" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Mulberry_Street_NYC_c1900_LOC_3g04637u_edit.jpg/220px-Mulberry_Street_NYC_c1900_LOC_3g04637u_edit.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Mulberry_Street_NYC_c1900_LOC_3g04637u_edit.jpg/330px-Mulberry_Street_NYC_c1900_LOC_3g04637u_edit.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Mulberry_Street_NYC_c1900_LOC_3g04637u_edit.jpg/440px-Mulberry_Street_NYC_c1900_LOC_3g04637u_edit.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Mulberry_Street_NYC_c1900_LOC_3g04637u_edit.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
Manhattan's <a href="/wiki/Little_Italy,_Manhattan" title="Little Italy, Manhattan">Little Italy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lower_East_Side" title="Lower East Side">Lower East Side</a>, circa 1900.</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Great_Famine_(Ireland)" title="Great Famine (Ireland)">Great Irish Famine</a> brought a large influx of Irish immigrants. Over 200,000 were living in New York by 1860, upwards of a quarter of the city's population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-127"><a href="#cite_note-127">[127]</a></sup> There was also extensive immigration from the German provinces, where revolutions had disrupted societies, and Germans comprised another 25% of New York's population by 1860.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Harris_128-0"><a href="#cite_note-Harris-128">[128]</a></sup></p>
<p><a href="/wiki/Democratic_Party_(United_States)" title="Democratic Party (United States)">Democratic Party</a> candidates were consistently elected to local office, increasing the city's ties to the South and its dominant party. In 1861, Mayor <a href="/wiki/Fernando_Wood" title="Fernando Wood">Fernando Wood</a> called upon the <a href="/wiki/Alderman" title="Alderman">aldermen</a> to declare independence from Albany and the United States after the South seceded, but his proposal was not acted on.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Divided_122-1"><a href="#cite_note-Divided-122">[122]</a></sup> Anger at new <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Military_conscription" title="Military conscription">military conscription</a> laws during the <a href="/wiki/American_Civil_War" title="American Civil War">American Civil War</a> (1861–1865), which spared wealthier men who could afford to pay a $300 (equivalent to $5,835 in 2016) commutation fee to hire a substitute,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-129"><a href="#cite_note-129">[129]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-130"><a href="#cite_note-130">[130]</a></sup> led to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/New_York_Draft_Riots" title="New York Draft Riots">Draft Riots of 1863</a>, whose most visible participants were ethnic Irish working class.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Divided_122-2"><a href="#cite_note-Divided-122">[122]</a></sup> The situation deteriorated into attacks on New York's elite, followed by attacks on black New Yorkers and their property after fierce competition for a decade between Irish immigrants and black people for work. Rioters burned the Colored Orphan Asylum to the ground, with more than 200 children escaping harm due to efforts of the <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Police_Department" title="New York City Police Department">New York City Police Department</a>, which was mainly made up of Irish immigrants.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Harris_128-1"><a href="#cite_note-Harris-128">[128]</a></sup> According to historian <a href="/wiki/James_M._McPherson" title="James M. McPherson">James M. McPherson</a> (2001), at least 120 people were killed. In all, eleven black men were lynched over five days, and the riots forced hundreds of blacks to flee the city for <a href="/wiki/Williamsburg,_Brooklyn" title="Williamsburg, Brooklyn">Williamsburg</a>, Brooklyn, and New Jersey; the black population in Manhattan fell below 10,000 by 1865, which it had last been in 1820. The white working class had established dominance.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Harris_128-2"><a href="#cite_note-Harris-128">[128]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-McPherson_131-0"><a href="#cite_note-McPherson-131">[131]</a></sup> Violence by longshoremen against black men was especially fierce in the docks area.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Harris_128-3"><a href="#cite_note-Harris-128">[128]</a></sup> It was one of the worst incidents of civil unrest in American history.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-132"><a href="#cite_note-132">[132]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Modern_history">Modern history</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Old_timer_structural_worker2.jpg"><img alt="A man working on a steel girder high about a city skyline." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2401" data-file-width="3000" height="176" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Old_timer_structural_worker2.jpg/220px-Old_timer_structural_worker2.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Old_timer_structural_worker2.jpg/330px-Old_timer_structural_worker2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Old_timer_structural_worker2.jpg/440px-Old_timer_structural_worker2.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Old_timer_structural_worker2.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
A <a href="/wiki/Construction_worker" title="Construction worker">construction worker</a> on top of the <a href="/wiki/Empire_State_Building" title="Empire State Building">Empire State Building</a> as it was being built in 1930. The <a href="/wiki/Chrysler_Building" title="Chrysler Building">Chrysler Building</a> is below and behind him.</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>In 1898, the modern City of New York was formed with the consolidation of Brooklyn (until then a separate city), the County of New York (which then included parts of the Bronx), the County of Richmond, and the western portion of the County of Queens.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-133"><a href="#cite_note-133">[133]</a></sup> The opening of the <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Subway" title="New York City Subway">subway</a> in 1904, first built as separate private systems, helped bind the new city together. Throughout the first half of the 20th century, the city became a world center for industry, commerce, and communication.</p>
<p>In 1904, the <a href="/wiki/Steamship" title="Steamship">steamship</a> <i><a href="/wiki/PS_General_Slocum" title="PS General Slocum">General Slocum</a></i> caught fire in the <a href="/wiki/East_River" title="East River">East River</a>, killing 1,021 people on board. In 1911, the <a href="/wiki/Triangle_Shirtwaist_Factory_fire" title="Triangle Shirtwaist Factory fire">Triangle Shirtwaist Factory fire</a>, the city's worst industrial disaster, took the lives of 146 garment workers and spurred the growth of the <a href="/wiki/International_Ladies%27_Garment_Workers%27_Union" title="International Ladies' Garment Workers' Union">International Ladies' Garment Workers' Union</a> and major improvements in factory safety standards.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cornell1_134-0"><a href="#cite_note-cornell1-134">[134]</a></sup></p>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Dag_Hammarskjold_outside_the_UN_building.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3000" data-file-width="2456" height="208" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/Dag_Hammarskjold_outside_the_UN_building.jpg/170px-Dag_Hammarskjold_outside_the_UN_building.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/Dag_Hammarskjold_outside_the_UN_building.jpg/255px-Dag_Hammarskjold_outside_the_UN_building.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/Dag_Hammarskjold_outside_the_UN_building.jpg/340px-Dag_Hammarskjold_outside_the_UN_building.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Dag_Hammarskjold_outside_the_UN_building.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/UN_Secretary_General" title="UN Secretary General">UN Secretary General</a> <a href="/wiki/Dag_Hammarskj%C3%B6ld" title="Dag Hammarskjöld">Dag Hammarskjöld</a> in front of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/United_Nations_Headquarters" title="United Nations Headquarters">United Nations Headquarters</a> building, completed in 1952</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>New York's non-white population was 36,620 in 1890.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-135"><a href="#cite_note-135">[135]</a></sup> New York City was a prime destination in the early twentieth century for African Americans during the <a href="/wiki/Great_Migration_(African_American)" title="Great Migration (African American)">Great Migration</a> from the American South, and by 1916, New York City had become home to the largest urban <a href="/wiki/African_diaspora" title="African diaspora">African diaspora</a> in North America. The <a href="/wiki/Harlem_Renaissance" title="Harlem Renaissance">Harlem Renaissance</a> of literary and cultural life flourished during the era of <a href="/wiki/Prohibition_in_the_United_States" title="Prohibition in the United States">Prohibition</a>. The larger economic boom generated construction of <a href="/wiki/Skyscraper" title="Skyscraper">skyscrapers</a> competing in height and creating an identifiable <a href="/wiki/Skyline" title="Skyline">skyline</a>.</p>
<p>New York became the most populous urbanized area in the world in the early 1920s, overtaking London. The metropolitan area surpassed the 10 million mark in the early 1930s, becoming the first <a href="/wiki/Megacity" title="Megacity">megacity</a> in human history.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-136"><a href="#cite_note-136">[136]</a></sup> The difficult years of the <a href="/wiki/Great_Depression" title="Great Depression">Great Depression</a> saw the election of reformer <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fiorello_La_Guardia" title="Fiorello La Guardia">Fiorello La Guardia</a> as mayor and the fall of <a href="/wiki/Tammany_Hall" title="Tammany Hall">Tammany Hall</a> after eighty years of political dominance.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-137"><a href="#cite_note-137">[137]</a></sup></p>
<p>Returning <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a> veterans created a post-war economic boom and the development of large <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Housing_tract" title="Housing tract">housing tracts</a> in eastern Queens. New York emerged from the war unscathed as the leading city of the world, with Wall Street leading America's place as the world's dominant economic power. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/United_Nations_Headquarters" title="United Nations Headquarters">United Nations Headquarters</a> was completed in 1952, solidifying New York's global <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Geopolitical" title="Geopolitical">geopolitical</a> influence, and the rise of <a href="/wiki/Abstract_expressionism" title="Abstract expressionism">abstract expressionism</a> in the city precipitated New York's displacement of <a href="/wiki/Paris" title="Paris">Paris</a> as the center of the art world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-138"><a href="#cite_note-138">[138]</a></sup></p>
<div class="thumb tleft">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Stonewall_Inn_5_pride_weekend_2016.jpg"><img alt="A two-story building with brick on the first floor, with two arched doorways, and gray stucco on the second floor off of which hang numerous rainbow flags." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3456" data-file-width="4608" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Stonewall_Inn_5_pride_weekend_2016.jpg/220px-Stonewall_Inn_5_pride_weekend_2016.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Stonewall_Inn_5_pride_weekend_2016.jpg/330px-Stonewall_Inn_5_pride_weekend_2016.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Stonewall_Inn_5_pride_weekend_2016.jpg/440px-Stonewall_Inn_5_pride_weekend_2016.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Stonewall_Inn_5_pride_weekend_2016.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
The <a href="/wiki/Stonewall_Inn" title="Stonewall Inn">Stonewall Inn</a> in <a href="/wiki/Greenwich_Village" title="Greenwich Village">Greenwich Village</a>, a designated U.S. <a href="/wiki/National_Historic_Landmark" title="National Historic Landmark">National Historic Landmark</a> and <a href="/wiki/Stonewall_National_Monument" title="Stonewall National Monument">National Monument</a>, as the site of the 1969 <a href="/wiki/Stonewall_riots" title="Stonewall riots">Stonewall riots</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-139"><a href="#cite_note-139">[139]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-140"><a href="#cite_note-140">[140]</a></sup></div>
</div>
</div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Stonewall_riots" title="Stonewall riots">Stonewall riots</a> were a series of spontaneous, violent demonstrations by members of the <a href="/wiki/LGBT_community" title="LGBT community">gay community</a> against a <a href="/wiki/Police_raid" title="Police raid">police raid</a> that took place in the early morning hours of June 28, 1969, at the <a href="/wiki/Stonewall_Inn" title="Stonewall Inn">Stonewall Inn</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Greenwich_Village" title="Greenwich Village">Greenwich Village</a> neighborhood of Lower Manhattan. They are widely considered to constitute the single most important event leading to the <a href="/wiki/Gay_liberation" title="Gay liberation">gay liberation</a> movement<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-KentuckyStonewall_141-0"><a href="#cite_note-KentuckyStonewall-141">[141]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PinkNewsStonewall_142-0"><a href="#cite_note-PinkNewsStonewall-142">[142]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EncycloStonewall_143-0"><a href="#cite_note-EncycloStonewall-143">[143]</a></sup> and the modern fight for <a href="/wiki/LGBT_rights_in_the_United_States" title="LGBT rights in the United States">LGBT rights in the United States</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NPSStonewall_144-0"><a href="#cite_note-NPSStonewall-144">[144]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ObamaStonewall_145-0"><a href="#cite_note-ObamaStonewall-145">[145]</a></sup></p>
<p>In the 1970s, job losses due to <a href="/wiki/Deindustrialization" title="Deindustrialization">industrial restructuring</a> caused New York City to suffer from economic problems and rising crime rates.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-146"><a href="#cite_note-146">[146]</a></sup> While a resurgence in the financial industry greatly improved the city's economic health in the 1980s, New York's crime rate continued to increase through that decade and into the beginning of the 1990s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-147"><a href="#cite_note-147">[147]</a></sup> By the mid 1990s, crime rates started to drop dramatically due to revised police strategies, improving economic opportunities, <a href="/wiki/Gentrification" title="Gentrification">gentrification</a>, and new residents, both American transplants and new immigrants from Asia and Latin America. Important new sectors, such as <a href="/wiki/Silicon_Alley" title="Silicon Alley">Silicon Alley</a>, emerged in the city's economy. New York's population reached all-time highs in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/United_States_Census,_2000" title="United States Census, 2000">2000 Census</a> and then again in the 2010 Census.</p>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:UA_Flight_175_hits_WTC_south_tower_9-11_edit.jpeg"><img alt="Two tall, gray, rectangular buildings spewing black smoke and flames, particularly from the left of the two." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="925" data-file-width="1063" height="191" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/UA_Flight_175_hits_WTC_south_tower_9-11_edit.jpeg/220px-UA_Flight_175_hits_WTC_south_tower_9-11_edit.jpeg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/UA_Flight_175_hits_WTC_south_tower_9-11_edit.jpeg/330px-UA_Flight_175_hits_WTC_south_tower_9-11_edit.jpeg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/UA_Flight_175_hits_WTC_south_tower_9-11_edit.jpeg/440px-UA_Flight_175_hits_WTC_south_tower_9-11_edit.jpeg 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:UA_Flight_175_hits_WTC_south_tower_9-11_edit.jpeg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
United Airlines Flight 175 hits the South Tower of the original <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Center_(1973%E2%80%932001)" title="World Trade Center (1973–2001)">World Trade Center</a> on September 11, 2001.</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>The city and surrounding area suffered the bulk of the economic damage and largest loss of human life in the aftermath of the <a href="/wiki/September_11_attacks" title="September 11 attacks">September 11, 2001 attacks</a> when 10 of the 19 <a href="/wiki/Terrorism" title="Terrorism">terrorists</a> associated with <a href="/wiki/Al-Qaeda" title="Al-Qaeda">Al-Qaeda</a> piloted <a href="/wiki/American_Airlines_Flight_11" title="American Airlines Flight 11">American Airlines Flight 11</a> into the North Tower of the <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Center_(1973%E2%80%932001)" title="World Trade Center (1973–2001)">World Trade Center</a> and <a href="/wiki/United_Airlines_Flight_175" title="United Airlines Flight 175">United Airlines Flight 175</a> into the South Tower of the World Trade Center, and <a href="/wiki/Collapse_of_the_World_Trade_Center" title="Collapse of the World Trade Center">later destroyed them</a>, killing 2,192 <a href="/wiki/Civilian" title="Civilian">civilians</a>, 343 <a href="/wiki/Firefighter" title="Firefighter">firefighters</a>, and 71 <a href="/wiki/Law_enforcement_officer" title="Law enforcement officer">law enforcement officers</a> who were in the towers and in the surrounding area. The North Tower was subsequently the tallest building ever to be destroyed and still is.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-148"><a href="#cite_note-148">[148]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Center_site#Rebuilding" title="World Trade Center site">The rebuilding of the area</a>, has created a new <a href="/wiki/One_World_Trade_Center" title="One World Trade Center">One World Trade Center</a>, and a <a href="/wiki/National_September_11_Memorial_%26_Museum" title="National September 11 Memorial &amp; Museum">9/11 memorial and museum</a> along with other new buildings and infrastructure. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/World_Trade_Center_(PATH_station)" title="World Trade Center (PATH station)">World Trade Center PATH station</a>, which opened on July 19, 1909 as the Hudson Terminal, was also destroyed in the attack. A temporary station was built and opened on November 23, 2003. An 800,000-square-foot (74,000 m<sup>2</sup>) permanent station designed by <a href="/wiki/Santiago_Calatrava" title="Santiago Calatrava">Santiago Calatrava</a>, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/World_Trade_Center_Transportation_Hub" title="World Trade Center Transportation Hub">World Trade Center Transportation Hub</a>, the city's third-largest hub, was completed in 2016.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-149"><a href="#cite_note-149">[149]</a></sup> The new One World Trade Center is the tallest <a href="/wiki/Skyscraper" title="Skyscraper">skyscraper</a> in the Western Hemisphere<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-OneWTCtallest_150-0"><a href="#cite_note-OneWTCtallest-150">[150]</a></sup> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_tallest_buildings_in_the_world" title="List of tallest buildings in the world">fourth-tallest building in the world</a> by <a href="/wiki/Pinnacle" title="Pinnacle">pinnacle</a> height, with its <a href="/wiki/Spire" title="Spire">spire</a> reaching a symbolic 1,776 feet (541.3 m) in reference to the year of <a href="/wiki/United_States_Declaration_of_Independence" title="United States Declaration of Independence">American independence</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-151"><a href="#cite_note-151">[151]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-152"><a href="#cite_note-152">[152]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-153"><a href="#cite_note-153">[153]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-154"><a href="#cite_note-154">[154]</a></sup></p>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Occupy_Wall_Street" title="Occupy Wall Street">Occupy Wall Street</a> protests in <a href="/wiki/Zuccotti_Park" title="Zuccotti Park">Zuccotti Park</a> in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Financial_District_(Manhattan)" title="Financial District (Manhattan)">Financial District</a> of Lower Manhattan began on September 17, 2011, receiving global attention and popularizing the <a href="/wiki/Occupy_movement" title="Occupy movement">Occupy</a> <a href="/wiki/Social_movement" title="Social movement">movement</a> against <a href="/wiki/Social_inequality" title="Social inequality">social</a> and <a href="/wiki/Economic_inequality" title="Economic inequality">economic inequality</a> worldwide.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-155"><a href="#cite_note-155">[155]</a></sup></p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">Geography</span></h2>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_New_York_City" title="Geography of New York City">Geography of New York City</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Geography_of_New_York_Harbor" title="Geography of New York Harbor">Geography of New York Harbor</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Aster_newyorkcity_lrg.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2607" data-file-width="1964" height="226" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Aster_newyorkcity_lrg.jpg/170px-Aster_newyorkcity_lrg.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Aster_newyorkcity_lrg.jpg/255px-Aster_newyorkcity_lrg.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Aster_newyorkcity_lrg.jpg/340px-Aster_newyorkcity_lrg.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Aster_newyorkcity_lrg.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
<a href="/wiki/Satellite_imagery" title="Satellite imagery">Satellite imagery</a> illustrating the core of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/New_York_City_Metropolitan_Area" title="New York City Metropolitan Area">New York City Metropolitan Area</a>, with <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Manhattan_Island" title="Manhattan Island">Manhattan Island</a> at its center</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>New York City is situated in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Northeastern_United_States_(U.S._Census_Bureau)" title="Northeastern United States (U.S. Census Bureau)">Northeastern United States</a>, in southeastern New York State, approximately halfway between <a href="/wiki/Washington,_D.C." title="Washington, D.C.">Washington, D.C.</a> and <a href="/wiki/Boston" title="Boston">Boston</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-156"><a href="#cite_note-156">[156]</a></sup> The location at the mouth of the <a href="/wiki/Hudson_River" title="Hudson River">Hudson River</a>, which feeds into a naturally sheltered harbor and then into the <a href="/wiki/Atlantic_Ocean" title="Atlantic Ocean">Atlantic Ocean</a>, has helped the city grow in significance as a trading <a href="/wiki/Port" title="Port">port</a>. Most of New York City is built on the three islands of <a href="/wiki/Long_Island" title="Long Island">Long Island</a>, Manhattan, and Staten Island.</p>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Hudson_River" title="Hudson River">Hudson River</a> flows through the <a href="/wiki/Hudson_Valley" title="Hudson Valley">Hudson Valley</a> into <a href="/wiki/New_York_Bay" title="New York Bay">New York Bay</a>. Between New York City and <a href="/wiki/Troy,_New_York" title="Troy, New York">Troy, New York</a>, the river is an <a href="/wiki/Estuary" title="Estuary">estuary</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-157"><a href="#cite_note-157">[157]</a></sup> The Hudson River separates the city from the U.S. state of <a href="/wiki/New_Jersey" title="New Jersey">New Jersey</a>. The <a href="/wiki/East_River" title="East River">East River</a>—a tidal strait—flows from <a href="/wiki/Long_Island_Sound" title="Long Island Sound">Long Island Sound</a> and separates the Bronx and Manhattan from Long Island. The <a href="/wiki/Harlem_River" title="Harlem River">Harlem River</a>, another tidal strait between the East and Hudson Rivers, separates most of Manhattan from the Bronx. The <a href="/wiki/Bronx_River" title="Bronx River">Bronx River</a>, which flows through the Bronx and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Westchester_County" title="Westchester County">Westchester County</a>, is the only entirely <a href="/wiki/Fresh_water" title="Fresh water">fresh water</a> river in the city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nytimes_158-0"><a href="#cite_note-nytimes-158">[158]</a></sup></p>
<p>The city's land has been altered substantially by human intervention, with considerable <a href="/wiki/Land_reclamation" title="Land reclamation">land reclamation</a> along the waterfronts since Dutch colonial times; reclamation is most prominent in <a href="/wiki/Lower_Manhattan" title="Lower Manhattan">Lower Manhattan</a>, with developments such as <a href="/wiki/Battery_Park_City" title="Battery Park City">Battery Park City</a> in the 1970s and 1980s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-gillespie-p71_159-0"><a href="#cite_note-gillespie-p71-159">[159]</a></sup> Some of the natural relief in topography has been evened out, especially in Manhattan.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-160"><a href="#cite_note-160">[160]</a></sup></p>
<p>The city's total area is 468.484 square miles (1,213.37 km<sup>2</sup>), including 302.643 sq mi (783.84 km<sup>2</sup>) of land and 165.841 sq mi (429.53 km<sup>2</sup>) of this is water.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CensusGazetteer_161-0"><a href="#cite_note-CensusGazetteer-161">[161]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYT_Land_Estimate_162-0"><a href="#cite_note-NYT_Land_Estimate-162">[162]</a></sup> The highest point in the city is <a href="/wiki/Todt_Hill" title="Todt Hill">Todt Hill</a> on Staten Island, which, at 409.8 feet (124.9 m) <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Above_mean_sea_level" title="Above mean sea level">above sea level</a>, is the highest point on the Eastern Seaboard south of <a href="/wiki/Maine" title="Maine">Maine</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-163"><a href="#cite_note-163">[163]</a></sup> The summit of the ridge is mostly covered in woodlands as part of the <a href="/wiki/Staten_Island_Greenbelt" title="Staten Island Greenbelt">Staten Island Greenbelt</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-164"><a href="#cite_note-164">[164]</a></sup></p>
<div style="clear:both;"></div>

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cityscape">Cityscape</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tnone" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right:auto; overflow:hidden; width:auto; max-width:1808px;">
<div class="thumbinner" style="">
<div class="overflowbugx" style="overflow:auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:10_mile_panorama_of_NYC,_taken_June,_2017.jpg" title="Ten-mile Manhattan panorama from 120th Street to the Battery, taken June 2017 from Weehawken, New Jersey.  # Riverside Church # Time Warner Center # 220 Central Park South # One57 # 432 Park Avenue # Chrysler Building # Bank of America Tower # Conde Nast Building # The New York Times Building # Empire State Building # Met Life Tower # 30 Hudson Yards # 10 Hudson Yards # 15 Hudson Yards # 56 Leonard Street # 8 Spruce Street # Woolworth Building # 70 Pine Street # 30 Park Place # 40 Wall Street # Three World Trade Center # Four World Trade Center # One World Trade Center "><img alt="" data-file-height="1203" data-file-width="8265" height="262" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/22/10_mile_panorama_of_NYC%2C_taken_June%2C_2017.jpg/1800px-10_mile_panorama_of_NYC%2C_taken_June%2C_2017.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/22/10_mile_panorama_of_NYC%2C_taken_June%2C_2017.jpg/2700px-10_mile_panorama_of_NYC%2C_taken_June%2C_2017.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/22/10_mile_panorama_of_NYC%2C_taken_June%2C_2017.jpg/3600px-10_mile_panorama_of_NYC%2C_taken_June%2C_2017.jpg 2x" width="1800"/></a></div>
