</div>
</div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Architecture">Architecture</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Architecture_of_New_York_City" title="Architecture of New York City">Architecture of New York City</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_tallest_buildings_in_New_York_City" title="List of tallest buildings in New York City">List of tallest buildings in New York City</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Antiguo_vs_Moderno_(4432379954).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3264" data-file-width="2448" height="227" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Antiguo_vs_Moderno_%284432379954%29.jpg/170px-Antiguo_vs_Moderno_%284432379954%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Antiguo_vs_Moderno_%284432379954%29.jpg/255px-Antiguo_vs_Moderno_%284432379954%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Antiguo_vs_Moderno_%284432379954%29.jpg/340px-Antiguo_vs_Moderno_%284432379954%29.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Antiguo_vs_Moderno_(4432379954).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
Modernist architecture juxtaposed with <a href="/wiki/Classical_architecture" title="Classical architecture">classical architecture</a> is seen often in New York City.</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="thumb tmulti tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:154px;max-width:154px">
<div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:152px;max-width:152px">
<div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Chrysler_Building_spire,_Manhattan,_by_Carol_Highsmith_(LOC_highsm.04444).jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="4284" data-file-width="2344" height="274" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Chrysler_Building_spire%2C_Manhattan%2C_by_Carol_Highsmith_%28LOC_highsm.04444%29.jpg/150px-Chrysler_Building_spire%2C_Manhattan%2C_by_Carol_Highsmith_%28LOC_highsm.04444%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Chrysler_Building_spire%2C_Manhattan%2C_by_Carol_Highsmith_%28LOC_highsm.04444%29.jpg/225px-Chrysler_Building_spire%2C_Manhattan%2C_by_Carol_Highsmith_%28LOC_highsm.04444%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Chrysler_Building_spire%2C_Manhattan%2C_by_Carol_Highsmith_%28LOC_highsm.04444%29.jpg/300px-Chrysler_Building_spire%2C_Manhattan%2C_by_Carol_Highsmith_%28LOC_highsm.04444%29.jpg 2x" width="150"/></a></div>
</div>
<div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:152px;max-width:152px">
<div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Empire_State_Building_(HDR).jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="3874" data-file-width="2617" height="222" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Empire_State_Building_%28HDR%29.jpg/150px-Empire_State_Building_%28HDR%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Empire_State_Building_%28HDR%29.jpg/225px-Empire_State_Building_%28HDR%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Empire_State_Building_%28HDR%29.jpg/300px-Empire_State_Building_%28HDR%29.jpg 2x" width="150"/></a></div>
<div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">The <a href="/wiki/Chrysler_Building" title="Chrysler Building">Chrysler Building</a>, above, built in 1930, is an example of the <a href="/wiki/Art_Deco" title="Art Deco">Art Deco</a> style, with ornamental hub caps and a <a href="/wiki/Spire" title="Spire">spire</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Empire_State_Building" title="Empire State Building">Empire State Building</a> is a solitary icon of New York. It was the <a href="/wiki/List_of_tallest_buildings_and_structures" title="List of tallest buildings and structures">world's tallest building</a> 1931–70 and is defined by its <a href="/wiki/Setback_(architecture)" title="Setback (architecture)">setbacks</a>, Art Deco details and the spire.</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="thumb tleft">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Greenpoint_Houses.JPG"><img alt="A view down a street with rowhouses in brown, white, and various shades of red." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1704" data-file-width="2272" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Greenpoint_Houses.JPG/220px-Greenpoint_Houses.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Greenpoint_Houses.JPG/330px-Greenpoint_Houses.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Greenpoint_Houses.JPG/440px-Greenpoint_Houses.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Greenpoint_Houses.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
Landmark 19th-century <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rowhouse" title="Rowhouse">rowhouses</a>, including <a href="/wiki/Brownstone" title="Brownstone">brownstones</a>, on tree-lined Kent Street in the <a href="/wiki/Greenpoint,_Brooklyn" title="Greenpoint, Brooklyn">Greenpoint Historic District</a>, Brooklyn.</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>New York has architecturally noteworthy buildings in a wide range of styles and from distinct time periods, from the <a href="/wiki/Saltbox" title="Saltbox">saltbox style</a> <a href="/wiki/Wyckoff_House" title="Wyckoff House">Pieter Claesen Wyckoff House</a> in Brooklyn, the oldest section of which dates to 1656, to the modern <a href="/wiki/One_World_Trade_Center" title="One World Trade Center">One World Trade Center</a>, the skyscraper at <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Center_site" title="World Trade Center site">Ground Zero</a> in Lower Manhattan and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_most_expensive_buildings_in_the_world" title="List of most expensive buildings in the world">most expensive office tower</a> in the world by construction cost.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-165"><a href="#cite_note-165">[165]</a></sup></p>
<p>Manhattan's <a href="/wiki/Skyline" title="Skyline">skyline</a>, with its many skyscrapers, is universally recognized, and the city has been home to several of the <a href="/wiki/Skyscraper#History_of_the_tallest_skyscrapers" title="Skyscraper">tallest buildings in the world</a>. As of 2011<sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=New_York_City&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, New York City had 5,937 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/High-rise" title="High-rise">high-rise</a> buildings, of which 550 completed structures were at least 330 feet (100 m) high, both second in the world after <a href="/wiki/Hong_Kong" title="Hong Kong">Hong Kong</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-166"><a href="#cite_note-166">[166]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-167"><a href="#cite_note-167">[167]</a></sup> with over 50 completed <a href="/wiki/List_of_tallest_buildings_in_New_York_City" title="List of tallest buildings in New York City">skyscrapers taller than 656 feet (200 m)</a>. These include the <a href="/wiki/Woolworth_Building" title="Woolworth Building">Woolworth Building</a>, an early example of <a href="/wiki/Gothic_Revival_architecture" title="Gothic Revival architecture">Gothic Revival architecture</a> in skyscraper design, built with massively scaled Gothic detailing; completed in 1913, for 17 years it was the world's tallest building.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-168"><a href="#cite_note-168">[168]</a></sup></p>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/1916_Zoning_Resolution" title="1916 Zoning Resolution">1916 Zoning Resolution</a> required <a href="/wiki/Setback_(architecture)" title="Setback (architecture)">setbacks</a> in new buildings and restricted towers to a percentage of the <a href="/wiki/Land_lot" title="Land lot">lot size</a>, to allow sunlight to reach the streets below.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-169"><a href="#cite_note-169">[169]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Art_Deco" title="Art Deco">Art Deco</a> style of the <a href="/wiki/Chrysler_Building" title="Chrysler Building">Chrysler Building</a> (1930) and <a href="/wiki/Empire_State_Building" title="Empire State Building">Empire State Building</a> (1931), with their tapered tops and steel <a href="/wiki/Spire" title="Spire">spires</a>, reflected the zoning requirements. The buildings have distinctive ornamentation, such as the eagles at the corners of the 61st floor on the Chrysler Building, and are considered some of the finest examples of the <a href="/wiki/Art_Deco" title="Art Deco">Art Deco</a> style.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-170"><a href="#cite_note-170">[170]</a></sup> A highly influential example of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/International_style_(architecture)" title="International style (architecture)">international style</a> in the United States is the <a href="/wiki/Seagram_Building" title="Seagram Building">Seagram Building</a> (1957), distinctive for its façade using visible bronze-toned <a href="/wiki/I-beam" title="I-beam">I-beams</a> to evoke the building's structure. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cond%C3%A9_Nast_Building" title="Condé Nast Building">Condé Nast Building</a> (2000) is a prominent example of <a href="/wiki/Sustainable_design" title="Sustainable design">green design</a> in American skyscrapers<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-greenbuilding_171-0"><a href="#cite_note-greenbuilding-171">[171]</a></sup> and has received an award from the <a href="/wiki/American_Institute_of_Architects" title="American Institute of Architects">American Institute of Architects</a> and AIA New York State for its design.</p>
<p>The character of New York's large residential districts is often defined by the elegant <a href="/wiki/Brownstone" title="Brownstone">brownstone</a> <a href="/wiki/Terraced_house" title="Terraced house">rowhouses</a> and <a href="/wiki/Townhouse" title="Townhouse">townhouses</a> and shabby <a href="/wiki/Tenement" title="Tenement">tenements</a> that were built during a period of rapid expansion from 1870 to 1930.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-172"><a href="#cite_note-172">[172]</a></sup> In contrast, New York City also has neighborhoods that are less densely populated and feature free-standing dwellings. In neighborhoods such as <a href="/wiki/Riverdale,_Bronx" title="Riverdale, Bronx">Riverdale</a> (in the Bronx), <a href="/wiki/Ditmas_Park,_Brooklyn" title="Ditmas Park, Brooklyn">Ditmas Park</a> (in Brooklyn), and <a href="/wiki/Douglaston,_Queens" title="Douglaston, Queens">Douglaston</a> (in Queens), large single-family homes are common in various architectural styles such as <a href="/wiki/Tudor_Revival_architecture" title="Tudor Revival architecture">Tudor Revival</a> and <a href="/wiki/Victorian_architecture" title="Victorian architecture">Victorian</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-173"><a href="#cite_note-173">[173]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-174"><a href="#cite_note-174">[174]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-175"><a href="#cite_note-175">[175]</a></sup></p>
<p>Stone and brick became the city's building materials of choice after the construction of wood-frame houses was limited in the aftermath of the <a href="/wiki/Great_Fire_of_New_York" title="Great Fire of New York">Great Fire of 1835</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lankevich-p82_176-0"><a href="#cite_note-lankevich-p82-176">[176]</a></sup> A distinctive feature of many of the city's buildings is the wooden roof-mounted <a href="/wiki/Water_tower" title="Water tower">water towers</a>. In the 1800s, the city required their installation on buildings higher than six stories to prevent the need for excessively high water pressures at lower elevations, which could break municipal water pipes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-177"><a href="#cite_note-177">[177]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Garden_city_movement" title="Garden city movement">Garden apartments</a> became popular during the 1920s in outlying areas, such as <a href="/wiki/Jackson_Heights,_Queens" title="Jackson Heights, Queens">Jackson Heights</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-178"><a href="#cite_note-178">[178]</a></sup></p>
<p>According to the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Geological_Survey" title="United States Geological Survey">United States Geological Survey</a>, an updated analysis of <a href="/wiki/Seismic_hazard" title="Seismic hazard">seismic hazard</a> in July 2014 revealed a "slightly lower hazard for tall buildings" in New York City than previously assessed. Scientists estimated this lessened risk based upon a lower likelihood than previously thought of slow shaking near the city, which would be more likely to cause damage to taller structures from an earthquake in the vicinity of the city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-179"><a href="#cite_note-179">[179]</a></sup></p>
<div style="clear:both;"></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Boroughs">Boroughs</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Borough_(New_York_City)" title="Borough (New York City)">Borough (New York City)</a> and <a href="/wiki/Neighborhoods_in_New_York_City" title="Neighborhoods in New York City">Neighborhoods in New York City</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:238px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:5_Boroughs_Labels_New_York_City_Map.svg"><img alt="A map with five insular regions of different colors." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1978" data-file-width="2000" height="233" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/34/5_Boroughs_Labels_New_York_City_Map.svg/236px-5_Boroughs_Labels_New_York_City_Map.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/34/5_Boroughs_Labels_New_York_City_Map.svg/354px-5_Boroughs_Labels_New_York_City_Map.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/34/5_Boroughs_Labels_New_York_City_Map.svg/472px-5_Boroughs_Labels_New_York_City_Map.svg.png 2x" width="236"/></a>

Manhattan</div>
<div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column"><span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color: #FFFF33; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;"> </span> 2. Brooklyn</div>
<div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column"><span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color: #FF7F00; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;"> </span> 3. Queens</div>

Bronx</div>
<div class="legend" style="-webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;page-break-inside: avoid;break-inside: avoid-column"><span class="legend-color" style="display:inline-block; width:1.5em; height:1.5em; margin:1px 0; border:1px solid black; background-color: #984EA3; color:black; font-size:100%; text-align:center;"> </span> 5. Staten Island</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>

<p>New York City is often referred to collectively as <i><b>the five boroughs</b></i>, and in turn, there are <a href="/wiki/Category:Neighborhoods_in_New_York_City" title="Category:Neighborhoods in New York City">hundreds of distinct neighborhoods</a> throughout the boroughs, many with a definable history and character to call their own. If the boroughs were each independent cities, four of the boroughs (Brooklyn, Queens, Manhattan, and the Bronx) would be among the ten most populous cities in the United States (Staten island would be ranked 37th) ; these same boroughs are coterminous with the four most densely populated counties in the United States (New York [Manhattan], Kings [Brooklyn], Bronx, and Queens).</p>
<ul>
<li><b><a href="/wiki/Manhattan" title="Manhattan">Manhattan</a></b> (New York County) is the geographically smallest and most densely populated borough, is home to <a href="/wiki/Central_Park" title="Central Park">Central Park</a> and most of the city's <a href="/wiki/Skyscraper" title="Skyscraper">skyscrapers</a>, and may be locally known simply as <i>The City</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ManhattanTheCity_181-0"><a href="#cite_note-ManhattanTheCity-181">[181]</a></sup> Manhattan's (New York County's) population density of 72,033 people per square mile (27,812/km²) in 2015 makes it the <a href="/wiki/County_statistics_of_the_United_States#Population_density" title="County statistics of the United States">highest of any county in the United States</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_United_States_cities_by_population_density#New_York_City_boroughs" title="List of United States cities by population density">higher than the density of any individual American city</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-182"><a href="#cite_note-182">[182]</a></sup> Manhattan is the cultural, administrative, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Financial_center" title="Financial center">financial center</a> of New York City and contains the <a href="/wiki/Headquarters" title="Headquarters">headquarters</a> of many major <a href="/wiki/Multinational_corporation" title="Multinational corporation">multinational corporations</a>, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/United_Nations_Headquarters" title="United Nations Headquarters">United Nations Headquarters</a>, <a href="/wiki/Wall_Street" title="Wall Street">Wall Street</a>, and a number of important <a href="/wiki/University" title="University">universities</a>. Manhattan is often described as the financial and cultural center of the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-183"><a href="#cite_note-183">[183]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-184"><a href="#cite_note-184">[184]</a></sup>
<div class="paragraphbreak" style="margin-top:0.5em"></div>
Most of the borough is situated on <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Manhattan_Island" title="Manhattan Island">Manhattan Island</a>, at the mouth of the <a href="/wiki/Hudson_River" title="Hudson River">Hudson River</a>. Several small islands are also part of the borough of Manhattan, including <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Randall%27s_Island" title="Randall's Island">Randall's Island</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wards_Island" title="Wards Island">Wards Island</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Roosevelt_Island" title="Roosevelt Island">Roosevelt Island</a> in the <a href="/wiki/East_River" title="East River">East River</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Governors_Island" title="Governors Island">Governors Island</a> and <a href="/wiki/Liberty_Island" title="Liberty Island">Liberty Island</a> to the south in <a href="/wiki/New_York_Harbor" title="New York Harbor">New York Harbor</a>. Manhattan Island is loosely divided into <a href="/wiki/Lower_Manhattan" title="Lower Manhattan">Lower</a>, <a href="/wiki/Midtown_Manhattan" title="Midtown Manhattan">Midtown</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Upper_Manhattan" title="Upper Manhattan">Uptown</a> regions. Uptown Manhattan is divided by Central Park into the <a href="/wiki/Upper_East_Side" title="Upper East Side">Upper East Side</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Upper_West_Side" title="Upper West Side">Upper West Side</a>, and above the park is <a href="/wiki/Harlem" title="Harlem">Harlem</a>. The borough also includes a small neighborhood on the <a href="/wiki/Contiguous_United_States" title="Contiguous United States">United States mainland</a>, called <a href="/wiki/Marble_Hill,_Manhattan" title="Marble Hill, Manhattan">Marble Hill</a>, which is contiguous with The Bronx. New York City's remaining four boroughs are collectively referred to as the <i>outer boroughs</i>.</li>
<li><b><a href="/wiki/Brooklyn" title="Brooklyn">Brooklyn</a></b> (Kings County), on the western tip of <a href="/wiki/Long_Island" title="Long Island">Long Island</a>, is the city's most populous borough. Brooklyn is known for its cultural, social, and ethnic diversity, an independent art scene, <a href="/wiki/List_of_Brooklyn_neighborhoods" title="List of Brooklyn neighborhoods">distinct neighborhoods</a>, and a distinctive architectural heritage. <a href="/wiki/Downtown_Brooklyn" title="Downtown Brooklyn">Downtown Brooklyn</a> is the largest central core neighborhood in the outer boroughs. The borough has a long beachfront shoreline including <a href="/wiki/Coney_Island" title="Coney Island">Coney Island</a>, established in the 1870s as one of the earliest amusement grounds in the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-185"><a href="#cite_note-185">[185]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Marine_Park" title="Marine Park">Marine Park</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LargestParksNYC_186-0"><a href="#cite_note-LargestParksNYC-186">[186]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Prospect_Park_(Brooklyn)" title="Prospect Park (Brooklyn)">Prospect Park</a> are the two largest parks in Brooklyn. Since 2010, Brooklyn has evolved into a thriving hub of <a href="/wiki/Entrepreneurship" title="Entrepreneurship">entrepreneurship</a> and <a href="/wiki/High_tech" title="High tech">high technology</a> <a href="/wiki/Startup_company" title="Startup company">startup firms</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-187"><a href="#cite_note-187">[187]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BrooklynDesignHub_188-0"><a href="#cite_note-BrooklynDesignHub-188">[188]</a></sup> and of <a href="/wiki/Postmodern_art" title="Postmodern art">postmodern art</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BrooklynArt1_189-0"><a href="#cite_note-BrooklynArt1-189">[189]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Design" title="Design">design</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BrooklynDesignHub_188-1"><a href="#cite_note-BrooklynDesignHub-188">[188]</a></sup></li>
<li><b><a href="/wiki/Queens" title="Queens">Queens</a></b> (Queens County), on Long Island north and east of Brooklyn, is geographically the largest borough, the most <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ethnic_diversity" title="Ethnic diversity">ethnically diverse</a> county in the United States,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-queensdiverse_190-0"><a href="#cite_note-queensdiverse-190">[190]</a></sup> and the most ethnically diverse urban area in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-QueensMostDiverseWorld1_191-0"><a href="#cite_note-QueensMostDiverseWorld1-191">[191]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-QueensMostDiverseWorld2_192-0"><a href="#cite_note-QueensMostDiverseWorld2-192">[192]</a></sup> Historically a collection of small towns and villages founded by the Dutch, the borough has since developed both commercial and residential prominence. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Downtown_Flushing" title="Downtown Flushing">Downtown Flushing</a> has become one of the busiest central core neighborhoods in the outer boroughs. Queens is the site of <a href="/wiki/Citi_Field" title="Citi Field">Citi Field</a>, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Baseball_stadium" title="Baseball stadium">baseball stadium</a> of the <a href="/wiki/New_York_Mets" title="New York Mets">New York Mets</a>, and hosts the annual <a href="/wiki/US_Open_(tennis)" title="US Open (tennis)">U.S. Open tennis tournament</a> at <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Flushing_Meadows-Corona_Park" title="Flushing Meadows-Corona Park">Flushing Meadows-Corona Park</a>. Additionally, two of the three busiest airports serving the New York metropolitan area, <a href="/wiki/John_F._Kennedy_International_Airport" title="John F. Kennedy International Airport">John F. Kennedy International Airport</a> and <a href="/wiki/LaGuardia_Airport" title="LaGuardia Airport">LaGuardia Airport</a>, are located in Queens. (The third is <a href="/wiki/Newark_Liberty_International_Airport" title="Newark Liberty International Airport">Newark Liberty International Airport</a> in <a href="/wiki/Newark,_New_Jersey" title="Newark, New Jersey">Newark</a>, <a href="/wiki/New_Jersey" title="New Jersey">New Jersey</a>.)</li>
<li><b><a href="/wiki/Staten_Island" title="Staten Island">Staten Island</a></b> (Richmond County) is the most <a href="/wiki/Suburb" title="Suburb">suburban</a> in character of the five boroughs. Staten Island is connected to Brooklyn by the <a href="/wiki/Verrazano-Narrows_Bridge" title="Verrazano-Narrows Bridge">Verrazano-Narrows Bridge</a> and to Manhattan by way of the free <a href="/wiki/Staten_Island_Ferry" title="Staten Island Ferry">Staten Island Ferry</a>, a daily <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Commuter" title="Commuter">commuter</a> ferry which provides unobstructed views of the <a href="/wiki/Statue_of_Liberty" title="Statue of Liberty">Statue of Liberty</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ellis_Island" title="Ellis Island">Ellis Island</a>, and Lower Manhattan. In central Staten Island, the <a href="/wiki/Staten_Island_Greenbelt" title="Staten Island Greenbelt">Staten Island Greenbelt</a> spans approximately 2,500 acres (10 km<sup>2</sup>), including 28 miles (45 km) of walking trails and one of the last undisturbed forests in the city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-193"><a href="#cite_note-193">[193]</a></sup> Designated in 1984 to protect the island's natural lands, the Greenbelt comprises seven city parks.</li>
<li><b><a href="/wiki/The_Bronx" title="The Bronx">The Bronx</a></b> (Bronx County) is New York City's northernmost borough and the only New York City borough with a majority of it a part of the mainland United States. It is the location of <a href="/wiki/Yankee_Stadium" title="Yankee Stadium">Yankee Stadium</a>, the baseball park of the <a href="/wiki/New_York_Yankees" title="New York Yankees">New York Yankees</a>, and home to the largest <a href="/wiki/Housing_cooperative" title="Housing cooperative">cooperatively owned housing</a> complex in the United States, <a href="/wiki/Co-op_City,_Bronx" title="Co-op City, Bronx">Co-op City</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-194"><a href="#cite_note-194">[194]</a></sup> It is also home to the <a href="/wiki/Bronx_Zoo" title="Bronx Zoo">Bronx Zoo</a>, the world's largest metropolitan zoo,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BronxZoo_195-0"><a href="#cite_note-BronxZoo-195">[195]</a></sup> which spans 265 acres (1.07 km<sup>2</sup>) and houses over 6,000 animals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-196"><a href="#cite_note-196">[196]</a></sup> The Bronx is also the birthplace of <a href="/wiki/Rapping" title="Rapping">rap</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hip_hop_culture" title="Hip hop culture">hip hop culture</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto_197-0"><a href="#cite_note-auto-197">[197]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Pelham_Bay_Park" title="Pelham Bay Park">Pelham Bay Park</a> is the largest park in New York City, at 2,765 acres (1,119 ha).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LargestParksNYC_186-1"><a href="#cite_note-LargestParksNYC-186">[186]</a></sup></li>
</ul>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Climate">Climate</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Hurricane_Sandy_Flooding_Avenue_C_2012.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2848" data-file-width="4288" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/Hurricane_Sandy_Flooding_Avenue_C_2012.JPG/220px-Hurricane_Sandy_Flooding_Avenue_C_2012.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/Hurricane_Sandy_Flooding_Avenue_C_2012.JPG/330px-Hurricane_Sandy_Flooding_Avenue_C_2012.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/Hurricane_Sandy_Flooding_Avenue_C_2012.JPG/440px-Hurricane_Sandy_Flooding_Avenue_C_2012.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Hurricane_Sandy_Flooding_Avenue_C_2012.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
<a href="/wiki/Avenue_C_(Manhattan)" title="Avenue C (Manhattan)">Avenue C</a> in Manhattan after flooding caused by <a href="/wiki/Hurricane_Sandy" title="Hurricane Sandy">Hurricane Sandy</a> on October 29, 2012.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-198"><a href="#cite_note-198">[198]</a></sup></div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Under the <a href="/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification" title="Köppen climate classification">Köppen climate classification</a>, using the 0 °C (32 °F) isotherm, New York City features a <a href="/wiki/Humid_subtropical_climate" title="Humid subtropical climate">humid subtropical climate</a> (<i>Cfa</i>), and is thus the northernmost major city on the North American continent with this categorization.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Peel.2C_M._C..3B_Finlayson.2C_B._L..3B_McMahon.2C_T._A_199-0"><a href="#cite_note-Peel.2C_M._C..3B_Finlayson.2C_B._L..3B_McMahon.2C_T._A-199">[199]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-newyorkpolonia.com_200-0"><a href="#cite_note-newyorkpolonia.com-200">[200]</a></sup> The suburbs to the immediate north and west lie in the transitional zone between humid subtropical and <a href="/wiki/Humid_continental_climate" title="Humid continental climate">humid continental climates</a> (<i>Dfa</i>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Peel.2C_M._C..3B_Finlayson.2C_B._L..3B_McMahon.2C_T._A_199-1"><a href="#cite_note-Peel.2C_M._C..3B_Finlayson.2C_B._L..3B_McMahon.2C_T._A-199">[199]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-newyorkpolonia.com_200-1"><a href="#cite_note-newyorkpolonia.com-200">[200]</a></sup> The city averages 234 days with at least some sunshine annually, and averages 57% of possible sunshine annually,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-noaasun_201-0"><a href="#cite_note-noaasun-201">[201]</a></sup> accumulating 2,535 hours of sunshine per annum.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-noaasun_201-1"><a href="#cite_note-noaasun-201">[201]</a></sup> The city lies in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/USDA" title="USDA">USDA</a> <a href="/wiki/Hardiness_zone" title="Hardiness zone">7b plant hardiness zone</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-202"><a href="#cite_note-202">[202]</a></sup></p>
<p>Winters are cold and damp, and prevailing wind patterns that blow offshore temper the moderating effects of the Atlantic Ocean; yet the Atlantic and the partial shielding from colder air by the <a href="/wiki/Appalachian_Mountains" title="Appalachian Mountains">Appalachians</a> keep the city warmer in the winter than inland North American cities at similar or lesser latitudes such as <a href="/wiki/Pittsburgh" title="Pittsburgh">Pittsburgh</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cincinnati" title="Cincinnati">Cincinnati</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Indianapolis" title="Indianapolis">Indianapolis</a>. The daily mean temperature in January, the area's coldest month, is 32.6 °F (0.3 °C);<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NOAA_txt_203-0"><a href="#cite_note-NOAA_txt-203">[203]</a></sup> temperatures usually drop to 10 °F (−12 °C) several times per winter,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NOAA_txt_203-1"><a href="#cite_note-NOAA_txt-203">[203]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYC_climate_204-0"><a href="#cite_note-NYC_climate-204">[204]</a></sup> and reach 60 °F (16 °C) several days in the coldest winter month.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NOAA_txt_203-2"><a href="#cite_note-NOAA_txt-203">[203]</a></sup> Spring and autumn are unpredictable and can range from chilly to warm, although they are usually mild with low humidity. Summers are typically warm to hot and humid, with a daily mean temperature of 76.5 °F (24.7 °C) in July.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NOAA_txt_203-3"><a href="#cite_note-NOAA_txt-203">[203]</a></sup> Nighttime conditions are often exacerbated by the <a href="/wiki/Urban_heat_island" title="Urban heat island">urban heat island</a> phenomenon, while daytime temperatures exceed 90 °F (32 °C) on average of 17 days each summer<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NOAA_205-0"><a href="#cite_note-NOAA-205">[205]</a></sup> and in some years exceed 100 °F (38 °C). Extreme temperatures have ranged from −15 °F (−26 °C), recorded on February 9, 1934, up to 106 °F (41 °C) on July 9, 1936.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NOAA_205-1"><a href="#cite_note-NOAA-205">[205]</a></sup> The average water temperature of the nearby Atlantic Ocean ranges from 39.7 °F (4.3 °C) in February to 74.1 °F (23.4 °C) in August.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-206"><a href="#cite_note-206">[206]</a></sup></p>
<p>The city receives 49.9 inches (1,270 mm) of <a href="/wiki/Precipitation" title="Precipitation">precipitation</a> annually, which is relatively evenly spread throughout the year. Average winter snowfall between 1981 and 2010 has been 25.8 inches (66 cm); this varies considerably from year to year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NOAA_205-2"><a href="#cite_note-NOAA-205">[205]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hurricane" title="Hurricane">Hurricanes</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tropical_storm" title="Tropical storm">tropical storms</a> are rare in the New York area, but they are not unheard of and always have the potential to strike the area.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-207"><a href="#cite_note-207">[207]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Hurricane_Sandy" title="Hurricane Sandy">Hurricane Sandy</a> brought a destructive <a href="/wiki/Storm_surge" title="Storm surge">storm surge</a> to New York City on the evening of October 29, 2012, flooding numerous streets, tunnels, and subway lines in Lower Manhattan and other areas of the city and cutting off electricity in many parts of the city and its suburbs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-208"><a href="#cite_note-208">[208]</a></sup> The storm and its profound impacts have prompted the discussion of constructing <a href="/wiki/Seawall" title="Seawall">seawalls</a> and other coastal barriers around the shorelines of the city and the metropolitan area to minimize the risk of destructive consequences from another such event in the future.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-209"><a href="#cite_note-209">[209]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-210"><a href="#cite_note-210">[210]</a></sup></p>
<p><br/></p>
<table class="wikitable collapsible" style="width:90%; text-align:center; font-size:90%; line-height: 1.2em; margin:auto;">

(−26)</td>
</tr>

</tr>
<tr style="text-align: center;">

<div class="mw-graph mw-graph-interactable" data-graph-id="c789087360de39e5714c884812ce27bd75006b10" style="min-width:500px;min-height:400px"><img class="mw-graph-img" src="/api/rest_v1/page/graph/png/New_York_City/0/c789087360de39e5714c884812ce27bd75006b10.png"/>

<p><br/></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Parks">Parks</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:New_York_World%27s_Fair_August_1964.jpeg"><img alt="A spherical sculpture and several attractions line a park during a World's Fair." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2048" data-file-width="3139" height="144" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/New_York_World%27s_Fair_August_1964.jpeg/220px-New_York_World%27s_Fair_August_1964.jpeg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/New_York_World%27s_Fair_August_1964.jpeg/330px-New_York_World%27s_Fair_August_1964.jpeg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/New_York_World%27s_Fair_August_1964.jpeg/440px-New_York_World%27s_Fair_August_1964.jpeg 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:New_York_World%27s_Fair_August_1964.jpeg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
<a href="/wiki/Flushing_Meadows%E2%80%93Corona_Park" title="Flushing Meadows–Corona Park">Flushing Meadows–Corona Park</a> was used in the <a href="/wiki/1964_New_York_World%27s_Fair" title="1964 New York World's Fair">1964 New York World's Fair</a>, with the <a href="/wiki/Unisphere" title="Unisphere">Unisphere</a> as its centerpiece.</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>The City of New York has a complex park system, with various lands operated by the <a href="/wiki/National_Park_Service" title="National Park Service">National Park Service</a>, the <a href="/wiki/New_York_State_Office_of_Parks,_Recreation_and_Historic_Preservation" title="New York State Office of Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation">New York State Office of Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Department_of_Parks_and_Recreation" title="New York City Department of Parks and Recreation">New York City Department of Parks and Recreation</a>.</p>
<p>In its 2013 ParkScore ranking, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Trust_for_Public_Land" title="Trust for Public Land">Trust for Public Land</a> reported that the park system in New York City was the second best park system among the 50 most populous US cities, behind the park system of <a href="/wiki/Minneapolis" title="Minneapolis">Minneapolis</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-214"><a href="#cite_note-214">[212]</a></sup> ParkScore ranks urban park systems by a formula that analyzes median park size, park acres as percent of city area, the percent of city residents within a half-mile of a park, spending of park services per resident, and the number of playgrounds per 10,000 residents.</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="National_parks">National parks</span></h4>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/National_Park_Service" title="National Park Service">National Park Service</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Statue_of_Liberty,_NY.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2668" data-file-width="3558" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Statue_of_Liberty%2C_NY.jpg/220px-Statue_of_Liberty%2C_NY.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Statue_of_Liberty%2C_NY.jpg/330px-Statue_of_Liberty%2C_NY.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Statue_of_Liberty%2C_NY.jpg/440px-Statue_of_Liberty%2C_NY.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Statue_of_Liberty,_NY.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
The <a href="/wiki/Statue_of_Liberty" title="Statue of Liberty">Statue of Liberty</a> on <a href="/wiki/Liberty_Island" title="Liberty Island">Liberty Island</a> in <a href="/wiki/New_York_Harbor" title="New York Harbor">New York Harbor</a> is a symbol of the United States and its ideals of freedom, <a href="/wiki/Democracy" title="Democracy">democracy</a>, and opportunity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-215"><a href="#cite_note-215">[213]</a></sup></div>
</div>
</div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Gateway_National_Recreation_Area" title="Gateway National Recreation Area">Gateway National Recreation Area</a> contains over 26,000 acres (10,521.83 <a href="/wiki/Hectare" title="Hectare">ha</a>) in total, most of it surrounded by New York City,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-216"><a href="#cite_note-216">[214]</a></sup> including the <a href="/wiki/Jamaica_Bay_Wildlife_Refuge" title="Jamaica Bay Wildlife Refuge">Jamaica Bay Wildlife Refuge</a>. In Brooklyn and Queens, the park contains over 9,000 acres (36 km<sup>2</sup>) of <a href="/wiki/Salt_marsh" title="Salt marsh">salt marsh</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wetlands" title="Wetlands">wetlands</a>, islands, and water, including most of <a href="/wiki/Jamaica_Bay" title="Jamaica Bay">Jamaica Bay</a>. Also in Queens, the park includes a significant portion of the western <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rockaway_Peninsula" title="Rockaway Peninsula">Rockaway Peninsula</a>, most notably <a href="/wiki/Jacob_Riis_Park" title="Jacob Riis Park">Jacob Riis Park</a> and <a href="/wiki/Fort_Tilden" title="Fort Tilden">Fort Tilden</a>. In Staten Island, Gateway National Recreation Area includes <a href="/wiki/Fort_Wadsworth" title="Fort Wadsworth">Fort Wadsworth</a>, with historic pre-Civil War era <a href="/wiki/Battery_Weed" title="Battery Weed">Battery Weed</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fort_Tompkins_Quadrangle" title="Fort Tompkins Quadrangle">Fort Tompkins</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Great_Kills_Park" title="Great Kills Park">Great Kills Park</a>, with beaches, trails, and a <a href="/wiki/Marina" title="Marina">marina</a>.</p>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Statue_of_Liberty_National_Monument" title="Statue of Liberty National Monument">Statue of Liberty National Monument and Ellis Island Immigration Museum</a> are managed by the National Park Service and are in both the states of New York and <a href="/wiki/New_Jersey" title="New Jersey">New Jersey</a>. They are joined in the harbor by <a href="/wiki/Governors_Island_National_Monument" title="Governors Island National Monument">Governors Island National Monument</a>, in New York. Historic sites under federal management on Manhattan Island include <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Castle_Clinton_National_Monument" title="Castle Clinton National Monument">Castle Clinton National Monument</a>; <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Federal_Hall_National_Memorial" title="Federal Hall National Memorial">Federal Hall National Memorial</a>; <a href="/wiki/Theodore_Roosevelt_Birthplace_National_Historic_Site" title="Theodore Roosevelt Birthplace National Historic Site">Theodore Roosevelt Birthplace National Historic Site</a>; <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/General_Grant_National_Memorial" title="General Grant National Memorial">General Grant National Memorial</a> ("Grant's Tomb"); <a href="/wiki/African_Burial_Ground_National_Monument" title="African Burial Ground National Monument">African Burial Ground National Monument</a>; and <a href="/wiki/Hamilton_Grange_National_Memorial" title="Hamilton Grange National Memorial">Hamilton Grange National Memorial</a>. Hundreds of private properties are listed on the <a href="/wiki/National_Register_of_Historic_Places" title="National Register of Historic Places">National Register of Historic Places</a> or as a <a href="/wiki/National_Historic_Landmark" title="National Historic Landmark">National Historic Landmark</a> such as, for example, the <a href="/wiki/Stonewall_Inn" title="Stonewall Inn">Stonewall Inn</a>, part of the <a href="/wiki/Stonewall_National_Monument" title="Stonewall National Monument">Stonewall National Monument</a> in <a href="/wiki/Greenwich_Village" title="Greenwich Village">Greenwich Village</a>, as the catalyst of the modern <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gay_rights_movement" title="Gay rights movement">gay rights movement</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-KentuckyStonewall_141-1"><a href="#cite_note-KentuckyStonewall-141">[141]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PinkNewsStonewall_142-1"><a href="#cite_note-PinkNewsStonewall-142">[142]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EncycloStonewall_143-1"><a href="#cite_note-EncycloStonewall-143">[143]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NPSStonewall_144-1"><a href="#cite_note-NPSStonewall-144">[144]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ObamaStonewall_145-1"><a href="#cite_note-ObamaStonewall-145">[145]</a></sup></p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="State_parks">State parks</span></h4>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/New_York_State_Parks" title="New York State Parks">New York State Parks</a></div>
<p>There are seven state parks within the confines of New York City, including <a href="/wiki/Clay_Pit_Ponds_State_Park_Preserve" title="Clay Pit Ponds State Park Preserve">Clay Pit Ponds State Park Preserve</a>, a natural area that includes extensive riding trails, and <a href="/wiki/Riverbank_State_Park" title="Riverbank State Park">Riverbank State Park</a>, a 28-acre (110,000 m<sup>2</sup>) facility that rises 69 feet (21 m) over the Hudson River.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-217"><a href="#cite_note-217">[215]</a></sup></p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="City_parks">City parks</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bronx_Zoo_reindeer.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1240" data-file-width="960" height="220" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Bronx_Zoo_reindeer.jpg/170px-Bronx_Zoo_reindeer.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Bronx_Zoo_reindeer.jpg/255px-Bronx_Zoo_reindeer.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Bronx_Zoo_reindeer.jpg/340px-Bronx_Zoo_reindeer.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Bronx_Zoo_reindeer.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
<a href="/wiki/Reindeer" title="Reindeer">Reindeer</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Bronx_Zoo" title="Bronx Zoo">Bronx Zoo</a>, the world's largest metropolitan zoo.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BronxZoo_195-1"><a href="#cite_note-BronxZoo-195">[195]</a></sup></div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Parks_and_recreation_in_New_York_City" title="Parks and recreation in New York City">Parks and recreation in New York City</a></div>
<p>New York City has over 28,000 acres (110 km<sup>2</sup>) of <a href="/wiki/Urban_park" title="Urban park">municipal parkland</a> and 14 miles (23 km) of public beaches.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-218"><a href="#cite_note-218">[216]</a></sup> The largest municipal park in the city is <a href="/wiki/Pelham_Bay_Park" title="Pelham Bay Park">Pelham Bay Park</a> in the Bronx, with 2,765 acres (1,119 ha).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-LargestParksNYC_186-2"><a href="#cite_note-LargestParksNYC-186">[186]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-219"><a href="#cite_note-219">[217]</a></sup></p>
<ul>
<li><a href="/wiki/Central_Park" title="Central Park">Central Park</a>, an 883-acre (3.57 km<sup>2</sup>) park in middle-upper Manhattan, is the most visited urban park in the United States and one of the most filmed locations in the world, with 40 million visitors in 2013.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-220"><a href="#cite_note-220">[218]</a></sup> The park contains a myriad of attractions; there are several lakes and ponds, two <a href="/wiki/Ice_rink" title="Ice rink">ice-skating rinks</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Central_Park_Zoo" title="Central Park Zoo">Central Park Zoo</a>, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Central_Park_Conservatory_Garden" title="Central Park Conservatory Garden">Central Park Conservatory Garden</a>, and the 106-acre (0.43 km<sup>2</sup>) Jackie Onassis Reservoir. Indoor attractions include <a href="/wiki/Belvedere_Castle" title="Belvedere Castle">Belvedere Castle</a> with its nature center, the Swedish Cottage Marionette Theater, and the historic Carousel. On October 23, 2012, <a href="/wiki/Hedge_fund" title="Hedge fund">hedge fund</a> manager <a href="/wiki/John_Paulson" title="John Paulson">John A. Paulson</a> announced a $100 million gift to the <a href="/wiki/Central_Park_Conservancy" title="Central Park Conservancy">Central Park Conservancy</a>, the largest ever monetary donation to New York City's park system.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-221"><a href="#cite_note-221">[219]</a></sup></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Washington_Square_Park" title="Washington Square Park">Washington Square Park</a> is a prominent landmark in the <a href="/wiki/Greenwich_Village" title="Greenwich Village">Greenwich Village</a> neighborhood of Lower Manhattan. The <a href="/wiki/Washington_Square_Arch" title="Washington Square Arch">Washington Square Arch</a> at the northern gateway to the park is an iconic symbol of both <a href="/wiki/New_York_University" title="New York University">New York University</a> and Greenwich Village.</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Prospect_Park_(Brooklyn)" title="Prospect Park (Brooklyn)">Prospect Park</a> in Brooklyn has a 90-acre (360,000 m<sup>2</sup>) <a href="/wiki/Meadow" title="Meadow">meadow</a>, a lake, and extensive <a href="/wiki/Woodland" title="Woodland">woodlands</a>. Within the park is the historic Battle Pass, prominent in the Battle of Long Island.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-222"><a href="#cite_note-222">[220]</a></sup></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Flushing_Meadows%E2%80%93Corona_Park" title="Flushing Meadows–Corona Park">Flushing Meadows–Corona Park</a> in Queens, with its 897 acres (363 ha) making it the city's fourth largest park,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-223"><a href="#cite_note-223">[221]</a></sup> was the setting for the <a href="/wiki/1939_New_York_World%27s_Fair" title="1939 New York World's Fair">1939 World's Fair</a> and the <a href="/wiki/1964_New_York_World%27s_Fair" title="1964 New York World's Fair">1964 World's Fair</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-224"><a href="#cite_note-224">[222]</a></sup> and is host to the <a href="/wiki/USTA_Billie_Jean_King_National_Tennis_Center" title="USTA Billie Jean King National Tennis Center">USTA Billie Jean King National Tennis Center</a> and the annual <a href="/wiki/US_Open_(tennis)" title="US Open (tennis)">United States Open Tennis Championships</a> tournament.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-225"><a href="#cite_note-225">[223]</a></sup></li>
<li>Over a fifth of the Bronx's area, 7,000 acres (28 km<sup>2</sup>), is given over to open space and parks, including Pelham Bay Park, <a href="/wiki/Van_Cortlandt_Park" title="Van Cortlandt Park">Van Cortlandt Park</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Bronx_Zoo" title="Bronx Zoo">Bronx Zoo</a>, and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/New_York_Botanical_Gardens" title="New York Botanical Gardens">New York Botanical Gardens</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-226"><a href="#cite_note-226">[224]</a></sup></li>
<li>In Staten Island, the <a href="/wiki/Conference_House_Park" title="Conference House Park">Conference House Park</a> contains the historic <a href="/wiki/Conference_House" title="Conference House">Conference House</a>, site of the only attempt of a peaceful resolution to the American Revolution which was conducted in September 1775, attended by <a href="/wiki/Benjamin_Franklin" title="Benjamin Franklin">Benjamin Franklin</a> representing the Americans and <a href="/wiki/Richard_Howe,_1st_Earl_Howe" title="Richard Howe, 1st Earl Howe">Lord Howe</a> representing the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/British_Crown" title="British Crown">British Crown</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-227"><a href="#cite_note-227">[225]</a></sup> The historic <a href="/wiki/Burial_Ridge" title="Burial Ridge">Burial Ridge</a>, the largest Native American burial ground within New York City, is within the park.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-228"><a href="#cite_note-228">[226]</a></sup></li>
</ul>
<div style="clear:both;"></div>
<div class="thumb tnone" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right:auto; overflow:hidden; width:auto; max-width:1108px;">
<div class="thumbinner" style="">
<div class="overflowbugx" style="overflow:auto;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:26_-_New_York_-_Octobre_2008.jpg" title="Central Park, as seen from Rockefeller Center, is the most visited city park in the United States."><img alt="A large rectangular park stretches to the horizon behind a city skyline." data-file-height="3522" data-file-width="18092" height="214" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/26_-_New_York_-_Octobre_2008.jpg/1100px-26_-_New_York_-_Octobre_2008.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/26_-_New_York_-_Octobre_2008.jpg/1650px-26_-_New_York_-_Octobre_2008.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/26_-_New_York_-_Octobre_2008.jpg/2200px-26_-_New_York_-_Octobre_2008.jpg 2x" width="1100"/></a></div>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:26_-_New_York_-_Octobre_2008.jpg" title="File:26 - New York - Octobre 2008.jpg"></a></div>
<div align="center"><a href="/wiki/Central_Park" title="Central Park">Central Park</a>, as seen from <a href="/wiki/Rockefeller_Center" title="Rockefeller Center">Rockefeller Center</a>, is the most visited <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/City_park" title="City park">city park</a> in the United States.</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Military_installations">Military installations</span></h3>
<p>New York City is home to <a href="/wiki/Fort_Hamilton" title="Fort Hamilton">Fort Hamilton</a>, the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Armed_Forces" title="United States Armed Forces">U.S. military's</a> only active duty installation within the city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-229"><a href="#cite_note-229">[227]</a></sup> Established in 1825 in Brooklyn on the site of a small battery utilized during the <a href="/wiki/American_Revolution" title="American Revolution">American Revolution</a>, it is one of America's longest serving military forts.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-230"><a href="#cite_note-230">[228]</a></sup> Today Fort Hamilton serves as the headquarters of the <a href="/wiki/North_Atlantic_Division" title="North Atlantic Division">North Atlantic Division</a> of the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Army_Corps_of_Engineers" title="United States Army Corps of Engineers">United States Army Corps of Engineers</a> and for the New York City Recruiting Battalion. It also houses the 1179th Transportation Brigade, the 722nd Aeromedical Staging Squadron, and a military entrance processing station. Other formerly active military reservations still utilized for <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/United_States_National_Guard" title="United States National Guard">National Guard</a> and military training or reserve operations in the city include <a href="/wiki/Fort_Wadsworth" title="Fort Wadsworth">Fort Wadsworth</a> in Staten Island and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fort_Totten_(New_York)" title="Fort Totten (New York)">Fort Totten</a> in Queens.</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">Demographics</span></h2>

<td colspan="3" style="border-top:1px solid black;font-size:85%;text-align:left"><span class="nowrap">Note: Census figures (1790–2010) cover</span> the present area of all five boroughs, before and after the 1898 consolidation.
