Source:
<center>U.S. Decennial Census<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DecennialCensus_243-0"><a href="#cite_note-DecennialCensus-243">[241]</a></sup></center>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<p>New York City is the most populous city in the United States,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2014NYCest2_9-1"><a href="#cite_note-2014NYCest2-9">[9]</a></sup> with an estimated record high of 8,537,673 residents as of 2016<sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=New_York_City&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2016Estimate_7-3"><a href="#cite_note-2016Estimate-7">[7]</a></sup> incorporating more immigration into the city than outmigration since the <a href="/wiki/2010_United_States_Census" title="2010 United States Census">2010 United States Census</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-244"><a href="#cite_note-244">[242]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-nytimes_a_245-0"><a href="#cite_note-nytimes_a-245">[243]</a></sup> More than twice as many people live in New York City as in the second-most populous U.S. city (<a href="/wiki/Los_Angeles" title="Los Angeles">Los Angeles</a>),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2014NYCest2_9-2"><a href="#cite_note-2014NYCest2-9">[9]</a></sup> and within a smaller area. New York City gained more residents between April 2010 and July 2014 (316,000) than any other U.S. city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2014NYCest2_9-3"><a href="#cite_note-2014NYCest2-9">[9]</a></sup> New York City's population is about 43% of New York State's population<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PopHousingEst_246-0"><a href="#cite_note-PopHousingEst-246">[244]</a></sup> and about 36% of the population of the <a href="/wiki/New_York_metropolitan_area" title="New York metropolitan area">New York metropolitan area</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-247"><a href="#cite_note-247">[245]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Population_density">Population density</span></h3>
<p>In 2015, the city had an estimated <a href="/wiki/Population_density" title="Population density">population density</a> of 28,053 people per square mile (10,756/km²), rendering it the most densely populated of all municipalities housing over 100,000 residents in the United States, with several small cities (of fewer than 100,000) in adjacent <a href="/wiki/Hudson_County,_New_Jersey" title="Hudson County, New Jersey">Hudson County, New Jersey</a> having <a href="/wiki/List_of_United_States_cities_by_population_density" title="List of United States cities by population density">greater density</a>, as per the 2010 Census.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-248"><a href="#cite_note-248">[246]</a></sup> Geographically co-extensive with New York County, the borough of Manhattan's 2015 population density of 69,468 inhabitants per square mile (26,822/km<sup>2</sup>)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-249"><a href="#cite_note-249">[247]</a></sup> makes it the <a href="/wiki/County_statistics_of_the_United_States#Population_density" title="County statistics of the United States">highest of any county in the United States</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-250"><a href="#cite_note-250">[248]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-251"><a href="#cite_note-251">[249]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_United_States_cities_by_population_density#New_York_City_boroughs" title="List of United States cities by population density">higher than the density of any individual American city</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-252"><a href="#cite_note-252">[250]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Race_and_ethnicity">Race and ethnicity</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chinese_in_New_York_City" title="Chinese in New York City">Chinese in New York City</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fuzhounese_in_New_York_City" title="Fuzhounese in New York City">Fuzhounese in New York City</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Indians_in_New_York_City" title="Indians in New York City">Indians in New York City</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Koreans_in_New_York_City" title="Koreans in New York City">Koreans in New York City</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Filipinos_in_New_York_City" title="Filipinos in New York City">Filipinos in New York City</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bangladeshis_in_New_York_City" title="Bangladeshis in New York City">Bangladeshis in New York City</a>, <a href="/wiki/Japanese_in_New_York_City" title="Japanese in New York City">Japanese in New York City</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Russians_in_New_York_City" title="Russians in New York City">Russians in New York City</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ukrainians_in_New_York_City" title="Ukrainians in New York City">Ukrainians in New York City</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Irish_in_New_York_City" title="Irish in New York City">Irish in New York City</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Italians_in_New_York_City" title="Italians in New York City">Italians in New York City</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Caribbeans_in_New_York_City" title="Caribbeans in New York City">Caribbeans in New York City</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Puerto_Ricans_in_New_York_City" title="Puerto Ricans in New York City">Puerto Ricans in New York City</a></div>
<p>The city's population in 2010 was 44% <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/White_American" title="White American">white</a> (33.3% non-Hispanic white), 25.5% <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Black_American" title="Black American">black</a> (23% non-Hispanic black), 0.7% <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Native_Americans_in_the_United_State" title="Native Americans in the United State">Native American</a>, and 12.7% <a href="/wiki/Asian_Americans_in_New_York_City" title="Asian Americans in New York City">Asian</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-census-est-nyc-ny_253-0"><a href="#cite_note-census-est-nyc-ny-253">[251]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Hispanic_and_Latino_Americans" title="Hispanic and Latino Americans">Hispanics</a> of any race represented 28.6% of the population,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-census-est-nyc-ny_253-1"><a href="#cite_note-census-est-nyc-ny-253">[251]</a></sup> while Asians constituted the fastest-growing segment of the city's population between 2000 and 2010; the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Non-Hispanic_Whites" title="Non-Hispanic Whites">non-Hispanic white</a> population declined 3 percent, the smallest recorded decline in decades; and for the first time since the Civil War, the number of blacks declined over a decade.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sam_Roberts_254-0"><a href="#cite_note-Sam_Roberts-254">[252]</a></sup></p>
<div class="thumb tmulti tleft">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:362px;max-width:362px">
<div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:175px;max-width:175px">
<div class="thumbimage" style="height:115px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Chinatown_manhattan_2009.JPG"><img alt="" data-file-height="2592" data-file-width="3872" height="116" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Chinatown_manhattan_2009.JPG/173px-Chinatown_manhattan_2009.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Chinatown_manhattan_2009.JPG/260px-Chinatown_manhattan_2009.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Chinatown_manhattan_2009.JPG/346px-Chinatown_manhattan_2009.JPG 2x" width="173"/></a></div>
</div>
<div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:183px;max-width:183px">
<div class="thumbimage" style="height:115px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Little_Italy_NY_Street.JPG"><img alt="" data-file-height="3456" data-file-width="4608" height="136" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Little_Italy_NY_Street.JPG/181px-Little_Italy_NY_Street.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Little_Italy_NY_Street.JPG/272px-Little_Italy_NY_Street.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Little_Italy_NY_Street.JPG/362px-Little_Italy_NY_Street.JPG 2x" width="181"/></a></div>
</div>
<div style="clear:left"></div>
<div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:175px;max-width:175px">
<div class="thumbimage" style="height:115px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:USA-NYC-Koreatown99.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="3456" data-file-width="5184" height="115" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/USA-NYC-Koreatown99.jpg/173px-USA-NYC-Koreatown99.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/USA-NYC-Koreatown99.jpg/260px-USA-NYC-Koreatown99.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/USA-NYC-Koreatown99.jpg/346px-USA-NYC-Koreatown99.jpg 2x" width="173"/></a></div>
</div>
<div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:183px;max-width:183px">
<div class="thumbimage" style="height:115px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Elbarrio116thLex.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="1089" data-file-width="1440" height="137" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Elbarrio116thLex.jpg/181px-Elbarrio116thLex.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Elbarrio116thLex.jpg/272px-Elbarrio116thLex.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Elbarrio116thLex.jpg/362px-Elbarrio116thLex.jpg 2x" width="181"/></a></div>
</div>
<div style="clear:left"></div>
<div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left;text-align:left;background-color:transparent">Clockwise, from upper left: the <a href="/wiki/Chinatown,_Manhattan" title="Chinatown, Manhattan">Manhattan Chinatown</a>; Manhattan's <a href="/wiki/Little_Italy,_Manhattan" title="Little Italy, Manhattan">Little Italy</a>; <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Spanish_Harlem" title="Spanish Harlem">Spanish Harlem</a>; and <a href="/wiki/Koreatown,_Manhattan" title="Koreatown, Manhattan">Manhattan's Koreatown</a></div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Throughout its history, the city has been a major <a href="/wiki/Port_of_entry" title="Port of entry">port of entry</a> for immigrants into the United States; more than 12 million <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/European_American" title="European American">European</a> immigrants were received at <a href="/wiki/Ellis_Island" title="Ellis Island">Ellis Island</a> between 1892 and 1924.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-255"><a href="#cite_note-255">[253]</a></sup> The term "<a href="/wiki/Melting_pot" title="Melting pot">melting pot</a>" was first coined to describe densely populated immigrant neighborhoods on the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lower_East_Side,_Manhattan" title="Lower East Side, Manhattan">Lower East Side</a>. By 1900, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/German_American" title="German American">Germans</a> constituted the largest immigrant group, followed by the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Irish_American" title="Irish American">Irish</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ashkenazi_Jews" title="Ashkenazi Jews">Jews</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Italian_American" title="Italian American">Italians</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-256"><a href="#cite_note-256">[254]</a></sup> In 1940, whites represented 92% of the city's population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pop_233-3"><a href="#cite_note-pop-233">[231]</a></sup></p>
<p>Approximately 37% of the city's population is <a href="/wiki/Foreign_born" title="Foreign born">foreign born</a> and more than half of all children are born to mothers who are immigrants.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CityDiversity_257-0"><a href="#cite_note-CityDiversity-257">[255]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYC_immigration_258-0"><a href="#cite_note-NYC_immigration-258">[256]</a></sup> In New York, no single country or region of origin dominates.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CityDiversity_257-1"><a href="#cite_note-CityDiversity-257">[255]</a></sup> The ten largest sources of foreign-born individuals in the city as of 2011<sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=New_York_City&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup> were the <a href="/wiki/Dominican_Republic" title="Dominican Republic">Dominican Republic</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Americans_in_New_York_City" title="Chinese Americans in New York City">China</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mexico" title="Mexico">Mexico</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Guyanese_American" title="Guyanese American">Guyana</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jamaica" title="Jamaica">Jamaica</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ecuador" title="Ecuador">Ecuador</a>, <a href="/wiki/Haiti" title="Haiti">Haiti</a>, <a href="/wiki/Indians_in_the_New_York_City_metropolitan_region" title="Indians in the New York City metropolitan region">India</a>, <a href="/wiki/Russian_Americans_in_New_York_City" title="Russian Americans in New York City">Russia</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Caribbeans_in_New_York_City" title="Caribbeans in New York City">Trinidad and Tobago</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-259"><a href="#cite_note-259">[257]</a></sup> while the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bangladeshi_American" title="Bangladeshi American">Bangladeshi-born</a> immigrant population has become one of the fastest growing in the city, counting over 74,000 by 2011.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYCHighestForeignBorn_41-1"><a href="#cite_note-NYCHighestForeignBorn-41">[41]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-260"><a href="#cite_note-260">[258]</a></sup></p>
<p><a href="/wiki/Asian_Americans_in_New_York_City" title="Asian Americans in New York City">Asian Americans in New York City</a>, according to the 2010 Census, number more than one million, greater than the combined totals of <a href="/wiki/San_Francisco" title="San Francisco">San Francisco</a> and Los Angeles.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-261"><a href="#cite_note-261">[259]</a></sup> New York contains the highest total Asian population of any U.S. city proper.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-262"><a href="#cite_note-262">[260]</a></sup> The New York City borough of Queens is home to the state's largest Asian American population and the largest <a href="/wiki/Andes" title="Andes">Andean</a> (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Colombian_American" title="Colombian American">Colombian</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ecuadorian_American" title="Ecuadorian American">Ecuadorian</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Peruvian_American" title="Peruvian American">Peruvian</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bolivian_American" title="Bolivian American">Bolivian</a>) populations in the United States, and is also the most ethnically diverse urban area in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-QueensMostDiverseWorld1_191-1"><a href="#cite_note-QueensMostDiverseWorld1-191">[191]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-QueensMostDiverseWorld2_192-1"><a href="#cite_note-QueensMostDiverseWorld2-192">[192]</a></sup> The Chinese population constitutes the fastest-growing nationality in New York State; multiple <a href="/wiki/Natural_satellite" title="Natural satellite">satellites</a> of the original <a href="/wiki/Chinatown,_Manhattan" title="Chinatown, Manhattan">Manhattan Chinatown</a>, in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chinatown,_Brooklyn" title="Chinatown, Brooklyn">Brooklyn</a>, and around <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chinatown,_Flushing" title="Chinatown, Flushing">Flushing, Queens</a>, are thriving as traditionally urban enclaves – while also expanding rapidly eastward into suburban <a href="/wiki/Nassau_County,_New_York" title="Nassau County, New York">Nassau County</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-263"><a href="#cite_note-263">[261]</a></sup> on <a href="/wiki/Long_Island" title="Long Island">Long Island</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-264"><a href="#cite_note-264">[262]</a></sup> as the New York metropolitan region and New York State have become the top destinations for new Chinese immigrants, respectively, and large-scale <a href="/wiki/Chinese_emigration" title="Chinese emigration">Chinese immigration</a> continues into New York City and surrounding areas,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Immigrants2012est_34-1"><a href="#cite_note-Immigrants2012est-34">[34]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated1_265-0"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated1-265">[263]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Chinese2013est_266-0"><a href="#cite_note-Chinese2013est-266">[264]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-267"><a href="#cite_note-267">[265]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-268"><a href="#cite_note-268">[266]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-269"><a href="#cite_note-269">[267]</a></sup> with the largest metropolitan Chinese diaspora outside Asia,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYCHighestForeignBorn_41-2"><a href="#cite_note-NYCHighestForeignBorn-41">[41]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-270"><a href="#cite_note-270">[268]</a></sup> including an estimated 812,410 individuals in 2015.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-271"><a href="#cite_note-271">[269]</a></sup> In 2012, 6.3% of New York City was of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chinese_American" title="Chinese American">Chinese ethnicity</a>, with nearly three-fourths living in either Queens or Brooklyn, geographically on Long Island.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-272"><a href="#cite_note-272">[270]</a></sup> A community numbering 20,000 <a href="/wiki/Koreans_in_China" title="Koreans in China">Korean-Chinese</a> (<i>Chaoxianzu</i> or <i>Joseonjok</i>) is centered in <a href="/wiki/Flushing,_Queens" title="Flushing, Queens">Flushing, Queens</a>, while New York City is also home to the largest <a href="/wiki/Tibetan_people" title="Tibetan people">Tibetan</a> population outside China, India, and <a href="/wiki/Nepal" title="Nepal">Nepal</a>, also centered in Queens.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UnreachedNY_273-0"><a href="#cite_note-UnreachedNY-273">[271]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Korean_Americans_in_New_York_City" title="Korean Americans in New York City">Koreans</a> made up 1.2% of the city's population, and <a href="/wiki/Japanese_in_New_York_City" title="Japanese in New York City">Japanese</a> 0.3%. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Filipinos_in_the_New_York_City_metropolitan_region" title="Filipinos in the New York City metropolitan region">Filipinos</a> were the largest <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Southeast_Asian" title="Southeast Asian">Southeast Asian</a> ethnic group at 0.8%, followed by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vietnamese_American" title="Vietnamese American">Vietnamese</a>, who made up 0.2% of New York City's population in 2010. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Indian_American" title="Indian American">Indians</a> are the largest <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/South_Asian" title="South Asian">South Asian</a> group, comprising 2.4% of the city's population, with Bangladeshis and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pakistani_American" title="Pakistani American">Pakistanis</a> at 0.7% and 0.5%, respectively.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-274"><a href="#cite_note-274">[272]</a></sup> Queens is the preferred borough of settlement for Asian Indians, Koreans, Filipinos,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-275"><a href="#cite_note-275">[273]</a></sup> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Malaysian_American" title="Malaysian American">Malaysians</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Immigrants2013est_33-1"><a href="#cite_note-Immigrants2013est-33">[33]</a></sup> and other Southeast Asians;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-276"><a href="#cite_note-276">[274]</a></sup> while Brooklyn is receiving large numbers of both <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/West_Indian_American" title="West Indian American">West Indian</a> and Asian Indian immigrants.</p>
<div class="thumb tleft">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Race_and_ethnicity_2010-_New_York_City_(5559914315).png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3009" data-file-width="3009" height="220" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/Race_and_ethnicity_2010-_New_York_City_%285559914315%29.png/220px-Race_and_ethnicity_2010-_New_York_City_%285559914315%29.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/Race_and_ethnicity_2010-_New_York_City_%285559914315%29.png/330px-Race_and_ethnicity_2010-_New_York_City_%285559914315%29.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/Race_and_ethnicity_2010-_New_York_City_%285559914315%29.png/440px-Race_and_ethnicity_2010-_New_York_City_%285559914315%29.png 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Race_and_ethnicity_2010-_New_York_City_(5559914315).png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
Map of racial distribution in New York, 2010 U.S. Census. Each dot is 25 people: <span style="color:#ff0000"><b>White</b></span>, <span style="color:#0000ff"><b>Black</b></span>, <span style="color:#00ff80"><b>Asian</b></span>, <span style="color:#ff8000"><b>Hispanic</b></span> or <b>Other</b> (yellow)</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>New York City has the largest <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/European_American" title="European American">European</a> and <a href="/wiki/Non-Hispanic_whites" title="Non-Hispanic whites">non-Hispanic white</a> population of any American city. At 2.7 million in 2012, New York's non-Hispanic white population is larger than the non-Hispanic white populations of Los Angeles (1.1 million), Chicago (865,000), and Houston (550,000) combined.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-277"><a href="#cite_note-277">[275]</a></sup> The non-Hispanic white population was 6.6 million in 1940.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-278"><a href="#cite_note-278">[276]</a></sup> The non-Hispanic white population has begun to increase since 2010.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-279"><a href="#cite_note-279">[277]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/European_diaspora" title="European diaspora">European diaspora</a> residing in the city is very diverse. According to 2012 Census estimates, there were roughly 560,000 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Italian_American" title="Italian American">Italian Americans</a>, 385,000 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Irish_American" title="Irish American">Irish Americans</a>, 253,000 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/German_American" title="German American">German Americans</a>, 223,000 <a href="/wiki/Russian_Americans_in_New_York_City" title="Russian Americans in New York City">Russian Americans</a>, 201,000 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Polish_American" title="Polish American">Polish Americans</a>, and 137,000 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/English_American" title="English American">English Americans</a>. Additionally, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Greek_American" title="Greek American">Greek</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/French_American" title="French American">French Americans</a> numbered 65,000 each, with those of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hungarian_American" title="Hungarian American">Hungarian</a> descent estimated at 60,000 people. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ukrainian_American" title="Ukrainian American">Ukrainian</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Scottish_American" title="Scottish American">Scottish Americans</a> numbered 55,000 and 35,000, respectively. People identifying ancestry from <a href="/wiki/Spain" title="Spain">Spain</a> numbered 30,838 total in 2010.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HispanicLatino_280-0"><a href="#cite_note-HispanicLatino-280">[278]</a></sup> People of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Norwegian_American" title="Norwegian American">Norwegian</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Swedish_American" title="Swedish American">Swedish</a> descent both stood at about 20,000 each, while people of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Czech_American" title="Czech American">Czech</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lithuanian_American" title="Lithuanian American">Lithuanian</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Portuguese_American" title="Portuguese American">Portuguese</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Scotch-Irish_American" title="Scotch-Irish American">Scotch-Irish</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Welsh_American" title="Welsh American">Welsh</a> descent all numbered between 12,000–14,000 people.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-281"><a href="#cite_note-281">[279]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arab_American" title="Arab American">Arab Americans</a> number over 160,000 in New York City,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-282"><a href="#cite_note-282">[280]</a></sup> with the highest concentration in Brooklyn. <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Central_Asia" title="Demographics of Central Asia">Central Asians</a>, primarily <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Uzbek_American" title="Uzbek American">Uzbek Americans</a>, are a rapidly growing segment of the city's non-Hispanic white population, enumerating over 30,000, and including over half of all Central Asian immigrants to the United States,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-283"><a href="#cite_note-283">[281]</a></sup> most settling in Queens or Brooklyn. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Albanian_American" title="Albanian American">Albanian Americans</a> are most highly concentrated in the Bronx.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-284"><a href="#cite_note-284">[282]</a></sup></p>
<p>The wider New York City metropolitan statistical area, with over 20 million people, about 50% greater than the second-place <a href="/wiki/Los_Angeles_metropolitan_area" title="Los Angeles metropolitan area">Los Angeles metropolitan area</a> in the United States,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MetroEst_4-2"><a href="#cite_note-MetroEst-4">[4]</a></sup> is also <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ethnic_diversity" title="Ethnic diversity">ethnically diverse</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-285"><a href="#cite_note-285">[283]</a></sup> with the largest <a href="/wiki/Foreign_born#Metropolitan_regions_with_largest_foreign_born_populations" title="Foreign born">foreign-born population of any metropolitan region</a> in the world. The New York region continues to be by far the leading metropolitan gateway for legal immigrants admitted into the United States, substantially exceeding the combined totals of Los Angeles and <a href="/wiki/Miami_metropolitan_area" title="Miami metropolitan area">Miami</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Immigrants2013est_33-2"><a href="#cite_note-Immigrants2013est-33">[33]</a></sup> It is home to the largest <a href="/wiki/Jews_in_New_York_City" title="Jews in New York City">Jewish</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Israeli_American" title="Israeli American">Israeli</a> communities outside <a href="/wiki/Israel" title="Israel">Israel</a>, with the Jewish population in the region numbering over 1.5 million in 2012 and including many diverse Jewish sects from around the <a href="/wiki/Middle_East" title="Middle East">Middle East</a> and <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Europe" title="Eastern Europe">Eastern Europe</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UnreachedNY_273-1"><a href="#cite_note-UnreachedNY-273">[271]</a></sup> The metropolitan area is also home to 20% of the nation's <a href="/wiki/Indians_in_the_New_York_City_metropolitan_region" title="Indians in the New York City metropolitan region">Indian Americans</a> and at least 20 <a href="/wiki/Little_India_(location)" title="Little India (location)">Little India</a> enclaves, and 15% of all <a href="/wiki/Korean_Americans_in_New_York_City" title="Korean Americans in New York City">Korean Americans</a> and four <a href="/wiki/Koreatown,_Manhattan" title="Koreatown, Manhattan">Koreatowns</a>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-factfinder2.census_286-0"><a href="#cite_note-factfinder2.census-286">[284]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-287"><a href="#cite_note-287">[285]</a></sup> the largest <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Asian_Indian" title="Asian Indian">Asian Indian</a> population in the Western Hemisphere; the largest Russian American,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated1_265-1"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated1-265">[263]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Italian_American" title="Italian American">Italian American</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/African_American" title="African American">African American</a> populations; the largest <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dominican_American" title="Dominican American">Dominican American</a>, <a href="/wiki/Puerto_Rican_migration_to_New_York_City" title="Puerto Rican migration to New York City">Puerto Rican American</a>, and <a href="/wiki/South_America" title="South America">South American</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated1_265-2"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated1-265">[263]</a></sup> and second-largest overall <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hispanic_and_Latino_American" title="Hispanic and Latino American">Hispanic</a> population in the United States, numbering 4.8 million;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HispanicLatino_280-1"><a href="#cite_note-HispanicLatino-280">[278]</a></sup> and includes multiple established <a href="/wiki/Chinatown" title="Chinatown">Chinatowns</a> within New York City alone.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-288"><a href="#cite_note-288">[286]</a></sup></p>
<p>Ecuador, <a href="/wiki/Colombia" title="Colombia">Colombia</a>, Guyana, <a href="/wiki/Peru" title="Peru">Peru</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Brazil" title="Brazil">Brazil</a> were the top source countries from South America for legal immigrants to the New York City region in 2013; the Dominican Republic, <a href="/wiki/Jamaica" title="Jamaica">Jamaica</a>, Haiti, and Trinidad and Tobago in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Caribbeans_in_New_York_City" title="Caribbeans in New York City">Caribbean</a>; <a href="/wiki/Egypt" title="Egypt">Egypt</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ghana" title="Ghana">Ghana</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Nigeria" title="Nigeria">Nigeria</a> from <a href="/wiki/Africa" title="Africa">Africa</a>; and <a href="/wiki/El_Salvador" title="El Salvador">El Salvador</a>, <a href="/wiki/Honduras" title="Honduras">Honduras</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Guatemala" title="Guatemala">Guatemala</a> in <a href="/wiki/Central_America" title="Central America">Central America</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-289"><a href="#cite_note-289">[287]</a></sup> Amidst a resurgence of <a href="/wiki/Puerto_Rican_migration_to_New_York_City" title="Puerto Rican migration to New York City">Puerto Rican migration to New York City</a>, this population had increased to approximately 1.3 million in the metropolitan area as of 2013<sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=New_York_City&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>.</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sexual_orientation_and_gender_identity">Sexual orientation and gender identity</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/LGBT_culture_in_New_York_City" title="LGBT culture in New York City">LGBT culture in New York City</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:New_York_Gay_Pride_2011.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="683" data-file-width="1024" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/New_York_Gay_Pride_2011.jpg/220px-New_York_Gay_Pride_2011.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/New_York_Gay_Pride_2011.jpg/330px-New_York_Gay_Pride_2011.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/New_York_Gay_Pride_2011.jpg/440px-New_York_Gay_Pride_2011.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:New_York_Gay_Pride_2011.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
The scene at the 2011 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/LGBT_Pride_March_(New_York_City)" title="LGBT Pride March (New York City)">LGBT Pride March</a>. New York City is home to the <a href="/wiki/LGBT_demographics_of_the_United_States#By_consolidated_metropolitan_statistical_area" title="LGBT demographics of the United States">largest LGBTQ community in the United States</a> and one of the world's largest.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-290"><a href="#cite_note-290">[288]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GLB_291-0"><a href="#cite_note-GLB-291">[289]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-WorldLargestGLBT_292-0"><a href="#cite_note-WorldLargestGLBT-292">[290]</a></sup></div>
</div>
</div>
<p>The New York metropolitan area is home to a self-identifying <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gays_in_New_York_City" title="Gays in New York City">gay</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bisexuality" title="Bisexuality">bisexual</a> community estimated at nearly 570,000 individuals, <a href="/wiki/LGBT_demographics_of_the_United_States#By_metropolitan_area" title="LGBT demographics of the United States">the largest in the United States</a> and one of the world's largest.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-293"><a href="#cite_note-293">[291]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-294"><a href="#cite_note-294">[292]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Same-sex_marriage_in_New_York" title="Same-sex marriage in New York">Same-sex marriages in New York</a> were legalized on June 24, 2011 and were authorized to take place beginning 30 days thereafter.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-295"><a href="#cite_note-295">[293]</a></sup> Charles Kaiser, author of <i>The Gay Metropolis: The Landmark History of Gay Life in America</i>, wrote that in the era after <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>, "New York City became the literal gay metropolis for hundreds of thousands of immigrants from within and without the United States: the place they chose to learn how to live openly, honestly and without shame."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-296"><a href="#cite_note-296">[294]</a></sup> The annual <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/New_York_City_Pride_March" title="New York City Pride March">New York City Pride March</a> (or <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_LGBT_Pride_March" title="New York City LGBT Pride March">gay</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pride_march" title="Pride march">pride parade</a>) traverses southward down <a href="/wiki/Fifth_Avenue" title="Fifth Avenue">Fifth Avenue</a> and ends at <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Greenwich_Village,_Manhattan" title="Greenwich Village, Manhattan">Greenwich Village</a> in Lower Manhattan; the parade rivals the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sao_Paulo_Gay_Pride_Parade" title="Sao Paulo Gay Pride Parade">Sao Paulo Gay Pride Parade</a> as the largest pride parade in the world, attracting tens of thousands of participants and millions of sidewalk spectators each June.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYCWorld.27sLargestPrideParade_297-0"><a href="#cite_note-NYCWorld.27sLargestPrideParade-297">[295]</a></sup></p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Transgender_contribution">Transgender contribution</span></h4>
<p><a href="/wiki/Wayne_R._Dynes" title="Wayne R. Dynes">Wayne R. Dynes</a>, author of the <a href="/wiki/Encyclopedia_of_Homosexuality" title="Encyclopedia of Homosexuality">Encyclopedia of Homosexuality</a>, wrote that <a href="/wiki/Drag_queen" title="Drag queen">drag queens</a> were the only "transgender folks around" during the June 1969 <a href="/wiki/Stonewall_riots" title="Stonewall riots">Stonewall riots</a>. "None of them in fact made a major contribution to the movement."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TransEqualityNYC_298-0"><a href="#cite_note-TransEqualityNYC-298">[296]</a></sup> Others say the <a href="/wiki/Transgender" title="Transgender">transgender</a> community in New York City played a significant role in fighting for <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/LGBT_equality" title="LGBT equality">LGBT equality</a> during the period of the Stonewall riots and thereafter.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TransEqualityNYC_298-1"><a href="#cite_note-TransEqualityNYC-298">[296]</a></sup> New York City is home to the largest transgender population in the United States, estimated at 25,000 in 2016.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-299"><a href="#cite_note-299">[297]</a></sup> However, until the Stonewall riots, this community had felt marginalized and neglected by the gay community.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TransEqualityNYC_298-2"><a href="#cite_note-TransEqualityNYC-298">[296]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">Religion</span></h3>
<p><a href="/wiki/Christianity_in_the_United_States" title="Christianity in the United States">Christianity</a> (59%), made up of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Roman_Catholicism_in_the_United_States" title="Roman Catholicism in the United States">Roman Catholicism</a> (33%), <a href="/wiki/Protestantism_in_the_United_States" title="Protestantism in the United States">Protestantism</a> (23%), and other Christians (3%), was the most prevalently practiced religion in New York as of 2014<sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=New_York_City&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYCReligion1_300-0"><a href="#cite_note-NYCReligion1-300">[298]</a></sup> followed by <a href="/wiki/American_Jews" title="American Jews">Judaism</a>, with approximately 1.1 million <a href="/wiki/Jews_in_New_York_City" title="Jews in New York City">Jews in New York City</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-301"><a href="#cite_note-301">[299]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-302"><a href="#cite_note-302">[300]</a></sup> over half living in Brooklyn;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BrooklynJewish_303-0"><a href="#cite_note-BrooklynJewish-303">[301]</a></sup> The Jewish population makes up 18.4% of the city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-304"><a href="#cite_note-304">[302]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">Islam</a> ranks third in New York City, with official estimates ranging between 600,000 and 1,000,000 observers and including 10% of the city's public schoolchildren,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-305"><a href="#cite_note-305">[303]</a></sup> followed by <a href="/wiki/Hinduism" title="Hinduism">Hinduism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Buddhism" title="Buddhism">Buddhism</a>, and a variety of other religions, as well as <a href="/wiki/Atheism" title="Atheism">atheism</a>. In 2014, 24% self-identified with no organized religious affiliation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYCReligion1_300-1"><a href="#cite_note-NYCReligion1-300">[298]</a></sup></p>
<div class="thumb tmulti tnone center">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:887px;max-width:887px">
<div style="clear:both;font-weight:bold;text-align:center;background-color:transparent">Religious affiliations in New York City</div>
<div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:122px;max-width:122px">
<div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:2016_St._Patrick%27s_Cathedral_-_Manhattan_02.JPG"><img alt="" data-file-height="3935" data-file-width="1752" height="270" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/2016_St._Patrick%27s_Cathedral_-_Manhattan_02.JPG/120px-2016_St._Patrick%27s_Cathedral_-_Manhattan_02.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/2016_St._Patrick%27s_Cathedral_-_Manhattan_02.JPG/180px-2016_St._Patrick%27s_Cathedral_-_Manhattan_02.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/2016_St._Patrick%27s_Cathedral_-_Manhattan_02.JPG/240px-2016_St._Patrick%27s_Cathedral_-_Manhattan_02.JPG 2x" width="120"/></a></div>
<div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/New_York_City_Landmarks" title="New York City Landmarks">landmark</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gothic_revival_architecture" title="Gothic revival architecture">Neo-Gothic</a> Roman Catholic <a href="/wiki/St._Patrick%27s_Cathedral_(Manhattan)" title="St. Patrick's Cathedral (Manhattan)">St. Patrick's Cathedral</a>, Midtown Manhattan</div>
</div>
<div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:202px;max-width:202px">
<div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Jueus_ultraortodoxes_satmar_a_brooklyn.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="768" data-file-width="1024" height="150" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/Jueus_ultraortodoxes_satmar_a_brooklyn.jpg/200px-Jueus_ultraortodoxes_satmar_a_brooklyn.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/Jueus_ultraortodoxes_satmar_a_brooklyn.jpg/300px-Jueus_ultraortodoxes_satmar_a_brooklyn.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/Jueus_ultraortodoxes_satmar_a_brooklyn.jpg/400px-Jueus_ultraortodoxes_satmar_a_brooklyn.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a></div>
<div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Haredi_Jews" title="Haredi Jews">Ultra-Orthodox</a> <a href="/wiki/Jews_in_New_York_City" title="Jews in New York City">Jewish</a> residents in Brooklyn. Brooklyn has the largest Jewish community in the United States, with approximately 600,000 individuals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-306"><a href="#cite_note-306">[304]</a></sup></div>
</div>
<div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:133px;max-width:133px">
<div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Islamic_Cultural_Center_E96_jeh.JPG"><img alt="" data-file-height="2388" data-file-width="2073" height="151" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Islamic_Cultural_Center_E96_jeh.JPG/131px-Islamic_Cultural_Center_E96_jeh.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Islamic_Cultural_Center_E96_jeh.JPG/197px-Islamic_Cultural_Center_E96_jeh.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Islamic_Cultural_Center_E96_jeh.JPG/262px-Islamic_Cultural_Center_E96_jeh.JPG 2x" width="131"/></a></div>
<div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">The <a href="/wiki/Islamic_Cultural_Center_of_New_York" title="Islamic Cultural Center of New York">Islamic Cultural Center of New York</a> in <a href="/wiki/Upper_Manhattan" title="Upper Manhattan">Upper Manhattan</a>, the first mosque built in New York City.</div>
</div>
<div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:102px;max-width:102px">
<div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Exterior_Hindu_Temple.JPG"><img alt="" data-file-height="4752" data-file-width="3168" height="150" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dc/Exterior_Hindu_Temple.JPG/100px-Exterior_Hindu_Temple.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dc/Exterior_Hindu_Temple.JPG/150px-Exterior_Hindu_Temple.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dc/Exterior_Hindu_Temple.JPG/200px-Exterior_Hindu_Temple.JPG 2x" width="100"/></a></div>

</div>
<div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:114px;max-width:114px">
<div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Buddhist_Temple,_Chinatown.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="1024" data-file-width="768" height="149" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/Buddhist_Temple%2C_Chinatown.jpg/112px-Buddhist_Temple%2C_Chinatown.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/Buddhist_Temple%2C_Chinatown.jpg/168px-Buddhist_Temple%2C_Chinatown.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/Buddhist_Temple%2C_Chinatown.jpg/224px-Buddhist_Temple%2C_Chinatown.jpg 2x" width="112"/></a></div>

</div>
<div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:202px;max-width:202px">
<div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Times_Square_after_dark_atheist.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="3456" data-file-width="4608" height="150" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Times_Square_after_dark_atheist.jpg/200px-Times_Square_after_dark_atheist.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Times_Square_after_dark_atheist.jpg/300px-Times_Square_after_dark_atheist.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Times_Square_after_dark_atheist.jpg/400px-Times_Square_after_dark_atheist.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a></div>
<div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left"><a href="/wiki/American_Atheists" title="American Atheists">Atheism</a>, promoted on an <a href="/wiki/Digital_billboard" title="Digital billboard">electronic billboard</a> in <a href="/wiki/Times_Square" title="Times Square">Times Square</a>, is observed by a significant proportion of New Yorkers.</div>
</div>
<div style="clear:left"></div>
</div>
</div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Income">Income</span></h3>
<p>New York City has a high degree of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Income_disparity" title="Income disparity">income disparity</a> as indicated by its <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gini_Coefficient" title="Gini Coefficient">Gini Coefficient</a> of 0.5 for the city overall and 0.6 for Manhattan.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-307"><a href="#cite_note-307">[305]</a></sup> In the first quarter of 2014, the average weekly wage in New York County (Manhattan) was $2,749, representing the highest total among large counties in the United States.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-308"><a href="#cite_note-308">[306]</a></sup> As of 2017, New York City had the highest number of <a href="/wiki/Billionaire" title="Billionaire">billionaires</a> of any city in the world at 82, with a combined <a href="/wiki/Net_worth" title="Net worth">net worth</a> of US$398 billion,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-309"><a href="#cite_note-309">[307]</a></sup> including former <a href="/wiki/Mayor_of_New_York_City" title="Mayor of New York City">Mayor</a> <a href="/wiki/Michael_Bloomberg" title="Michael Bloomberg">Michael Bloomberg</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-310"><a href="#cite_note-310">[308]</a></sup> New York also had the highest density of <a href="/wiki/Millionaire" title="Millionaire">millionaires</a> per capita among major U.S. cities in 2014, at 4.6% of residents.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-311"><a href="#cite_note-311">[309]</a></sup> Lower Manhattan has been experiencing a <a href="/wiki/Baby_boom" title="Baby boom">baby boom</a>, with the area south of <a href="/wiki/Canal_Street_(Manhattan)" title="Canal Street (Manhattan)">Canal Street</a> witnessing 1,086 births in 2010, 12% greater than 2009 and over twice the number born in 2001.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-312"><a href="#cite_note-312">[310]</a></sup></p>
<p><br/></p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">Economy</span></h2>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_New_York_City" title="Economy of New York City">Economy of New York City</a></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="City_economic_overview">City economic overview</span></h3>
<table class="toc" style="float:right; font-size:90%; text-align:center; margin:1em;">
<tr>
<td colspan="6" style="background:tan;"><b>Top publicly traded companies<br/>
in New York City</b><br/>
(ranked by 2015 revenues)<br/>
<i>with City and U.S. ranks</i></td>
</tr>
<tr style="background:#ccc;">
<td><b>NYC</b></td>
<td></td>
<td style="background:#ccc;"><b>corporation</b></td>
<td></td>
<td style="background:#ccc;"><b>US</b></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td>1</td>
<td></td>
<td><a href="/wiki/Verizon_Communications" title="Verizon Communications">Verizon Communications</a></td>
<td></td>
<td>13</td>
</tr>
<tr>

<td></td>
<td style="background:#afa;"><a href="/wiki/JPMorgan_Chase" title="JPMorgan Chase">JPMorgan Chase</a></td>

</tr>

</tr>

</tr>

<td>12</td>
<td></td>

<td></td>
<td>85</td>
</tr>
<tr style="background:lemonchiffon">
<td colspan="5"><small><i>Every firm's revenue exceeded $30 billion</i></small></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td colspan="5" style="background:#afa;"><i>Financial services firms in green</i></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td colspan="5">Full table at <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_New_York_City" title="Economy of New York City">Economy of New York City</a></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td colspan="5"><b>Source:</b> <i>Fortune</i> 500<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-313"><a href="#cite_note-313">[311]</a></sup></td>
</tr>
</table>
<p>New York is a <a href="/wiki/Global_city" title="Global city">global hub</a> of international business and commerce. In 2012, New York City topped the first <i>Global Economic Power Index</i>, published by <i><a href="/wiki/The_Atlantic" title="The Atlantic">The Atlantic</a></i> (to be differentiated from a namesake list published by the <i>Martin Prosperity Institute</i>), with cities ranked according to criteria reflecting their presence on similar lists as published by other entities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-314"><a href="#cite_note-314">[312]</a></sup> The city is a major center for banking and finance, retailing, world trade, transportation, tourism, real estate, <a href="/wiki/New_media" title="New media">new media</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Traditional_media" title="Traditional media">traditional media</a>, <a href="/wiki/Advertising" title="Advertising">advertising</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Legal_services" title="Legal services">legal services</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Accountancy" title="Accountancy">accountancy</a>, insurance, theater, fashion, and the arts in the United States; while <a href="/wiki/Silicon_Alley" title="Silicon Alley">Silicon Alley</a>, metonymous for New York's broad-spectrum <a href="/wiki/High_tech" title="High tech">high technology</a> sphere, continues to expand. The <a href="/wiki/Port_of_New_York_and_New_Jersey" title="Port of New York and New Jersey">Port of New York and New Jersey</a> is also a major economic engine, handling record <a href="/wiki/Cargo" title="Cargo">cargo</a> volume in the first half of 2014.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-315"><a href="#cite_note-315">[313]</a></sup> In February 2017, New York City's <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Unemployment_rate" title="Unemployment rate">unemployment rate</a> fell to 4.3%, the lowest in the city's recorded history, with the city achieving the status of what many economists refer to as <i>full employment</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-316"><a href="#cite_note-316">[314]</a></sup></p>
<p>Many <a href="/wiki/Fortune_500" title="Fortune 500">Fortune 500</a> corporations are <a href="/wiki/Headquarters" title="Headquarters">headquartered</a> in New York City,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-317"><a href="#cite_note-317">[315]</a></sup> as are a large number of <a href="/wiki/Multinational_corporation" title="Multinational corporation">multinational corporations</a>. One out of ten <a href="/wiki/Private_sector" title="Private sector">private sector</a> jobs in the city is with a foreign company.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-318"><a href="#cite_note-318">[316]</a></sup> New York City has been ranked first among cities across the globe in attracting <a href="/wiki/Capital_(economics)" title="Capital (economics)">capital</a>, business, and tourists.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-319"><a href="#cite_note-319">[317]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-320"><a href="#cite_note-320">[318]</a></sup> This ability to attract <a href="/wiki/Foreign_direct_investment" title="Foreign direct investment">foreign investment</a> helped New York City top the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/FDi_Magazine" title="FDi Magazine">FDi Magazine</a> American Cities of the Future ranking for 2013.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-321"><a href="#cite_note-321">[319]</a></sup></p>
<p><a href="/wiki/Real_estate" title="Real estate">Real estate</a> is a major force in the city's economy, as the total value of all New York City property was assessed at US$1.072 trillion for the 2017 <a href="/wiki/Fiscal_year" title="Fiscal year">fiscal year</a>, an increase of 10.6% from the previous year with 89% of the increase coming from market effects.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYC_real_estate_322-0"><a href="#cite_note-NYC_real_estate-322">[320]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Time_Warner_Center" title="Time Warner Center">Time Warner Center</a> is the property with the highest-listed market value in the city, at US$1.1 billion in 2006.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYC_real_estate_322-1"><a href="#cite_note-NYC_real_estate-322">[320]</a></sup> New York City is home to some of the nation's—and the world's—most valuable real estate. 450 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Park_Avenue_(Manhattan)" title="Park Avenue (Manhattan)">Park Avenue</a> was sold on July 2, 2007 for US$510 million, about $1,589 per square foot ($17,104/m²), breaking the barely month-old record for an American office building of $1,476 per square foot ($15,887/m²) set in the June 2007 sale of 660 Madison Avenue.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-323"><a href="#cite_note-323">[321]</a></sup> According to <i><a href="/wiki/Forbes" title="Forbes">Forbes</a></i>, in 2014, Manhattan was home to six of the top ten <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Zip_code" title="Zip code">zip codes</a> in the United States by median housing price.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-324"><a href="#cite_note-324">[322]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Fifth_Avenue" title="Fifth Avenue">Fifth Avenue</a> in Midtown Manhattan commands the highest <a href="/wiki/Retail" title="Retail">retail</a> rents in the world, at US$3,000 per square foot ($32,000/m<sup>2</sup>) in 2017.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-325"><a href="#cite_note-325">[323]</a></sup></p>
<p>As of 2013<sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=New_York_City&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, the global <a href="/wiki/List_of_advertising_agencies" title="List of advertising agencies">advertising agencies</a> of <a href="/wiki/Omnicom_Group" title="Omnicom Group">Omnicom Group</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Interpublic_Group" title="Interpublic Group">Interpublic Group</a>, both based in Manhattan, had combined annual revenues of approximately US$21 billion, reflecting New York City's role as the top global center for the <a href="/wiki/Advertising" title="Advertising">advertising industry</a>, which is metonymously referred to as <a href="/wiki/Madison_Avenue#Advertising_industry" title="Madison Avenue">"Madison Avenue"</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MadisonAveMetonym_326-0"><a href="#cite_note-MadisonAveMetonym-326">[324]</a></sup> The city's <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fashion_industry" title="Fashion industry">fashion industry</a> provides approximately 180,000 employees with $11 billion in annual wages.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-327"><a href="#cite_note-327">[325]</a></sup></p>
<p>Other important sectors include <a href="/wiki/Medical_research" title="Medical research">medical research</a> and technology, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Non-profit" title="Non-profit">non-profit</a> institutions, and universities. Manufacturing accounts for a significant but declining share of employment, although the city's <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Garment_industry" title="Garment industry">garment industry</a> is showing a resurgence in Brooklyn.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-328"><a href="#cite_note-328">[326]</a></sup> Food processing is a US$5 billion industry that employs more than 19,000 residents.</p>
<p><a href="/wiki/Chocolate" title="Chocolate">Chocolate</a> is New York City's leading <a href="/wiki/Specialty_Food_Association" title="Specialty Food Association">specialty-food</a> export, with up to US$234 million worth of exports each year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-food_manufacturing_329-0"><a href="#cite_note-food_manufacturing-329">[327]</a></sup> Entrepreneurs were forming a "Chocolate District" in Brooklyn as of 2014<sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=New_York_City&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-330"><a href="#cite_note-330">[328]</a></sup> while <a href="/wiki/Godiva_Chocolatier" title="Godiva Chocolatier">Godiva</a>, one of the world's largest <a href="/wiki/Chocolatier" title="Chocolatier">chocolatiers</a>, continues to be headquartered in Manhattan.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-331"><a href="#cite_note-331">[329]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Wall_Street">Wall Street</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Wall_Street" title="Wall Street">Wall Street</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Photos_NewYork1_032.jpg"><img alt="A large flag is stretched over Roman style columns on the front of a large building." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="768" data-file-width="1024" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Photos_NewYork1_032.jpg/220px-Photos_NewYork1_032.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Photos_NewYork1_032.jpg/330px-Photos_NewYork1_032.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Photos_NewYork1_032.jpg/440px-Photos_NewYork1_032.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Photos_NewYork1_032.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
The <a href="/wiki/New_York_Stock_Exchange" title="New York Stock Exchange">New York Stock Exchange</a> on <a href="/wiki/Wall_Street" title="Wall Street">Wall Street</a>, the world's largest stock exchange per total <a href="/wiki/Market_capitalization" title="Market capitalization">market capitalization</a> of its listed companies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYSElargest_70-1"><a href="#cite_note-NYSElargest-70">[70]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYSEhighestcap_71-1"><a href="#cite_note-NYSEhighestcap-71">[71]</a></sup></div>
</div>
</div>
<p>New York City's most important economic sector lies in its role as the headquarters for the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Financial_center" title="Financial center">U.S.financial industry</a>, metonymously known as <i>Wall Street</i>. The city's <a href="/wiki/Security_(finance)" title="Security (finance)">securities</a> industry, enumerating 163,400 jobs in August 2013, continues to form the largest segment of the city's financial sector and an important economic engine, accounting in 2012 for 5 percent of the city's private sector jobs, 8.5 percent (US$3.8 billion) of its tax revenue, and 22 percent of the city's total wages, including an average salary of US$360,700.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-332"><a href="#cite_note-332">[330]</a></sup> Many large financial companies are headquartered in New York City, and the city is also home to a burgeoning number of financial <a href="/wiki/Startup_company" title="Startup company">startup companies</a>.</p>
<p><a href="/wiki/Lower_Manhattan" title="Lower Manhattan">Lower Manhattan</a> is the third-largest <a href="/wiki/Central_business_district" title="Central business district">central business district</a> in the United States and is home to the <a href="/wiki/New_York_Stock_Exchange" title="New York Stock Exchange">New York Stock Exchange</a>, on Wall Street, and the <a href="/wiki/NASDAQ" title="NASDAQ">NASDAQ</a>, at <a href="/wiki/One_Liberty_Plaza" title="One Liberty Plaza">165 Broadway</a>, representing the world's largest and second largest <a href="/wiki/Stock_exchange" title="Stock exchange">stock exchanges</a>, respectively, when measured both by overall average daily trading volume and by total <a href="/wiki/Market_capitalization" title="Market capitalization">market capitalization</a> of their listed companies in 2013.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYSElargest_70-2"><a href="#cite_note-NYSElargest-70">[70]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYSEhighestcap_71-2"><a href="#cite_note-NYSEhighestcap-71">[71]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Investment_banking" title="Investment banking">Investment banking</a> fees on Wall Street totaled approximately $40 billion in 2012,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-333"><a href="#cite_note-333">[331]</a></sup> while in 2013, senior New York City bank officers who manage <a href="/wiki/Risk_management" title="Risk management">risk and compliance</a> functions earned as much as $324,000 annually.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-334"><a href="#cite_note-334">[332]</a></sup> In fiscal year 2013–14, Wall Street's <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Securities_industry" title="Securities industry">securities industry</a> generated 19% of New York State's tax revenue.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-335"><a href="#cite_note-335">[333]</a></sup> New York City remains the largest global center for trading in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Public_equity" title="Public equity">public equity</a> and <a href="/wiki/Security_(finance)" title="Security (finance)">debt</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Capital_markets" title="Capital markets">capital markets</a>, driven in part by the size and <a href="/wiki/Financial_Development_Index" title="Financial Development Index">financial development</a> of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/U.S._economy" title="U.S. economy">U.S. economy</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CNY2007_336-0"><a href="#cite_note-CNY2007-336">[334]</a></sup><sup class="reference" style="white-space:nowrap;">:31–32</sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-337"><a href="#cite_note-337">[335]</a></sup> In July 2013, <a href="/wiki/NYSE_Euronext" title="NYSE Euronext">NYSE Euronext</a>, the operator of the New York Stock Exchange, took over the administration of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/London_interbank_offered_rate" title="London interbank offered rate">London interbank offered rate</a> from the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/British_Bankers_Association" title="British Bankers Association">British Bankers Association</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-338"><a href="#cite_note-338">[336]</a></sup> New York also leads in <a href="/wiki/Hedge_fund" title="Hedge fund">hedge fund</a> management; <a href="/wiki/List_of_private_equity_firms" title="List of private equity firms">private equity</a>; and the monetary volume of <a href="/wiki/Mergers_and_acquisitions" title="Mergers and acquisitions">mergers and acquisitions</a>. Several <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Investment_Banking" title="Investment Banking">investment banks</a> and <a href="/wiki/Investment_management" title="Investment management">investment managers</a> headquartered in Manhattan are important participants in other global financial centers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CNY2007_336-1"><a href="#cite_note-CNY2007-336">[334]</a></sup><sup class="reference" style="white-space:nowrap;">:34–35</sup> New York is also the principal <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Commercial_banking" title="Commercial banking">commercial banking</a> center of the United States.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-339"><a href="#cite_note-339">[337]</a></sup></p>
<p>Many of the world's largest <a href="/wiki/Media_conglomerate" title="Media conglomerate">media conglomerates</a> are also based in the city. Manhattan contained over 500 million square feet (46.5 million m<sup>2</sup>) of office space in 2015,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ManhattanOfficeSpace_340-0"><a href="#cite_note-ManhattanOfficeSpace-340">[338]</a></sup> making it the largest office market in the United States,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-341"><a href="#cite_note-341">[339]</a></sup> while <a href="/wiki/Midtown_Manhattan" title="Midtown Manhattan">Midtown Manhattan</a>, with nearly 400 million square feet (37.2 million m<sup>2</sup>) in 2015,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ManhattanOfficeSpace_340-1"><a href="#cite_note-ManhattanOfficeSpace-340">[338]</a></sup> is the largest central business district in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-342"><a href="#cite_note-342">[340]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Silicon_Alley">Silicon Alley</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Silicon_Alley" title="Silicon Alley">Silicon Alley</a></div>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tech_companies_in_New_York_City" title="Tech companies in New York City">Tech companies in New York City</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Biotech_companies_in_New_York_City" title="Biotech companies in New York City">Biotech companies in New York City</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Flatiron_District.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1146" data-file-width="1749" height="144" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Flatiron_District.jpg/220px-Flatiron_District.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Flatiron_District.jpg/330px-Flatiron_District.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Flatiron_District.jpg/440px-Flatiron_District.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Flatiron_District.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
<a href="/wiki/Silicon_Alley" title="Silicon Alley">Silicon Alley</a>, once centered around the <a href="/wiki/Flatiron_District" title="Flatiron District">Flatiron District</a>, is now <a href="/wiki/Metonymy" title="Metonymy">metonymous</a> for New York's <a href="/wiki/High_tech" title="High tech">high tech</a> sector, which has since expanded beyond the area.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-343"><a href="#cite_note-343">[341]</a></sup></div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Silicon Alley, centered in Manhattan, has evolved into a <a href="/wiki/Metonymy" title="Metonymy">metonym</a> for the sphere encompassing the New York City metropolitan region's high technology industries<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-344"><a href="#cite_note-344">[342]</a></sup> involving the <a href="/wiki/Internet" title="Internet">Internet</a>, <a href="/wiki/New_media" title="New media">new media</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Telecommunications" title="Telecommunications">telecommunications</a>, <a href="/wiki/Digital_media" title="Digital media">digital media</a>, <a href="/wiki/Software_development" title="Software development">software development</a>, <a href="/wiki/Biotechnology" title="Biotechnology">biotechnology</a>, <a href="/wiki/Game_design" title="Game design">game design</a>, <a href="/wiki/Financial_technology" title="Financial technology">financial technology</a> ("<i>FinTech</i>"), and other fields within <a href="/wiki/Information_technology" title="Information technology">information technology</a> that are supported by its <a href="/wiki/Entrepreneurship_ecosystem" title="Entrepreneurship ecosystem">entrepreneurship ecosystem</a> and <a href="/wiki/Venture_capital" title="Venture capital">venture capital</a> investments. In 2015, Silicon Alley generated over US$7.3 billion in venture capital investment across a broad spectrum of high technology enterprises,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-VentureCapitalNY1_51-1"><a href="#cite_note-VentureCapitalNY1-51">[51]</a></sup> most based in Manhattan, with others in Brooklyn, Queens, and elsewhere in the region. High technology <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Startup_companies" title="Startup companies">startup companies</a> and employment are growing in New York City and the region, bolstered by the city's position in North America as the leading Internet hub and telecommunications center, including its vicinity to several <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Transatlantic_telephone_cable" title="Transatlantic telephone cable">transatlantic fiber optic trunk lines</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-345"><a href="#cite_note-345">[343]</a></sup> New York's <a href="/wiki/Intellectual_capital" title="Intellectual capital">intellectual capital</a>, and its extensive outdoor <a href="/wiki/Wireless_network" title="Wireless network">wireless connectivity</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-346"><a href="#cite_note-346">[344]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Verizon_Communications" title="Verizon Communications">Verizon Communications</a>, headquartered at 140 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/West_Street_(Manhattan)" title="West Street (Manhattan)">West Street</a> in Lower Manhattan, was at the final stages in 2014 of completing a US$3 billion <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fiberoptic_communication" title="Fiberoptic communication">fiberoptic telecommunications</a> upgrade throughout New York City.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-347"><a href="#cite_note-347">[345]</a></sup> As of 2014<sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=New_York_City&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, New York City hosted 300,000 employees in the tech sector.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-348"><a href="#cite_note-348">[346]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-349"><a href="#cite_note-349">[347]</a></sup></p>
<p>The biotechnology sector is also growing in New York City, based upon the city's strength in academic scientific <a href="/wiki/Research" title="Research">research</a> and public and commercial financial support. On December 19, 2011, then Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced his choice of <a href="/wiki/Cornell_University" title="Cornell University">Cornell University</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Technion-Israel_Institute_of_Technology" title="Technion-Israel Institute of Technology">Technion-Israel Institute of Technology</a> to build a US$2 billion <a href="/wiki/Graduate_school" title="Graduate school">graduate school</a> of <a href="/wiki/Applied_science" title="Applied science">applied sciences</a> called <a href="/wiki/Cornell_Tech" title="Cornell Tech">Cornell Tech</a> on <a href="/wiki/Roosevelt_Island" title="Roosevelt Island">Roosevelt Island</a> with the goal of transforming New York City into the world's premier technology capital.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-350"><a href="#cite_note-350">[348]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-351"><a href="#cite_note-351">[349]</a></sup> By mid-2014, Accelerator, a biotech <a href="/wiki/Investment" title="Investment">investment</a> firm, had raised more than US$30 million from <a href="/wiki/Investor" title="Investor">investors</a>, including <a href="/wiki/Eli_Lilly_and_Company" title="Eli Lilly and Company">Eli Lilly and Company</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pfizer" title="Pfizer">Pfizer</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Johnson_%26_Johnson" title="Johnson &amp; Johnson">Johnson &amp; Johnson</a>, for initial funding to create biotechnology <a href="/wiki/Startup_company" title="Startup company">startups</a> at the Alexandria Center for Life Science, which encompasses more than 700,000 square feet (65,000 m<sup>2</sup>) on <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/29th_Street_(Manhattan)" title="29th Street (Manhattan)">East 29th Street</a> and promotes collaboration among scientists and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Entrepreneur" title="Entrepreneur">entrepreneurs</a> at the center and with nearby academic, medical, and research institutions. The <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Economic_Development_Corporation" title="New York City Economic Development Corporation">New York City Economic Development Corporation</a>'s Early Stage Life Sciences Funding Initiative and venture capital partners, including <a href="/wiki/Celgene" title="Celgene">Celgene</a>, <a href="/wiki/General_Electric" title="General Electric">General Electric</a> Ventures, and Eli Lilly, committed a minimum of US$100 million to help launch 15 to 20 ventures in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Life_sciences" title="Life sciences">life sciences</a> and biotechnology.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-352"><a href="#cite_note-352">[350]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Tourism">Tourism</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_New_York_City" title="Tourism in New York City">Tourism in New York City</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:1_times_square_night_2013.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="4912" data-file-width="7360" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/1_times_square_night_2013.jpg/220px-1_times_square_night_2013.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/1_times_square_night_2013.jpg/330px-1_times_square_night_2013.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/1_times_square_night_2013.jpg/440px-1_times_square_night_2013.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:1_times_square_night_2013.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
<a href="/wiki/Times_Square" title="Times Square">Times Square</a> is the hub of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Broadway_theater" title="Broadway theater">Broadway theater</a> <a href="/wiki/Theater_District,_Manhattan" title="Theater District, Manhattan">district</a> and a <a href="/wiki/Media_(communication)" title="Media (communication)">media</a> center. It also has one of the highest annual attendance rates of any tourist attraction in the world, estimated at 50 million.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ann_Shields_57-1"><a href="#cite_note-Ann_Shields-57">[57]</a></sup></div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:I_Love_New_York.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="279" data-file-width="300" height="205" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/I_Love_New_York.svg/220px-I_Love_New_York.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/I_Love_New_York.svg/330px-I_Love_New_York.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/I_Love_New_York.svg/440px-I_Love_New_York.svg.png 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:I_Love_New_York.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
The <i><a href="/wiki/I_Love_New_York" title="I Love New York">I Love New York</a></i> logo, designed by <a href="/wiki/Milton_Glaser" title="Milton Glaser">Milton Glaser</a> in 1977</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Tourism is a vital industry for New York City, which has witnessed a growing combined volume of international and domestic tourists, receiving a seventh consecutive annual record of approximately 61 million visitors in 2016.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYCTouristCount_56-1"><a href="#cite_note-NYCTouristCount-56">[56]</a></sup> Tourism had generated an all-time high US$61.3 billion in overall economic impact for New York City in 2014,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYCTouristCount_56-2"><a href="#cite_note-NYCTouristCount-56">[56]</a></sup> pending 2015 statistics. Approximately 12 million visitors to New York City were from outside the United States, with the highest numbers from the <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom" title="United Kingdom">United Kingdom</a>, <a href="/wiki/Canada" title="Canada">Canada</a>, <a href="/wiki/Brazil" title="Brazil">Brazil</a>, and <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a>. According to the website reuters.com, "New York City tourism climb[ed] record high in 2015 for [the] sixth year.".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYCTouristCount_56-3"><a href="#cite_note-NYCTouristCount-56">[56]</a></sup></p>
<p><i><a href="/wiki/I_Love_New_York" title="I Love New York">I Love New York</a></i> (stylized <b>I ❤ NY</b>) is both a <a href="/wiki/Logo" title="Logo">logo</a> and a <a href="/wiki/Song" title="Song">song</a> that are the basis of an <a href="/wiki/Advertising" title="Advertising">advertising</a> campaign and have been used since 1977 to promote <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_New_York_City" title="Tourism in New York City">tourism</a> in New York City,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-353"><a href="#cite_note-353">[351]</a></sup> and later to promote New York State as well. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Trademarked" title="Trademarked">trademarked</a> logo, owned by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/New_York_State_Empire_State_Development" title="New York State Empire State Development">New York State Empire State Development</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-354"><a href="#cite_note-354">[352]</a></sup> appears in souvenir shops and brochures throughout the city and state, some licensed, many not. The song is the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/State_song" title="State song">state song</a> of New York.</p>
<p>Major tourist destinations include <a href="/wiki/Times_Square" title="Times Square">Times Square</a>; <a href="/wiki/Broadway_theatre" title="Broadway theatre">Broadway theater</a> productions; the <a href="/wiki/Empire_State_Building" title="Empire State Building">Empire State Building</a>; the <a href="/wiki/Statue_of_Liberty" title="Statue of Liberty">Statue of Liberty</a>; <a href="/wiki/Ellis_Island" title="Ellis Island">Ellis Island</a>; the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/United_Nations_Headquarters" title="United Nations Headquarters">United Nations Headquarters</a>; museums such as the <a href="/wiki/Metropolitan_Museum_of_Art" title="Metropolitan Museum of Art">Metropolitan Museum of Art</a>; greenspaces such as <a href="/wiki/Central_Park" title="Central Park">Central Park</a> and <a href="/wiki/Washington_Square_Park" title="Washington Square Park">Washington Square Park</a>; <a href="/wiki/Rockefeller_Center" title="Rockefeller Center">Rockefeller Center</a>; the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Manhattan_Chinatown" title="Manhattan Chinatown">Manhattan Chinatown</a>; luxury shopping along <a href="/wiki/Fifth_Avenue" title="Fifth Avenue">Fifth</a> and <a href="/wiki/Madison_Avenue" title="Madison Avenue">Madison Avenues</a>; and events such as the <a href="/wiki/New_York%27s_Village_Halloween_Parade" title="New York's Village Halloween Parade">Halloween Parade</a> in <a href="/wiki/Greenwich_Village" title="Greenwich Village">Greenwich Village</a>; the <a href="/wiki/Macy%27s_Thanksgiving_Day_Parade" title="Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade">Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade</a>; the lighting of the <a href="/wiki/Rockefeller_Center_Christmas_Tree" title="Rockefeller Center Christmas Tree">Rockefeller Center Christmas Tree</a>; the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/St._Patrick%27s_Day#New_York_City" title="St. Patrick's Day">St. Patrick's Day parade</a>; seasonal activities such as ice skating in Central Park in the wintertime;
