the <a href="/wiki/Tribeca_Film_Festival" title="Tribeca Film Festival">Tribeca Film Festival</a>; and free performances in Central Park at Summerstage.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYC_-_A_Vast_Richness_Of_History.2C_Music.2C_Culture.2C_Cuisine_and_Color_355-0"><a href="#cite_note-NYC_-_A_Vast_Richness_Of_History.2C_Music.2C_Culture.2C_Cuisine_and_Color-355">[353]</a></sup> Major attractions in the boroughs outside Manhattan include <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Flushing_Meadows-Corona_Park" title="Flushing Meadows-Corona Park">Flushing Meadows-Corona Park</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Unisphere" title="Unisphere">Unisphere</a> in Queens; the <a href="/wiki/Bronx_Zoo" title="Bronx Zoo">Bronx Zoo</a>; <a href="/wiki/Coney_Island" title="Coney Island">Coney Island</a>, Brooklyn; and the <a href="/wiki/New_York_Botanical_Garden" title="New York Botanical Garden">New York Botanical Garden</a> in the Bronx. The <a href="/wiki/New_York_Wheel" title="New York Wheel">New York Wheel</a>, a 630-foot <a href="/wiki/Ferris_wheel" title="Ferris wheel">ferris wheel</a>, was under construction at the northern shore of Staten Island in 2015,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-356"><a href="#cite_note-356">[354]</a></sup> overlooking the Statue of Liberty, New York Harbor, and the Lower Manhattan skyline.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-357"><a href="#cite_note-357">[355]</a></sup></p>
<p>Manhattan was on track to have an estimated 90,000 <a href="/wiki/Hotel" title="Hotel">hotel</a> rooms at the end of 2014, a 10% increase from 2013.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-358"><a href="#cite_note-358">[356]</a></sup> In October 2014, the Anbang Insurance Group, based in <a href="/wiki/China" title="China">China</a>, purchased the <a href="/wiki/Waldorf_Astoria_New_York" title="Waldorf Astoria New York">Waldorf Astoria New York</a> for US$1.95 billion, making it the world's most expensive hotel ever sold.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-359"><a href="#cite_note-359">[357]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Media_and_entertainment">Media and entertainment</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Media_in_New_York_City" title="Media in New York City">Media in New York City</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Rockefeller_Center_(2006).JPG"><img alt="Ice skaters on a rink below a golden sculpture and a row of national flags that fly in front of a stone tower." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1200" data-file-width="1600" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/Rockefeller_Center_%282006%29.JPG/220px-Rockefeller_Center_%282006%29.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/Rockefeller_Center_%282006%29.JPG/330px-Rockefeller_Center_%282006%29.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/Rockefeller_Center_%282006%29.JPG/440px-Rockefeller_Center_%282006%29.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Rockefeller_Center_(2006).JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
<a href="/wiki/Rockefeller_Center" title="Rockefeller Center">Rockefeller Center</a> is home to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/NBC_Studios_(New_York)" title="NBC Studios (New York)">NBC Studios</a>.</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>New York is a prominent location for the American <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Entertainment_industry" title="Entertainment industry">entertainment industry</a>, with many <a href="/wiki/Film_industry" title="Film industry">films</a>, television series, books, and other media being set there.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-360"><a href="#cite_note-360">[358]</a></sup> As of 2012<sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=New_York_City&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, New York City was the second largest center for <a href="/wiki/Filmmaking" title="Filmmaking">filmmaking</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Television_production" title="Television production">television production</a> in the United States, producing about 200 <a href="/wiki/Feature_film" title="Feature film">feature films</a> annually, employing 130,000 individuals; the filmed entertainment industry has been growing in New York, contributing nearly US$9 billion to the New York City economy alone as of 2015,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-361"><a href="#cite_note-361">[359]</a></sup> and by volume, New York is the world leader in <a href="/wiki/Independent_film" title="Independent film">independent film</a> production<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-362"><a href="#cite_note-362">[360]</a></sup> – one-third of all American independent films are produced in New York City.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYC_Media_363-0"><a href="#cite_note-NYC_Media-363">[361]</a></sup> The Association of Independent Commercial Producers is also based in New York.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-364"><a href="#cite_note-364">[362]</a></sup> In the first five months of 2014 alone, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Location_filming" title="Location filming">location filming</a> for <a href="/wiki/Television_pilot" title="Television pilot">television pilots</a> in New York City exceeded the record production levels for all of 2013,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-365"><a href="#cite_note-365">[363]</a></sup> with New York surpassing Los Angeles as the top North American city for the same distinction during the 2013/2014 cycle.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-366"><a href="#cite_note-366">[364]</a></sup></p>
<p>New York City is additionally a center for the <a href="/wiki/Advertising" title="Advertising">advertising</a>, music, newspaper, digital media, and <a href="/wiki/Publishing" title="Publishing">publishing</a> industries and is also the largest media market in North America.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-367"><a href="#cite_note-367">[365]</a></sup> Some of the city's <a href="/wiki/Media_conglomerate" title="Media conglomerate">media conglomerates</a> and institutions include <a href="/wiki/Time_Warner" title="Time Warner">Time Warner</a>, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Thomson_Reuters_Corporation" title="Thomson Reuters Corporation">Thomson Reuters Corporation</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Associated_Press" title="Associated Press">Associated Press</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bloomberg_L.P." title="Bloomberg L.P.">Bloomberg L.P.</a>, the <a href="/wiki/News_Corporation" title="News Corporation">News Corporation</a>, <a href="/wiki/The_New_York_Times_Company" title="The New York Times Company">The New York Times Company</a>, <a href="/wiki/NBCUniversal" title="NBCUniversal">NBCUniversal</a>, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hearst_Corporation" title="Hearst Corporation">Hearst Corporation</a>, <a href="/wiki/AOL" title="AOL">AOL</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Viacom" title="Viacom">Viacom</a>. Seven of the world's top eight global <a href="/wiki/Advertising_agency" title="Advertising agency">advertising agency</a> networks have their headquarters in New York.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-368"><a href="#cite_note-368">[366]</a></sup> Two of the top three <a href="/wiki/Music_industry" title="Music industry">record labels'</a> headquarters are in New York: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sony_Music_Entertainment" title="Sony Music Entertainment">Sony Music Entertainment</a> and <a href="/wiki/Warner_Music_Group" title="Warner Music Group">Warner Music Group</a>. <a href="/wiki/Universal_Music_Group" title="Universal Music Group">Universal Music Group</a> also has offices in New York. <a href="/wiki/New_media" title="New media">New media</a> enterprises are contributing an increasingly important component to the city's central role in the media sphere.</p>
<p>More than 200 newspapers and 350 <a href="/wiki/Magazine" title="Magazine">consumer magazines</a> have an office in the city,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYC_Media_363-1"><a href="#cite_note-NYC_Media-363">[361]</a></sup> and the publishing industry employs about 25,000 people.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-369"><a href="#cite_note-369">[367]</a></sup> Two of the three national daily newspapers in the United States are New York papers: <i><a href="/wiki/The_Wall_Street_Journal" title="The Wall Street Journal">The Wall Street Journal</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/The_New_York_Times" title="The New York Times">The New York Times</a></i>, which has won the most <a href="/wiki/Pulitzer_Prize" title="Pulitzer Prize">Pulitzer Prizes</a> for journalism. Major tabloid newspapers in the city include: <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Daily_News_(New_York)" title="Daily News (New York)">The New York Daily News</a></i>, which was founded in 1919 by <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Medill_Patterson" title="Joseph Medill Patterson">Joseph Medill Patterson</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-370"><a href="#cite_note-370">[368]</a></sup> and <i><a href="/wiki/New_York_Post" title="New York Post">The New York Post</a></i>, founded in 1801 by <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Hamilton" title="Alexander Hamilton">Alexander Hamilton</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-371"><a href="#cite_note-371">[369]</a></sup> The city also has a comprehensive ethnic press, with 270 newspapers and magazines published in more than 40 languages.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-372"><a href="#cite_note-372">[370]</a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/El_Diario_La_Prensa" title="El Diario La Prensa">El Diario La Prensa</a></i> is New York's largest <a href="/wiki/Spanish_language" title="Spanish language">Spanish-language</a> daily and the oldest in the nation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-373"><a href="#cite_note-373">[371]</a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/New_York_Amsterdam_News" title="New York Amsterdam News">The New York Amsterdam News</a></i>, published in Harlem, is a prominent African American newspaper. <i><a href="/wiki/The_Village_Voice" title="The Village Voice">The Village Voice</a></i>, historically the largest <a href="/wiki/Alternative_newspaper" title="Alternative newspaper">alternative newspaper</a> in the United States, announced in 2017 that it would cease publication of its print edition and convert to a fully digital venture.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-VillageVoiceDigital_374-0"><a href="#cite_note-VillageVoiceDigital-374">[372]</a></sup></p>
<p>The television and radio industry developed in New York and is a significant employer in the city's economy. The three major American <a href="/wiki/Broadcast_network" title="Broadcast network">broadcast networks</a> are all headquartered in New York: <a href="/wiki/American_Broadcasting_Company" title="American Broadcasting Company">ABC</a>, <a href="/wiki/CBS" title="CBS">CBS</a>, and <a href="/wiki/NBC" title="NBC">NBC</a>. Many cable networks are based in the city as well, including <a href="/wiki/MTV" title="MTV">MTV</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fox_News_Channel" title="Fox News Channel">Fox News</a>, <a href="/wiki/HBO" title="HBO">HBO</a>, <a href="/wiki/Showtime_(TV_network)" title="Showtime (TV network)">Showtime</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bravo_(U.S._TV_network)" title="Bravo (U.S. TV network)">Bravo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Food_Network" title="Food Network">Food Network</a>, <a href="/wiki/AMC_(TV_channel)" title="AMC (TV channel)">AMC</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Comedy_Central" title="Comedy Central">Comedy Central</a>. The City of New York operates a public broadcast service, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/NYCTV" title="NYCTV">NYCTV</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-375"><a href="#cite_note-375">[373]</a></sup> that has produced several original <a href="/wiki/Emmy_Award" title="Emmy Award">Emmy Award</a>-winning shows covering music and culture in city neighborhoods and city government. <a href="/wiki/WBAI" title="WBAI">WBAI</a>, with news and information programming, is one of the few <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Socialist" title="Socialist">socialist</a> radio stations operating in the United States.</p>
<p>New York is also a major center for <a href="/wiki/Non-commercial_educational" title="Non-commercial educational">non-commercial educational</a> media. The oldest <a href="/wiki/Public-access_television" title="Public-access television">public-access television</a> channel in the United States is the <a href="/wiki/Manhattan_Neighborhood_Network" title="Manhattan Neighborhood Network">Manhattan Neighborhood Network</a>, founded in 1971.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-376"><a href="#cite_note-376">[374]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/WNET" title="WNET">WNET</a> is the city's major public television station and a primary source of national <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Public_Broadcasting_Service" title="Public Broadcasting Service">Public Broadcasting Service</a> (PBS) television programming. <a href="/wiki/WNYC" title="WNYC">WNYC</a>, a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Public_radio" title="Public radio">public radio</a> station owned by the city until 1997, has the largest public radio audience in the United States.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-377"><a href="#cite_note-377">[375]</a></sup></p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Human_resources">Human resources</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Education_and_scholarly_activity">Education and scholarly activity</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Education_in_New_York_City" title="Education in New York City">Education in New York City</a></div>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Primary_and_secondary_education">Primary and secondary education</span></h4>
<p>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/New_York_City_Public_Schools" title="New York City Public Schools">New York City Public Schools</a> system, managed by the <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Department_of_Education" title="New York City Department of Education">New York City Department of Education</a>, is the largest public school system in the United States, serving about 1.1 million students in more than 1,700 separate primary and secondary schools.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-378"><a href="#cite_note-378">[376]</a></sup> The city's public school system includes nine <a href="/wiki/Specialized_high_schools_in_New_York_City" title="Specialized high schools in New York City">specialized high schools</a> to serve academically and artistically <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gifted_student" title="Gifted student">gifted students</a>. The city government pays the <a href="/wiki/Pelham_Public_Schools" title="Pelham Public Schools">Pelham Public Schools</a> to educate a very small, detached section of the Bronx.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-gross19970506_379-0"><a href="#cite_note-gross19970506-379">[377]</a></sup></p>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Butler_Library_-_1000px_-_AC.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="664" data-file-width="1000" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/Butler_Library_-_1000px_-_AC.jpg/220px-Butler_Library_-_1000px_-_AC.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/Butler_Library_-_1000px_-_AC.jpg/330px-Butler_Library_-_1000px_-_AC.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/Butler_Library_-_1000px_-_AC.jpg/440px-Butler_Library_-_1000px_-_AC.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Butler_Library_-_1000px_-_AC.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
<a href="/wiki/Butler_Library" title="Butler Library">Butler Library</a> at <a href="/wiki/Columbia_University" title="Columbia University">Columbia University</a>, described as one of the most beautiful college libraries in the United States.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-380"><a href="#cite_note-380">[378]</a></sup></div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:NYC_-_Washington_Square_Park_-_Arch.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="4000" data-file-width="6000" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/NYC_-_Washington_Square_Park_-_Arch.jpg/220px-NYC_-_Washington_Square_Park_-_Arch.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/NYC_-_Washington_Square_Park_-_Arch.jpg/330px-NYC_-_Washington_Square_Park_-_Arch.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/NYC_-_Washington_Square_Park_-_Arch.jpg/440px-NYC_-_Washington_Square_Park_-_Arch.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:NYC_-_Washington_Square_Park_-_Arch.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
The <a href="/wiki/Washington_Square_Arch" title="Washington Square Arch">Washington Square Arch</a>, an unofficial icon of both <a href="/wiki/New_York_University" title="New York University">New York University</a> (NYU) and its <a href="/wiki/Greenwich_Village" title="Greenwich Village">Greenwich Village</a> neighborhood.</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>The New York City Charter School Center assists the setup of new <a href="/wiki/Charter_school" title="Charter school">charter schools</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-381"><a href="#cite_note-381">[379]</a></sup> There are approximately 900 additional privately run secular and religious schools in the city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-382"><a href="#cite_note-382">[380]</a></sup></p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Higher_education_and_research">Higher education and research</span></h4>
<p>Over 600,000 students are enrolled in New York City's over 120 <a href="/wiki/Higher_education" title="Higher education">higher education</a> institutions, the highest number of any city in the United States, including over half million in the <a href="/wiki/City_University_of_New_York" title="City University of New York">City University of New York</a> (CUNY) system alone in 2014.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-383"><a href="#cite_note-383">[381]</a></sup> In 2005, three out of five Manhattan residents were college graduates, and one out of four had a <a href="/wiki/Postgraduate_education" title="Postgraduate education">postgraduate degree</a>, forming one of the highest concentrations of highly educated people in any American city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-384"><a href="#cite_note-384">[382]</a></sup> New York City is home to such notable private universities as <a href="/wiki/Barnard_College" title="Barnard College">Barnard College</a>, <a href="/wiki/Columbia_University" title="Columbia University">Columbia University</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cooper_Union" title="Cooper Union">Cooper Union</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fordham_University" title="Fordham University">Fordham University</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mercy_College_(New_York)" title="Mercy College (New York)">Mercy College</a>, <a href="/wiki/New_York_University" title="New York University">New York University</a>, <a href="/wiki/New_York_Institute_of_Technology" title="New York Institute of Technology">New York Institute of Technology</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pace_University" title="Pace University">Pace University</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Yeshiva_University" title="Yeshiva University">Yeshiva University</a>. The public CUNY system is one of the largest universities in the nation, comprising 24 institutions across all five boroughs: senior colleges, <a href="/wiki/Community_college" title="Community college">community colleges</a>, and other graduate/professional schools. The public <a href="/wiki/State_University_of_New_York" title="State University of New York">State University of New York</a> (SUNY) system serves New York City, as well as the rest of the state. The city also has other smaller private colleges and universities, including many religious and special-purpose institutions, such as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/St._John%27s_University_(Jamaica,_NY)" title="St. John's University (Jamaica, NY)">St. John's University</a>, <a href="/wiki/Juilliard_School" title="Juilliard School">The Juilliard School</a>, <a href="/wiki/Manhattan_College" title="Manhattan College">Manhattan College</a>, <a href="/wiki/College_of_Mount_Saint_Vincent" title="College of Mount Saint Vincent">The College of Mount Saint Vincent</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fashion_Institute_of_Technology" title="Fashion Institute of Technology">Fashion Institute of Technology</a>, <a href="/wiki/Parsons_School_of_Design" title="Parsons School of Design">Parsons School of Design</a>, <a href="/wiki/The_New_School" title="The New School">The New School</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pratt_Institute" title="Pratt Institute">Pratt Institute</a>, <a href="/wiki/School_of_Visual_Arts" title="School of Visual Arts">The School of Visual Arts</a>, The King's College, and <a href="/wiki/Wagner_College" title="Wagner College">Wagner College</a>.</p>
<p>Much of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Scientific_research" title="Scientific research">scientific research</a> in the city is done in <a href="/wiki/Medicine" title="Medicine">medicine</a> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Life_sciences" title="Life sciences">life sciences</a>. New York City has the most post-graduate life sciences degrees awarded annually in the United States, with 127 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nobel_laureate" title="Nobel laureate">Nobel laureates</a> having roots in local institutions as of 2005<sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=New_York_City&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYC_science_institutions_385-0"><a href="#cite_note-NYC_science_institutions-385">[383]</a></sup> while in 2012, 43,523 licensed <a href="/wiki/Physician" title="Physician">physicians</a> were practicing in New York City.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-386"><a href="#cite_note-386">[384]</a></sup> Major biomedical research institutions include <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Memorial_Sloan%E2%80%93Kettering_Cancer_Center" title="Memorial Sloan–Kettering Cancer Center">Memorial Sloan–Kettering Cancer Center</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rockefeller_University" title="Rockefeller University">Rockefeller University</a>, <a href="/wiki/SUNY_Downstate_Medical_Center" title="SUNY Downstate Medical Center">SUNY Downstate Medical Center</a>, <a href="/wiki/Albert_Einstein_College_of_Medicine" title="Albert Einstein College of Medicine">Albert Einstein College of Medicine</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mount_Sinai_School_of_Medicine" title="Mount Sinai School of Medicine">Mount Sinai School of Medicine</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Weill_Cornell_Medical_College_of_Cornell_University" title="Weill Cornell Medical College of Cornell University">Weill Cornell Medical College</a>, being joined by the <a href="/wiki/Cornell_University" title="Cornell University">Cornell University</a>/<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Technion-Israel_Institute_of_Technology" title="Technion-Israel Institute of Technology">Technion-Israel Institute of Technology</a> venture on <a href="/wiki/Roosevelt_Island" title="Roosevelt Island">Roosevelt Island</a>. The graduates of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/SUNY_Maritime_College" title="SUNY Maritime College">SUNY Maritime College</a> in the Bronx earned the highest average annual salary of any university graduates in the United States, US$144,000 as of 2017.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SUNYMaritime_387-0"><a href="#cite_note-SUNYMaritime-387">[385]</a></sup></p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Public_library_system">Public library system</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tleft">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:New_York_Public_Library_May_2011.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3000" data-file-width="4000" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/New_York_Public_Library_May_2011.JPG/220px-New_York_Public_Library_May_2011.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/New_York_Public_Library_May_2011.JPG/330px-New_York_Public_Library_May_2011.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/New_York_Public_Library_May_2011.JPG/440px-New_York_Public_Library_May_2011.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:New_York_Public_Library_May_2011.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
The Stephen A. Schwarzman <a href="/wiki/Headquarters" title="Headquarters">Headquarters</a> Building of the <a href="/wiki/New_York_Public_Library" title="New York Public Library">New York Public Library</a>, at <a href="/wiki/Fifth_Avenue" title="Fifth Avenue">5th Avenue</a> and <a href="/wiki/42nd_Street_(Manhattan)" title="42nd Street (Manhattan)">42nd Street</a>.</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/New_York_Public_Library" title="New York Public Library">New York Public Library</a>, which has the largest collection of any public library system in the United States, serves Manhattan, the Bronx, and Staten Island.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-libraryspot_388-0"><a href="#cite_note-libraryspot-388">[386]</a></sup> Queens is served by the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Queens_Borough_Public_Library" title="Queens Borough Public Library">Queens Borough Public Library</a>, the nation's second largest public library system, while the <a href="/wiki/Brooklyn_Public_Library" title="Brooklyn Public Library">Brooklyn Public Library</a> serves Brooklyn.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-libraryspot_388-1"><a href="#cite_note-libraryspot-388">[386]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Public_health">Public health</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/New_York_City_Health_and_Hospitals_Corporation" title="New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation">New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:NewYorkPresbyterian-Cornell.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="587" data-file-width="800" height="161" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/NewYorkPresbyterian-Cornell.jpg/220px-NewYorkPresbyterian-Cornell.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/NewYorkPresbyterian-Cornell.jpg/330px-NewYorkPresbyterian-Cornell.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/NewYorkPresbyterian-Cornell.jpg/440px-NewYorkPresbyterian-Cornell.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:NewYorkPresbyterian-Cornell.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/New_York-Presbyterian_Hospital" title="New York-Presbyterian Hospital">New York-Presbyterian Hospital</a>, white complex at center, the largest hospital and largest private employer in New York City<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-389"><a href="#cite_note-389">[387]</a></sup> and one of the world's busiest.</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>The New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation (HHC) operates the <a href="/wiki/Public_hospital#United_States" title="Public hospital">public hospitals</a> and <a href="/wiki/Clinic" title="Clinic">clinics</a> in New York City. A <a href="/wiki/Public-benefit_corporation" title="Public-benefit corporation">public benefit corporation</a> with $6.7 billion in annual revenues, HHC is the largest municipal healthcare system in the United States serving 1.4 million patients, including more than 475,000 uninsured city residents.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HHC1_390-0"><a href="#cite_note-HHC1-390">[388]</a></sup> HHC was created in 1969 by the <a href="/wiki/New_York_State_Legislature" title="New York State Legislature">New York State Legislature</a> as a public benefit corporation (Chapter 1016 of the Laws 1969).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-391"><a href="#cite_note-391">[389]</a></sup> HHC operates 11 <a href="/wiki/Acute_care" title="Acute care">acute care</a> hospitals, five nursing homes, six diagnostic and treatment centers, and more than 70 community-based <a href="/wiki/Primary_care" title="Primary care">primary care</a> sites, serving primarily the poor and working class. HHC's MetroPlus Health Plan is one of the New York area's largest providers of government-sponsored health insurance and is the plan of choice for nearly half million New Yorkers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Metroplus_392-0"><a href="#cite_note-Metroplus-392">[390]</a></sup></p>
<p>HHC's facilities annually provide millions of New Yorkers services interpreted in more than 190 languages.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HHC2_393-0"><a href="#cite_note-HHC2-393">[391]</a></sup> The most well-known hospital in the HHC system is <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bellevue_Hospital" title="Bellevue Hospital">Bellevue Hospital</a>, the oldest public hospital in the United States. Bellevue is the designated hospital for treatment of the <a href="/wiki/President_of_the_United_States" title="President of the United States">President of the United States</a> and other <a href="/wiki/List_of_current_heads_of_state_and_government" title="List of current heads of state and government">world leaders</a> if they become sick or injured while in New York City.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Funding_Universe_Web_Site_394-0"><a href="#cite_note-Funding_Universe_Web_Site-394">[392]</a></sup> The president of HHC is Ramanathan Raju, MD, a <a href="/wiki/Surgeon" title="Surgeon">surgeon</a> and former CEO of the Cook County health system in Illinois.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-395"><a href="#cite_note-395">[393]</a></sup> In August 2017, Mayor <a href="/wiki/Bill_de_Blasio" title="Bill de Blasio">Bill de Blasio</a> signed legislation outlawing <a href="/wiki/Pharmacy" title="Pharmacy">pharmacies</a> from selling cigarettes once their existing licenses to do so expired, beginning in 2018.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-396"><a href="#cite_note-396">[394]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Public_safety">Public safety</span></h3>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Police_and_law_enforcement">Police and law enforcement</span></h4>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/New_York_Police_Department" title="New York Police Department">New York Police Department</a> and <a href="/wiki/Law_enforcement_in_New_York_City" title="Law enforcement in New York City">Law enforcement in New York City</a></div>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Crime_in_New_York_City" title="Crime in New York City">Crime in New York City</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Manhattan,_New_York_-_USA_(6914876902).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2645" data-file-width="3962" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d9/Manhattan%2C_New_York_-_USA_%286914876902%29.jpg/220px-Manhattan%2C_New_York_-_USA_%286914876902%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d9/Manhattan%2C_New_York_-_USA_%286914876902%29.jpg/330px-Manhattan%2C_New_York_-_USA_%286914876902%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d9/Manhattan%2C_New_York_-_USA_%286914876902%29.jpg/440px-Manhattan%2C_New_York_-_USA_%286914876902%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Manhattan,_New_York_-_USA_(6914876902).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
The <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Police_Department" title="New York City Police Department">New York City Police Department</a> (NYPD) represents the largest police force in the United States.</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Police_Department" title="New York City Police Department">New York City Police Department</a> (NYPD) has been the largest police force in the United States by a significant margin, with over 35,000 sworn officers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-397"><a href="#cite_note-397">[395]</a></sup> Members of the NYPD are frequently referred to by politicians, the media, and their own police cars by the nickname, <i>New York's Finest</i>.</p>
<p>Crime has continued an overall downward trend in New York City since the 1990s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-398"><a href="#cite_note-398">[396]</a></sup> In 2012, the NYPD came under scrutiny for its use of a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/New_York_City_stop-and-frisk_program" title="New York City stop-and-frisk program">stop-and-frisk</a> program,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-399"><a href="#cite_note-399">[397]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-400"><a href="#cite_note-400">[398]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-401"><a href="#cite_note-401">[399]</a></sup> which has undergone several policy revisions since then. In 2014, New York City had the third lowest murder rate among the largest U.S. cities,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-402"><a href="#cite_note-402">[400]</a></sup> having become significantly safer after a spike in crime in the 1970s through 1990s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Prager_403-0"><a href="#cite_note-Prager-403">[401]</a></sup> Violent crime in New York City decreased more than 75% from 1993 to 2005, and continued decreasing during periods when the nation as a whole saw increases.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Law_404-0"><a href="#cite_note-Law-404">[402]</a></sup> By 2002, New York City's crime rate was similar to that of <a href="/wiki/Provo,_Utah" title="Provo, Utah">Provo, Utah</a>, and was ranked 197th in crime among the 216 U.S. cities with populations greater than 100,000.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Law_404-1"><a href="#cite_note-Law-404">[402]</a></sup> In 2005, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_homicide_rate" title="List of countries by homicide rate">homicide rate</a> was at its lowest level since 1966,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-405"><a href="#cite_note-405">[403]</a></sup> and in 2007, the city recorded fewer than 500 <a href="/wiki/Homicide" title="Homicide">homicides</a> for the first time ever since crime statistics were first published in 1963.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-406"><a href="#cite_note-406">[404]</a></sup> In 2015, 50.5% of New York City misdemeanor assault suspects were black, 33.3% Hispanic, 11.1% white, 4.8% Asian/Pacific Islander and 0.3% Native American.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-407"><a href="#cite_note-407">[405]</a></sup> New York City experienced 352 homicides in 2015,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-408"><a href="#cite_note-408">[406]</a></sup> its second lowest number on record.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-409"><a href="#cite_note-409">[407]</a></sup></p>
<p>Sociologists and criminologists have not reached consensus on the explanation for the dramatic decrease in the city's crime rate. Some attribute the phenomenon to new tactics used by the NYPD,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-410"><a href="#cite_note-410">[408]</a></sup> including its use of <a href="/wiki/CompStat" title="CompStat">CompStat</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Broken_windows_theory" title="Broken windows theory">broken windows theory</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-411"><a href="#cite_note-411">[409]</a></sup> Others cite the end of the <a href="/wiki/Crack_epidemic" title="Crack epidemic">crack epidemic</a> and demographic changes,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-412"><a href="#cite_note-412">[410]</a></sup> including from immigration.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-413"><a href="#cite_note-413">[411]</a></sup> Another theory is that widespread exposure to lead pollution from automobile exhaust, which can lower intelligence and increase aggression levels, incited the initial crime wave in the mid-20th century, most acutely affecting heavily trafficked cities like New York. A strong correlation was found demonstrating that violent crime rates in New York and other big cities began to fall after lead was removed from American gasoline in the 1970s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-414"><a href="#cite_note-414">[412]</a></sup> Another theory cited to explain New York City's falling homicide rate is the inverse correlation between the number of murders and the increasingly wetter climate in the city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-415"><a href="#cite_note-415">[413]</a></sup></p>
<p><a href="/wiki/Organized_crime" title="Organized crime">Organized crime</a> has long been associated with New York City, beginning with the <a href="/wiki/Forty_Thieves_(New_York_gang)" title="Forty Thieves (New York gang)">Forty Thieves</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Roach_Guards" title="Roach Guards">Roach Guards</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Five_Points,_Manhattan" title="Five Points, Manhattan">Five Points</a> in the 1820s. The 20th century saw a rise in the <a href="/wiki/American_Mafia" title="American Mafia">Mafia</a>, dominated by the <a href="/wiki/Five_Families" title="Five Families">Five Families</a>, as well as in <a href="/wiki/Gang" title="Gang">gangs</a>, including the <a href="/wiki/Black_Spades" title="Black Spades">Black Spades</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-416"><a href="#cite_note-416">[414]</a></sup> The Mafia and gang presence has declined in the city in the 21st century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-417"><a href="#cite_note-417">[415]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-418"><a href="#cite_note-418">[416]</a></sup></p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Firefighting">Firefighting</span></h4>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Fire_Department" title="New York City Fire Department">New York City Fire Department</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Peter_Stehlik_-_FDNY_Rescue_1_-_2012.05.18.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3456" data-file-width="5184" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Peter_Stehlik_-_FDNY_Rescue_1_-_2012.05.18.JPG/220px-Peter_Stehlik_-_FDNY_Rescue_1_-_2012.05.18.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Peter_Stehlik_-_FDNY_Rescue_1_-_2012.05.18.JPG/330px-Peter_Stehlik_-_FDNY_Rescue_1_-_2012.05.18.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Peter_Stehlik_-_FDNY_Rescue_1_-_2012.05.18.JPG/440px-Peter_Stehlik_-_FDNY_Rescue_1_-_2012.05.18.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Peter_Stehlik_-_FDNY_Rescue_1_-_2012.05.18.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
The <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Fire_Department" title="New York City Fire Department">New York City Fire Department</a> (FDNY) is the largest municipal fire department in the United States.</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Fire_Department" title="New York City Fire Department">New York City Fire Department</a> (FDNY), provides <a href="/wiki/Fire_protection" title="Fire protection">fire protection</a>, technical rescue, primary response to biological, chemical, and radioactive hazards, and <a href="/wiki/Emergency_medical_services" title="Emergency medical services">emergency medical services</a> for the five boroughs of New York City. The New York City Fire Department is the largest municipal <a href="/wiki/Fire_department" title="Fire department">fire department</a> in the United States and the second largest in the world after the <a href="/wiki/Tokyo_Fire_Department" title="Tokyo Fire Department">Tokyo Fire Department</a>. The FDNY employs approximately 11,080 uniformed <a href="/wiki/Firefighter" title="Firefighter">firefighters</a> and over 3,300 uniformed <a href="/wiki/Emergency_medical_technician" title="Emergency medical technician">EMTs</a> and <a href="/wiki/Paramedic" title="Paramedic">paramedics</a>. The FDNY's motto is <i>New York's Bravest</i>.</p>
<p>The New York City Fire Department faces highly multifaceted firefighting challenges in many ways unique to New York. In addition to responding to building types that range from wood-frame single family homes to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/High-rise" title="High-rise">high-rise structures</a>, there are many secluded bridges and tunnels, as well as large parks and wooded areas that can give rise to brush fires. New York is also home to one of the largest <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Subway" title="New York City Subway">subway systems</a> in the world, consisting of hundreds of miles of tunnel with electrified track.</p>
<p>The FDNY headquarters is located at <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/9_MetroTech_Center" title="9 MetroTech Center">9 MetroTech Center</a> in <a href="/wiki/Downtown_Brooklyn" title="Downtown Brooklyn">Downtown Brooklyn</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-419"><a href="#cite_note-419">[417]</a></sup> and the FDNY Fire Academy is located on <a href="/wiki/Randalls_and_Wards_Islands" title="Randalls and Wards Islands">Randalls Island</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-420"><a href="#cite_note-420">[418]</a></sup> There are three Bureau of Fire Communications alarm offices which receive and dispatch alarms to appropriate units. One office, at 11 Metrotech Center in Brooklyn, houses Manhattan/Citywide, Brooklyn, and Staten Island Fire Communications. The Bronx and Queens offices are in separate buildings.</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Culture_and_contemporary_life">Culture and contemporary life</span></h2>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_New_York_City" title="Culture of New York City">Culture of New York City</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_people_from_New_York_City" title="List of people from New York City">List of people from New York City</a></div>
<p>New York City has been described as the cultural capital of the world by the <a href="/wiki/Consul_(representative)" title="Consul (representative)">diplomatic consulates</a> of <a href="/wiki/Iceland" title="Iceland">Iceland</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cultura1_23-1"><a href="#cite_note-cultura1-23">[23]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Latvia" title="Latvia">Latvia</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-culture2_24-1"><a href="#cite_note-culture2-24">[24]</a></sup> and by New York's <a href="/wiki/Baruch_College" title="Baruch College">Baruch College</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-culture3_25-1"><a href="#cite_note-culture3-25">[25]</a></sup> A book containing a series of essays titled <i>New York, Culture Capital of the World, 1940–1965</i> has also been published as showcased by the <a href="/wiki/National_Library_of_Australia" title="National Library of Australia">National Library of Australia</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-culture4_26-1"><a href="#cite_note-culture4-26">[26]</a></sup> In describing New York, author <a href="/wiki/Tom_Wolfe" title="Tom Wolfe">Tom Wolfe</a> said, "Culture just seems to be in the air, like part of the weather."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-421"><a href="#cite_note-421">[419]</a></sup></p>
<p>Numerous major American cultural movements began in the city, such as the <a href="/wiki/Harlem_Renaissance" title="Harlem Renaissance">Harlem Renaissance</a>, which established the African-American literary canon in the United States.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-422"><a href="#cite_note-422">[420]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-423"><a href="#cite_note-423">[421]</a></sup> The city was a center of <a href="/wiki/Jazz" title="Jazz">jazz</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jazzzz_424-0"><a href="#cite_note-Jazzzz-424">[422]</a></sup> in the 1940s, <a href="/wiki/Abstract_expressionism" title="Abstract expressionism">abstract expressionism</a> in the 1950s, and the birthplace of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hip_hop_culture" title="Hip hop culture">hip hop</a> in the 1970s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BPOHPINY_425-0"><a href="#cite_note-BPOHPINY-425">[423]</a></sup> The city's <a href="/wiki/Punk_subculture" title="Punk subculture">punk</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-426"><a href="#cite_note-426">[424]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Hardcore_punk" title="Hardcore punk">hardcore</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-427"><a href="#cite_note-427">[425]</a></sup> scenes were influential in the 1970s and 1980s. New York has long had a flourishing scene for <a href="/wiki/Jewish_American_literature" title="Jewish American literature">Jewish American literature</a>.</p>
<p>The city is the birthplace of many cultural movements, including the <a href="/wiki/Harlem_Renaissance" title="Harlem Renaissance">Harlem Renaissance</a> in literature and visual art; <a href="/wiki/Abstract_expressionism" title="Abstract expressionism">abstract expressionism</a> (also known as the <a href="/wiki/New_York_School_(art)" title="New York School (art)">New York School</a>) in painting; and <a href="/wiki/Hip_hop_music" title="Hip hop music">hip hop</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto_197-1"><a href="#cite_note-auto-197">[197]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Punk_rock" title="Punk rock">punk</a>, <a href="/wiki/Salsa_music" title="Salsa music">salsa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Disco" title="Disco">disco</a>, <a href="/wiki/Freestyle_music" title="Freestyle music">freestyle</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tin_Pan_Alley" title="Tin Pan Alley">Tin Pan Alley</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Jazz" title="Jazz">jazz</a> in music. New York City has been considered the dance capital of the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-428"><a href="#cite_note-428">[426]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-429"><a href="#cite_note-429">[427]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-430"><a href="#cite_note-430">[428]</a></sup> The city is also frequently the setting for <a href="/wiki/Novel" title="Novel">novels</a>, movies (see <a href="/wiki/List_of_films_set_in_New_York_City" title="List of films set in New York City">List of films set in New York City</a>), and television programs. <a href="/wiki/New_York_Fashion_Week" title="New York Fashion Week">New York Fashion Week</a> is one of the world's preeminent fashion events and is afforded extensive coverage by the media.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-431"><a href="#cite_note-431">[429]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-432"><a href="#cite_note-432">[430]</a></sup> New York has also frequently been ranked the top <a href="/wiki/Fashion_capital" title="Fashion capital">fashion capital</a> of the world on the annual list compiled by the <a href="/wiki/Global_Language_Monitor" title="Global Language Monitor">Global Language Monitor</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-433"><a href="#cite_note-433">[431]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Arts">Arts</span></h3>
<p>New York City has more than 2,000 arts and cultural organizations and more than 500 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Art_gallery" title="Art gallery">art galleries</a> of all sizes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYC_arts_434-0"><a href="#cite_note-NYC_arts-434">[432]</a></sup> The city government funds the arts with a larger annual budget than the <a href="/wiki/National_Endowment_for_the_Arts" title="National Endowment for the Arts">National Endowment for the Arts</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYC_arts_434-1"><a href="#cite_note-NYC_arts-434">[432]</a></sup> Wealthy <a href="/wiki/Business_magnate" title="Business magnate">business magnates</a> in the 19th century built a network of major cultural institutions, such as the famed <a href="/wiki/Carnegie_Hall" title="Carnegie Hall">Carnegie Hall</a> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/The_Metropolitan_Museum_of_Art" title="The Metropolitan Museum of Art">Metropolitan Museum of Art</a>, that would become internationally established. The advent of electric lighting led to elaborate theater productions, and in the 1880s, New York City theaters on <a href="/wiki/Broadway_(Manhattan)" title="Broadway (Manhattan)">Broadway</a> and along 42nd Street began featuring a new stage form that became known as the <a href="/wiki/Musical_theatre" title="Musical theatre">Broadway musical</a>. Strongly influenced by the city's immigrants, productions such as those of <a href="/wiki/Edward_Harrigan" title="Edward Harrigan">Harrigan and Hart</a>, <a href="/wiki/George_M._Cohan" title="George M. Cohan">George M. Cohan</a>, and others used song in narratives that often reflected themes of hope and ambition.</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Performing_arts">Performing arts</span></h4>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Broadway_theatre" title="Broadway theatre">Broadway theatre</a> and <a href="/wiki/Music_of_New_York_City" title="Music of New York City">Music of New York City</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Lincoln_Center_Twilight.jpg"><img alt="The corner of a lit up plaza with a fountain in the center and the ends of two brightly lit buildings with tall arches on the square." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1501" data-file-width="2000" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Lincoln_Center_Twilight.jpg/220px-Lincoln_Center_Twilight.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Lincoln_Center_Twilight.jpg/330px-Lincoln_Center_Twilight.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Lincoln_Center_Twilight.jpg/440px-Lincoln_Center_Twilight.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Lincoln_Center_Twilight.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
<a href="/wiki/Lincoln_Center_for_the_Performing_Arts" title="Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts">Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts</a></div>
</div>
</div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Broadway_theatre" title="Broadway theatre">Broadway theatre</a> is one of the premier forms of English-language theatre in the world, named after <a href="/wiki/Broadway_(Manhattan)" title="Broadway (Manhattan)">Broadway</a>, the major thoroughfare that crosses <a href="/wiki/Times_Square" title="Times Square">Times Square</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-435"><a href="#cite_note-435">[433]</a></sup> also sometimes referred to as "<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/The_Great_White_Way" title="The Great White Way">The Great White Way</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-436"><a href="#cite_note-436">[434]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-437"><a href="#cite_note-437">[435]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-438"><a href="#cite_note-438">[436]</a></sup> Forty-one venues in Midtown Manhattan's <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Theatre_District,_Manhattan" title="Theatre District, Manhattan">Theatre District</a>, each with at least 500 seats, are classified as Broadway theatres. According to <a href="/wiki/The_Broadway_League" title="The Broadway League">The Broadway League</a>, Broadway shows sold approximately US$1.27 billion worth of tickets in the 2013–2014 season, an 11.4% increase from US$1.139 billion in the 2012–2013 season. Attendance in 2013–2014 stood at 12.21 million, representing a 5.5% increase from the 2012–2013 season's 11.57 million.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-league_439-0"><a href="#cite_note-league-439">[437]</a></sup> Performance artists displaying diverse skills are ubiquitous on the streets of Manhattan.</p>
<p><a href="/wiki/Lincoln_Center_for_the_Performing_Arts" title="Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts">Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts</a>, anchoring <a href="/wiki/Lincoln_Square,_Manhattan" title="Lincoln Square, Manhattan">Lincoln Square</a> on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, is home to numerous influential arts organizations, including the <a href="/wiki/Metropolitan_Opera" title="Metropolitan Opera">Metropolitan Opera</a>, <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Opera" title="New York City Opera">New York City Opera</a>, <a href="/wiki/New_York_Philharmonic" title="New York Philharmonic">New York Philharmonic</a>, and <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Ballet" title="New York City Ballet">New York City Ballet</a>, as well as the <a href="/wiki/Vivian_Beaumont_Theater" title="Vivian Beaumont Theater">Vivian Beaumont Theater</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Juilliard_School" title="Juilliard School">Juilliard School</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jazz_at_Lincoln_Center" title="Jazz at Lincoln Center">Jazz at Lincoln Center</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Alice_Tully_Hall" title="Alice Tully Hall">Alice Tully Hall</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Lee_Strasberg_Theatre_and_Film_Institute" title="Lee Strasberg Theatre and Film Institute">Lee Strasberg Theatre and Film Institute</a> is in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Union_Square_(New_York_City)" title="Union Square (New York City)">Union Square</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Tisch_School_of_the_Arts" title="Tisch School of the Arts">Tisch School of the Arts</a> is based at New York University, while <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Central_Park_SummerStage" title="Central Park SummerStage">Central Park SummerStage</a> presents free music concerts in Central Park.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-440"><a href="#cite_note-440">[438]</a></sup></p>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:MET_entrance.jpg"><img alt="A very ornate multi-story stone façade rises over steps and a plaza at night." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1200" data-file-width="1600" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/35/MET_entrance.jpg/220px-MET_entrance.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/35/MET_entrance.jpg/330px-MET_entrance.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/35/MET_entrance.jpg/440px-MET_entrance.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:MET_entrance.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/The_Metropolitan_Museum_of_Art" title="The Metropolitan Museum of Art">The Metropolitan Museum of Art</a>, part of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Museum_Mile,_New_York_City" title="Museum Mile, New York City">Museum Mile</a>, is one of the largest museums in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-441"><a href="#cite_note-441">[439]</a></sup></div>
</div>
</div>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Visual_arts">Visual arts</span></h4>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/List_of_museums_and_cultural_institutions_in_New_York_City" title="List of museums and cultural institutions in New York City">List of museums and cultural institutions in New York City</a></div>
<p>New York City is home to hundreds of cultural institutions and historic sites, many of which are internationally known. <a href="/wiki/Fifth_Avenue" title="Fifth Avenue">Museum Mile</a> is the name for a section of Fifth Avenue running from 82nd to 105th streets on the <a href="/wiki/Upper_East_Side" title="Upper East Side">Upper East Side</a> of Manhattan,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-festival_442-0"><a href="#cite_note-festival-442">[440]</a></sup> in an area sometimes called Upper <a href="/wiki/Carnegie_Hill" title="Carnegie Hill">Carnegie Hill</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-443"><a href="#cite_note-443">[441]</a></sup> The Mile, which contains one of the densest displays of <a href="/wiki/Culture" title="Culture">culture</a> in the world, is actually three blocks longer than one mile (1.6 km). Ten museums occupy the length of this section of Fifth Avenue.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mmilemus_444-0"><a href="#cite_note-mmilemus-444">[442]</a></sup> The tenth museum, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Museum_for_African_Art" title="Museum for African Art">Museum for African Art</a>, joined the ensemble in 2009, although its museum at <a href="/wiki/110th_Street_(Manhattan)" title="110th Street (Manhattan)">110th Street</a>, the first new museum constructed on the Mile since the <a href="/wiki/Solomon_R._Guggenheim_Museum" title="Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum">Guggenheim</a> in 1959,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mafr_445-0"><a href="#cite_note-mafr-445">[443]</a></sup> opened in late 2012. In addition to other programming, the museums collaborate for the annual Museum Mile Festival, held each year in June, to promote the museums and increase visitation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-drv_446-0"><a href="#cite_note-drv-446">[444]</a></sup> Many of the world's most lucrative <a href="/wiki/Art_auction" title="Art auction">art auctions</a> are held in New York City.</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cuisine">Cuisine</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Cuisine_of_New_York_City" title="Cuisine of New York City">Cuisine of New York City</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Smorgasburg_in_Dumbo.jpg"><img alt="People crowd around white tents in the foreground next to a red brick wall with arched windows. Above and to the left is a towering stone bridge." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1594" data-file-width="2400" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Smorgasburg_in_Dumbo.jpg/220px-Smorgasburg_in_Dumbo.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Smorgasburg_in_Dumbo.jpg/330px-Smorgasburg_in_Dumbo.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Smorgasburg_in_Dumbo.jpg/440px-Smorgasburg_in_Dumbo.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Smorgasburg_in_Dumbo.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
Smorgasburg opened in 2011 as an open-air food market and is part of the <a href="/wiki/Brooklyn_Flea" title="Brooklyn Flea">Brooklyn Flea</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-447"><a href="#cite_note-447">[445]</a></sup></div>
</div>
</div>
<p>New York City's food culture includes an array of international cuisines influenced by the city's immigrant history. <a href="/wiki/Central_Europe" title="Central Europe">Central European</a> and <a href="/wiki/Italian_diaspora" title="Italian diaspora">Italian</a> immigrants brought <a href="/wiki/Bagel" title="Bagel">bagels</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cheesecake#North_America" title="Cheesecake">cheesecake</a>, and <a href="/wiki/New_York-style_pizza" title="New York-style pizza">New York-style pizza</a> into the city, while <a href="/wiki/Chinese_restaurant" title="Chinese restaurant">Chinese</a> and other Asian restaurants, <a href="/wiki/Sandwich" title="Sandwich">sandwich</a> joints, <a href="/wiki/Trattoria" title="Trattoria">trattorias</a>, <a href="/wiki/Diner" title="Diner">diners</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Coffeehouse" title="Coffeehouse">coffeehouses</a> have become ubiquitous. Some 4,000 mobile food vendors licensed by the city, many immigrant-owned, have made <a href="/wiki/Middle_East" title="Middle East">Middle Eastern</a> foods such as <a href="/wiki/Falafel" title="Falafel">falafel</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kebab" title="Kebab">kebabs</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-448"><a href="#cite_note-448">[446]</a></sup> examples of modern New York <a href="/wiki/Street_food" title="Street food">street food</a>. The city is home to "nearly one thousand of the finest and most diverse <a href="/wiki/Haute_cuisine" title="Haute cuisine">haute cuisine</a> restaurants in the world", according to <a href="/wiki/Michelin" title="Michelin">Michelin</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-449"><a href="#cite_note-449">[447]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Department_of_Health_and_Mental_Hygiene" title="New York City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene">New York City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene</a> assigns letter grades to the city's 24,000 restaurants based upon their inspection results.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-450"><a href="#cite_note-450">[448]</a></sup></p>
<div class="thumb tmulti tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:362px;max-width:362px">
<div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:175px;max-width:175px">

</div>

</div>
<div style="clear:left"></div>
<div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:175px;max-width:175px">
<div class="thumbimage" style="height:115px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Apollo_11_ticker_tape_parade_2.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="3895" data-file-width="5796" height="116" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Apollo_11_ticker_tape_parade_2.jpg/173px-Apollo_11_ticker_tape_parade_2.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Apollo_11_ticker_tape_parade_2.jpg/260px-Apollo_11_ticker_tape_parade_2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Apollo_11_ticker_tape_parade_2.jpg/346px-Apollo_11_ticker_tape_parade_2.jpg 2x" width="173"/></a></div>
</div>
<div class="tsingle" style="float:left;margin:1px;width:183px;max-width:183px">
<div class="thumbimage" style="height:115px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Pinoydayparade2.JPG"><img alt="" data-file-height="1944" data-file-width="2592" height="136" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/0/0d/Pinoydayparade2.JPG/181px-Pinoydayparade2.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/0/0d/Pinoydayparade2.JPG/272px-Pinoydayparade2.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/0/0d/Pinoydayparade2.JPG/362px-Pinoydayparade2.JPG 2x" width="181"/></a></div>
</div>
<div style="clear:left"></div>
<div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left;text-align:left;background-color:transparent">Clockwise, from upper left: the annual <a href="/wiki/Macy%27s_Thanksgiving_Day_Parade" title="Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade">Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade</a>, the world's largest parade;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYCThanksgivingParade_451-0"><a href="#cite_note-NYCThanksgivingParade-451">[449]</a></sup> the annual <a href="/wiki/New_York%27s_Village_Halloween_Parade" title="New York's Village Halloween Parade">Halloween Parade</a> in <a href="/wiki/Greenwich_Village" title="Greenwich Village">Greenwich Village</a>; the annual <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Filipinos_in_the_New_York_City_metropolitan_region" title="Filipinos in the New York City metropolitan region">Philippine</a> <a href="/wiki/Philippine_Independence_Day_Parade" title="Philippine Independence Day Parade">Independence Day Parade</a>; and the <a href="/wiki/List_of_ticker-tape_parades_in_New_York_City" title="List of ticker-tape parades in New York City">ticker-tape parade</a> for the <a href="/wiki/Apollo_11" title="Apollo 11">Apollo 11</a> <a href="/wiki/Astronaut" title="Astronaut">astronauts</a></div>
</div>
</div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Parades">Parades</span></h3>
<p>New York City is well known for its street <a href="/wiki/Parade" title="Parade">parades</a>, which celebrate a broad array of themes, including holidays, nationalities, human rights, and major league sports team championship victories. The majority of parades are held in Manhattan. The primary orientation of the annual street parades is typically from north to south, marching along major avenues. The annual <a href="/wiki/Macy%27s_Thanksgiving_Day_Parade" title="Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade">Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade</a> is the world's largest parade,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYCThanksgivingParade_451-1"><a href="#cite_note-NYCThanksgivingParade-451">[449]</a></sup> beginning alongside <a href="/wiki/Central_Park" title="Central Park">Central Park</a> and processing southward to the flagship <a href="/wiki/Macy%27s_Herald_Square" title="Macy's Herald Square">Macy's Herald Square</a> store;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-452"><a href="#cite_note-452">[450]</a></sup> the parade is viewed on telecasts worldwide and draws millions of spectators in person.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYCThanksgivingParade_451-2"><a href="#cite_note-NYCThanksgivingParade-451">[449]</a></sup> Other notable parades including the annual <a href="/wiki/Saint_Patrick%27s_Day_in_the_United_States#New_York_City" title="Saint Patrick's Day in the United States">St. Patrick's Day Parade</a> in March, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/LGBT_Pride_March_(New_York_City)" title="LGBT Pride March (New York City)">LGBT Pride March</a> in June, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Greenwich_Village_Halloween_Parade" title="Greenwich Village Halloween Parade">Greenwich Village Halloween Parade</a> in October, and numerous parades commemorating the independence days of many nations. <a href="/wiki/List_of_ticker-tape_parades_in_New_York_City" title="List of ticker-tape parades in New York City">Ticker-tape parades</a> celebrating championships won by sports teams as well as other heroic accomplishments march northward along the <a href="/wiki/Broadway_(Manhattan)#Canyon_of_Heroes" title="Broadway (Manhattan)">Canyon of Heroes</a> on <a href="/wiki/Broadway_(Manhattan)" title="Broadway (Manhattan)">Broadway</a> from <a href="/wiki/Bowling_Green_(New_York_City)" title="Bowling Green (New York City)">Bowling Green</a> to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/City_Hall_Park" title="City Hall Park">City Hall Park</a> in Lower Manhattan.</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Accent_and_dialect">Accent and dialect</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_English" title="New York City English">New York City English</a></div>
<p>The New York area has historically been home to a distinctive regional speech pattern called the <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_English" title="New York City English">New York dialect</a>, alternatively known as <i>Brooklynese</i> or <i>New Yorkese</i>. It has generally been considered one of the most recognizable accents within <a href="/wiki/American_English" title="American English">American English</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-453"><a href="#cite_note-453">[451]</a></sup> The classic version of this dialect is centered on middle and working-class people of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/European_American" title="European American">European</a> descent. The influx of non-European immigrants in recent decades has led to changes in this distinctive dialect,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYT19930214_454-0"><a href="#cite_note-NYT19930214-454">[452]</a></sup> and the traditional form of this speech pattern is no longer as prevalent among general New Yorkers as in the past.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYT19930214_454-1"><a href="#cite_note-NYT19930214-454">[452]</a></sup></p>
<p>The traditional New York area accent is characterized as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rhotic_and_non-rhotic_accents" title="Rhotic and non-rhotic accents">non-rhotic</a>, so that the sound <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[ɹ]</span> does not appear at the end of a <a href="/wiki/Syllable" title="Syllable">syllable</a> or immediately before a <a href="/wiki/Consonant" title="Consonant">consonant</a>; hence the pronunciation of the city name as "New Yawk."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYT19930214_454-2"><a href="#cite_note-NYT19930214-454">[452]</a></sup> There is no <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[ɹ]</span> in words like <i>park</i> <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[pɑək]</span> or <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[pɒək]</span> (with vowel backed and <a href="/wiki/Vowel_breaking" title="Vowel breaking">diphthongized</a> due to the low-back chain shift), <i>butter</i> <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[bʌɾə]</span>, or <i>here</i> <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[hiə]</span>. In another feature called the low back chain shift, the <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[ɔ]</span> vowel sound of words like <i>talk</i>, <i>law</i>, <i>cross</i>, <i>chocolate</i>, and <i>coffee</i> and the often <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Homophonous" title="Homophonous">homophonous</a> <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[ɔr]</span> in <i>core</i> and <i>more</i> are tensed and usually raised more than in <a href="/wiki/General_American" title="General American">General American</a>. In the most old-fashioned and extreme versions of the New York dialect, the vowel sounds of words like "girl" and of words like "oil" became a diphthong <span class="IPA" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[ɜɪ]</span>. This would often be misperceived by speakers of other accents as a reversal of the <i>er</i> and <i>oy</i> sounds, so that <i>girl</i> is pronounced "goil" and <i>oil</i> is pronounced "erl"; this leads to the caricature of New Yorkers saying things like "Joizey" (Jersey), "Toidy-Toid Street" (33rd St.) and "terlet" (toilet).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYT19930214_454-3"><a href="#cite_note-NYT19930214-454">[452]</a></sup> The character <a href="/wiki/Archie_Bunker" title="Archie Bunker">Archie Bunker</a> from the 1970s sitcom <i><a href="/wiki/All_in_the_Family" title="All in the Family">All in the Family</a></i> (played by <a href="/wiki/Carroll_O%27Connor" title="Carroll O'Connor">Carroll O'Connor</a>) was an example of having used this pattern of speech, which continues to fade in its overall presence.</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sports">Sports</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tmulti tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:229px;max-width:229px">
<div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:227px;max-width:227px">
<div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:New_York_City_Marathon_2014_(15082977714).jpg"><img alt="Three runners in a race down a street where onlookers are cheering behind barriers." data-file-height="1118" data-file-width="1680" height="150" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/New_York_City_Marathon_2014_%2815082977714%29.jpg/225px-New_York_City_Marathon_2014_%2815082977714%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/New_York_City_Marathon_2014_%2815082977714%29.jpg/338px-New_York_City_Marathon_2014_%2815082977714%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/New_York_City_Marathon_2014_%2815082977714%29.jpg/450px-New_York_City_Marathon_2014_%2815082977714%29.jpg 2x" width="225"/></a></div>
<div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">The <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Marathon" title="New York City Marathon">New York Marathon</a> is the largest marathon in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYCMarathonWorld.27sLargest_455-0"><a href="#cite_note-NYCMarathonWorld.27sLargest-455">[453]</a></sup></div>
</div>
<div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:227px;max-width:227px">
<div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Arthur_ashe_stadium_interior.jpg"><img alt="A tennis stadium pack with fans watching a grass court." data-file-height="960" data-file-width="1280" height="169" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Arthur_ashe_stadium_interior.jpg/225px-Arthur_ashe_stadium_interior.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Arthur_ashe_stadium_interior.jpg/338px-Arthur_ashe_stadium_interior.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Arthur_ashe_stadium_interior.jpg/450px-Arthur_ashe_stadium_interior.jpg 2x" width="225"/></a></div>
<div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/U.S._Open_(tennis)" title="U.S. Open (tennis)">US Open Tennis Championships</a> are held every August and September in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Flushing_Meadows-Corona_Park" title="Flushing Meadows-Corona Park">Flushing Meadows-Corona Park</a>, Queens.</div>
</div>
<div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:227px;max-width:227px">
<div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Citi_Field_2011.JPG"><img alt="A baseball stadium from behind home plate in the evening." data-file-height="2647" data-file-width="3529" height="169" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/Citi_Field_2011.JPG/225px-Citi_Field_2011.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/Citi_Field_2011.JPG/338px-Citi_Field_2011.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/Citi_Field_2011.JPG/450px-Citi_Field_2011.JPG 2x" width="225"/></a></div>
<div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left"><a href="/wiki/Citi_Field" title="Citi Field">Citi Field</a>, also in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, has been home to the <a href="/wiki/New_York_Mets" title="New York Mets">New York Mets</a> since 2009.</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Sports_in_New_York_City" title="Sports in New York City">Sports in New York City</a></div>
<p>New York City is home to the <a href="/wiki/Headquarters" title="Headquarters">headquarters</a> of the <a href="/wiki/National_Football_League" title="National Football League">National Football League</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-456"><a href="#cite_note-456">[454]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Major_League_Baseball" title="Major League Baseball">Major League Baseball</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-457"><a href="#cite_note-457">[455]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/National_Basketball_Association" title="National Basketball Association">National Basketball Association</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-458"><a href="#cite_note-458">[456]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/National_Hockey_League" title="National Hockey League">National Hockey League</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-459"><a href="#cite_note-459">[457]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Major_League_Soccer" title="Major League Soccer">Major League Soccer</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-460"><a href="#cite_note-460">[458]</a></sup> The New York metropolitan area hosts the <a href="/wiki/List_of_American_and_Canadian_cities_by_number_of_major_professional_sports_franchises" title="List of American and Canadian cities by number of major professional sports franchises">most</a> sports teams in these five professional leagues. Participation in professional sports in the city predates all professional leagues, and the city has been continuously hosting professional sports since the birth of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Brooklyn_Dodgers" title="Brooklyn Dodgers">Brooklyn Dodgers</a> in 1882. The city has played host to over forty major professional teams in the five sports and their respective competing leagues, both current and historic. Four of the ten most expensive <a href="/wiki/Stadium" title="Stadium">stadiums</a> ever built worldwide (<a href="/wiki/MetLife_Stadium" title="MetLife Stadium">MetLife Stadium</a>, the new <a href="/wiki/Yankee_Stadium" title="Yankee Stadium">Yankee Stadium</a>, <a href="/wiki/Madison_Square_Garden" title="Madison Square Garden">Madison Square Garden</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Citi_Field" title="Citi Field">Citi Field</a>) are located in the New York metropolitan area.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-461"><a href="#cite_note-461">[459]</a></sup> Madison Square Garden, <a href="/wiki/Madison_Square_Garden_(1925)" title="Madison Square Garden (1925)">its predecessor</a>, <a href="/wiki/Yankee_Stadium_(1923)" title="Yankee Stadium (1923)">the original Yankee Stadium</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ebbets_Field" title="Ebbets Field">Ebbets Field</a>, are sporting venues located in New York City, the latter two having been commemorated on <a href="/wiki/Postage_stamps_and_postal_history_of_the_United_States" title="Postage stamps and postal history of the United States">U.S. postage stamps</a>.</p>
<p>New York has been described as the "Capital of Baseball".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-462"><a href="#cite_note-462">[460]</a></sup> There have been 35 Major League Baseball <a href="/wiki/World_Series" title="World Series">World Series</a> and 73 <a href="/wiki/Pennant_(sports)#Pennants_as_trophies" title="Pennant (sports)">pennants</a> won by New York teams. It is one of only five metro areas (<a href="/wiki/Los_Angeles_metropolitan_area" title="Los Angeles metropolitan area">Los Angeles</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chicago_metropolitan_area" title="Chicago metropolitan area">Chicago</a>, <a href="/wiki/Baltimore%E2%80%93Washington_metropolitan_area" title="Baltimore–Washington metropolitan area">Baltimore–Washington</a>, and the San Francisco Bay Area being the others) to have two baseball teams. Additionally, there have been 14 World Series in which two New York City teams played each other, known as a <a href="/wiki/Subway_Series" title="Subway Series">Subway Series</a> and occurring most recently in <a href="/wiki/2000_World_Series" title="2000 World Series">2000</a>. No other metropolitan area has had this happen more than once (Chicago in <a href="/wiki/1906_World_Series" title="1906 World Series">1906</a>, St. Louis in <a href="/wiki/1944_World_Series" title="1944 World Series">1944</a>, and the San Francisco Bay Area in <a href="/wiki/1989_World_Series" title="1989 World Series">1989</a>). The city's two current Major League Baseball teams are the <a href="/wiki/New_York_Mets" title="New York Mets">New York Mets</a>, who play at <a href="/wiki/Citi_Field" title="Citi Field">Citi Field</a> in Queens,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-463"><a href="#cite_note-463">[461]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/New_York_Yankees" title="New York Yankees">New York Yankees</a>, who play at <a href="/wiki/Yankee_Stadium" title="Yankee Stadium">Yankee Stadium</a> in the Bronx.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-464"><a href="#cite_note-464">[462]</a></sup> who compete in six games of <a href="/wiki/Interleague_play" title="Interleague play">interleague play</a> every regular season that has also come to be called the <a href="/wiki/Subway_Series" title="Subway Series">Subway Series</a>. The Yankees have won a record 27 championships,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-465"><a href="#cite_note-465">[463]</a></sup> while the Mets have won the World Series twice.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-466"><a href="#cite_note-466">[464]</a></sup> The city also was once home to the Brooklyn Dodgers (now the <a href="/wiki/Los_Angeles_Dodgers" title="Los Angeles Dodgers">Los Angeles Dodgers</a>), who won the World Series once,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-467"><a href="#cite_note-467">[465]</a></sup> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/New_York_Giants_(NL)" title="New York Giants (NL)">New York Giants</a> (now the <a href="/wiki/San_Francisco_Giants" title="San Francisco Giants">San Francisco Giants</a>), who won the World Series five times.
