Both teams moved to California in 1958.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-468"><a href="#cite_note-468">[466]</a></sup> There are also two <a href="/wiki/Minor_League_Baseball" title="Minor League Baseball">Minor League Baseball</a> teams in the city, the <a href="/wiki/Brooklyn_Cyclones" title="Brooklyn Cyclones">Brooklyn Cyclones</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-469"><a href="#cite_note-469">[467]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Staten_Island_Yankees" title="Staten Island Yankees">Staten Island Yankees</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-470"><a href="#cite_note-470">[468]</a></sup></p>
<p>The city is represented in the National Football League by the <a href="/wiki/New_York_Giants" title="New York Giants">New York Giants</a> and the <a href="/wiki/New_York_Jets" title="New York Jets">New York Jets</a>, although both teams play their home games at MetLife Stadium in nearby <a href="/wiki/East_Rutherford,_New_Jersey" title="East Rutherford, New Jersey">East Rutherford, New Jersey</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-471"><a href="#cite_note-471">[469]</a></sup> which hosted <a href="/wiki/Super_Bowl_XLVIII" title="Super Bowl XLVIII">Super Bowl XLVIII</a> in 2014.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-472"><a href="#cite_note-472">[470]</a></sup></p>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/New_York_Islanders" title="New York Islanders">New York Islanders</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-473"><a href="#cite_note-473">[471]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/New_York_Rangers" title="New York Rangers">New York Rangers</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-474"><a href="#cite_note-474">[472]</a></sup> represent the city in the <a href="/wiki/National_Hockey_League" title="National Hockey League">National Hockey League</a>. Also within the metropolitan area are the <a href="/wiki/New_Jersey_Devils" title="New Jersey Devils">New Jersey Devils</a>, who play in nearby <a href="/wiki/Newark,_New_Jersey" title="Newark, New Jersey">Newark, New Jersey</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-475"><a href="#cite_note-475">[473]</a></sup></p>
<p>The city's National Basketball Association teams are the <a href="/wiki/Brooklyn_Nets" title="Brooklyn Nets">Brooklyn Nets</a> and the <a href="/wiki/New_York_Knicks" title="New York Knicks">New York Knicks</a>, while the <a href="/wiki/New_York_Liberty" title="New York Liberty">New York Liberty</a> is the city's <a href="/wiki/Women%27s_National_Basketball_Association" title="Women's National Basketball Association">Women's National Basketball Association</a>. The first national college-level basketball championship, the <a href="/wiki/National_Invitation_Tournament" title="National Invitation Tournament">National Invitation Tournament</a>, was held in New York in 1938 and remains in the city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-476"><a href="#cite_note-476">[474]</a></sup> The city is well known for its links to basketball, which is played in nearly every park in the city by local youth, many of whom have gone on to play for major college programs and in the NBA.</p>
<p>In soccer, New York City is represented by <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_FC" title="New York City FC">New York City FC</a> of Major League Soccer, who play their home games at Yankee Stadium.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-477"><a href="#cite_note-477">[475]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/New_York_Red_Bulls" title="New York Red Bulls">New York Red Bulls</a> play their home games at <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Red_Bull_Arena_(Harrison)" title="Red Bull Arena (Harrison)">Red Bull Arena</a> in nearby <a href="/wiki/Harrison,_New_Jersey" title="Harrison, New Jersey">Harrison, New Jersey</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-478"><a href="#cite_note-478">[476]</a></sup> Historically, the city is known for the <a href="/wiki/New_York_Cosmos_(1970%E2%80%9385)" title="New York Cosmos (1970–85)">New York Cosmos</a>, the highly successful former professional soccer team which was the American home of <a href="/wiki/Pel%C3%A9" title="Pelé">Pelé</a>. A new version of the <a href="/wiki/New_York_Cosmos_(2010)" title="New York Cosmos (2010)">New York Cosmos</a> was formed in 2010, and began play in the second division <a href="/wiki/North_American_Soccer_League" title="North American Soccer League">North American Soccer League</a> in 2013. The Cosmos play their home games at <a href="/wiki/James_M._Shuart_Stadium" title="James M. Shuart Stadium">James M. Shuart Stadium</a> on the campus of <a href="/wiki/Hofstra_University" title="Hofstra University">Hofstra University</a>, just outside the New York City limits in <a href="/wiki/Hempstead_(village),_New_York" title="Hempstead (village), New York">Hempstead, New York</a>.</p>
<p>The annual <a href="/wiki/US_Open_(tennis)" title="US Open (tennis)">United States Open Tennis Championships</a> is one of the world's four <a href="/wiki/Grand_Slam_(tennis)" title="Grand Slam (tennis)">Grand Slam</a> tennis tournaments and is held at the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/USTA_National_Tennis_Center" title="USTA National Tennis Center">National Tennis Center</a> in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Flushing_Meadows-Corona_Park" title="Flushing Meadows-Corona Park">Flushing Meadows-Corona Park</a>, Queens.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-479"><a href="#cite_note-479">[477]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Marathon" title="New York City Marathon">New York City Marathon</a>, which courses through all five boroughs, is the world's largest running marathon,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYCMarathonWorld.27sLargest_455-1"><a href="#cite_note-NYCMarathonWorld.27sLargest-455">[453]</a></sup> with 51,394 finishers in 2016<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-480"><a href="#cite_note-480">[478]</a></sup> and 98,247 applicants for the 2017 race.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYCMarathonWorld.27sLargest_455-2"><a href="#cite_note-NYCMarathonWorld.27sLargest-455">[453]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Millrose_Games" title="Millrose Games">Millrose Games</a> is an annual <a href="/wiki/Track_and_field" title="Track and field">track and field</a> meet whose featured event is the <a href="/wiki/Wanamaker_Mile" title="Wanamaker Mile">Wanamaker Mile</a>. Boxing is also a prominent part of the city's sporting scene, with events like the Amateur Boxing Golden Gloves being held at <a href="/wiki/Madison_Square_Garden" title="Madison Square Garden">Madison Square Garden</a> each year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-481"><a href="#cite_note-481">[479]</a></sup> The city is also considered the host of the <a href="/wiki/Belmont_Stakes" title="Belmont Stakes">Belmont Stakes</a>, the last, longest and oldest of horse racing's <a href="/wiki/Triple_Crown_of_Thoroughbred_Racing_(United_States)" title="Triple Crown of Thoroughbred Racing (United States)">Triple Crown races</a>, held just over the city's border at <a href="/wiki/Belmont_Park" title="Belmont Park">Belmont Park</a> on the first or second Sunday of June. The city also hosted the <a href="/wiki/1932_U.S._Open_(golf)" title="1932 U.S. Open (golf)">1932 U.S. Open</a> golf tournament and the <a href="/wiki/1930_PGA_Championship" title="1930 PGA Championship">1930</a> and <a href="/wiki/1939_PGA_Championship" title="1939 PGA Championship">1939</a> PGA Championships, and has been host city for both events several times, most notably for nearby <a href="/wiki/Winged_Foot_Golf_Club" title="Winged Foot Golf Club">Winged Foot Golf Club</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Gaelic_games_in_North_America" title="Gaelic games in North America">Gaelic games</a> are played in <a href="/wiki/Riverdale,_Bronx" title="Riverdale, Bronx">Riverdale, Bronx</a> at <a href="/wiki/Gaelic_Park" title="Gaelic Park">Gaelic Park</a>, home to the <a href="/wiki/New_York_GAA" title="New York GAA">New York GAA</a>, the only North American team to compete at the senior <a href="/wiki/Gaelic_Athletic_Association_county" title="Gaelic Athletic Association county">inter-county</a> level.</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Transportation">Transportation</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tleft">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Image-Grand_central_Station_Outside_Night_2.jpg"><img alt="A row of yellow taxis in front of a multi-story ornate stone building with three huge arched windows." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3805" data-file-width="4726" height="177" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/Image-Grand_central_Station_Outside_Night_2.jpg/220px-Image-Grand_central_Station_Outside_Night_2.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/Image-Grand_central_Station_Outside_Night_2.jpg/330px-Image-Grand_central_Station_Outside_Night_2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/Image-Grand_central_Station_Outside_Night_2.jpg/440px-Image-Grand_central_Station_Outside_Night_2.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Image-Grand_central_Station_Outside_Night_2.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
New York City is home to the two busiest <a href="/wiki/Train_station" title="Train station">rail stations</a> in the US, including <a href="/wiki/Grand_Central_Terminal" title="Grand Central Terminal">Grand Central Terminal</a>.</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Transportation_in_New_York_City" title="Transportation in New York City">Transportation in New York City</a></div>
<p>New York City's comprehensive transportation system is both complex and extensive.</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Rapid_transit">Rapid transit</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mass_transit_in_New_York_City" title="Mass transit in New York City">Mass transit in New York City</a></div>
<p>Mass transit in New York City, most of which runs 24 hours a day, accounts for one in every three users of mass transit in the United States, and two-thirds of the nation's rail riders live in the New York City Metropolitan Area.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MTAinfo_482-0"><a href="#cite_note-MTAinfo-482">[480]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-483"><a href="#cite_note-483">[481]</a></sup></p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Rail">Rail</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:NYC_Subway_R160A_9237_on_the_E.jpg"><img alt="The back end of a subway train, with a red E on a LED display on the top. To the left of the train is a platform with a person walking away." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="768" data-file-width="1024" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/NYC_Subway_R160A_9237_on_the_E.jpg/220px-NYC_Subway_R160A_9237_on_the_E.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/NYC_Subway_R160A_9237_on_the_E.jpg/330px-NYC_Subway_R160A_9237_on_the_E.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/NYC_Subway_R160A_9237_on_the_E.jpg/440px-NYC_Subway_R160A_9237_on_the_E.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:NYC_Subway_R160A_9237_on_the_E.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
The <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Subway" title="New York City Subway">New York City Subway</a> is the world's largest <a href="/wiki/Rapid_transit" title="Rapid transit">rapid transit</a> system by length of routes and by number of <a href="/wiki/Train_station" title="Train station">stations</a>.</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>The iconic <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Subway" title="New York City Subway">New York City Subway</a> system is the largest <a href="/wiki/Rapid_transit" title="Rapid transit">rapid transit</a> system in the world when measured by stations in operation, with 472, and by length of routes. Nearly all of New York's subway system is open 24 hours a day, in contrast to the overnight shutdown common to systems in most cities, including <a href="/wiki/MTR" title="MTR">Hong Kong</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-484"><a href="#cite_note-484">[482]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-485"><a href="#cite_note-485">[483]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/London_Underground" title="London Underground">London</a>, <a href="/wiki/Paris_M%C3%A9tro" title="Paris Métro">Paris</a>, <a href="/wiki/Seoul_Metropolitan_Subway" title="Seoul Metropolitan Subway">Seoul</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-486"><a href="#cite_note-486">[484]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-487"><a href="#cite_note-487">[485]</a></sup> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tokyo_Subway" title="Tokyo Subway">Tokyo</a>. The New York City Subway is also <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Metro_systems_by_annual_passenger_rides" title="Metro systems by annual passenger rides">the busiest metropolitan rail transit system in the Western Hemisphere</a>, with 1.76 billion passenger rides in 2015,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-488"><a href="#cite_note-488">[486]</a></sup> while <a href="/wiki/Grand_Central_Terminal" title="Grand Central Terminal">Grand Central Terminal</a>, also referred to as "Grand Central Station", is the world's largest <a href="/wiki/Train_station" title="Train station">railway station</a> by number of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Train_platform" title="Train platform">train platforms</a>.</p>
<p><a href="/wiki/Public_transport" title="Public transport">Public transport</a> is essential in New York City. 54.6% of New Yorkers commuted to work in 2005 using mass transit.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-489"><a href="#cite_note-489">[487]</a></sup> This is in contrast to the rest of the United States, where about 90% of commuters drive automobiles to their workplace.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2001summary_490-0"><a href="#cite_note-2001summary-490">[488]</a></sup> According to the <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Comptroller" title="New York City Comptroller">New York City Comptroller</a>, workers in the New York City area spend an average of 6 hours and 18 minutes getting to work each week, the longest commute time in the nation among large cities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-491"><a href="#cite_note-491">[489]</a></sup> New York is the only US city in which a majority (52%) of households do not have a car; only 22% of Manhattanites own a car.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-492"><a href="#cite_note-492">[490]</a></sup> Due to their <a href="/wiki/List_of_U.S._cities_with_high_transit_ridership" title="List of U.S. cities with high transit ridership">high usage of mass transit</a>, New Yorkers spend less of their household income on transportation than the national average, saving $19 billion annually on transportation compared to other urban Americans.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-493"><a href="#cite_note-493">[491]</a></sup></p>
<p>New York City's <a href="/wiki/Commuter_rail" title="Commuter rail">commuter rail</a> network is the largest in North America.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MTAinfo_482-1"><a href="#cite_note-MTAinfo-482">[480]</a></sup> The rail network, connecting New York City to its <a href="/wiki/Suburb" title="Suburb">suburbs</a>, consists of the <a href="/wiki/Long_Island_Rail_Road" title="Long Island Rail Road">Long Island Rail Road</a>, <a href="/wiki/Metro-North_Railroad" title="Metro-North Railroad">Metro-North Railroad</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/New_Jersey_Transit_rail_operations" title="New Jersey Transit rail operations">New Jersey Transit</a>. The combined systems converge at Grand Central Terminal and <a href="/wiki/Pennsylvania_Station_(New_York_City)" title="Pennsylvania Station (New York City)">Pennsylvania Station</a> and contain more than 250 stations and 20 rail lines.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MTAinfo_482-2"><a href="#cite_note-MTAinfo-482">[480]</a></sup> In Queens, the elevated <a href="/wiki/AirTrain_JFK" title="AirTrain JFK">AirTrain</a> <a href="/wiki/People_mover" title="People mover">people mover</a> system connects <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/JFK_International_Airport" title="JFK International Airport">JFK International Airport</a> to the New York City Subway and the Long Island Rail Road; a separate AirTrain system is planned alongside the <a href="/wiki/Grand_Central_Parkway" title="Grand Central Parkway">Grand Central Parkway</a> to connect <a href="/wiki/LaGuardia_Airport" title="LaGuardia Airport">LaGuardia Airport</a> to these transit systems.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-494"><a href="#cite_note-494">[492]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-495"><a href="#cite_note-495">[493]</a></sup> For <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Intercity_rail" title="Intercity rail">intercity rail</a>, New York City is served by <a href="/wiki/Amtrak" title="Amtrak">Amtrak</a>, whose busiest station by a significant margin is Pennsylvania Station on the <a href="/wiki/West_Side_(Manhattan)" title="West Side (Manhattan)">West Side</a> of Manhattan, from which Amtrak provides connections to <a href="/wiki/Boston" title="Boston">Boston</a>, <a href="/wiki/Philadelphia" title="Philadelphia">Philadelphia</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Washington,_D.C." title="Washington, D.C.">Washington, D.C.</a> along the <a href="/wiki/Northeast_Corridor" title="Northeast Corridor">Northeast Corridor</a>, and long-distance train service to other North American cities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-496"><a href="#cite_note-496">[494]</a></sup></p>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Staten_Island_Railway" title="Staten Island Railway">Staten Island Railway</a> rapid transit system solely serves Staten Island, operating 24 hours a day. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Port_Authority_Trans-Hudson" title="Port Authority Trans-Hudson">Port Authority Trans-Hudson</a> (PATH train) links Midtown and Lower Manhattan to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Northeastern_New_Jersey" title="Northeastern New Jersey">northeastern New Jersey</a>, primarily <a href="/wiki/Hoboken,_New_Jersey" title="Hoboken, New Jersey">Hoboken</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jersey_City,_New_Jersey" title="Jersey City, New Jersey">Jersey City</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Newark,_New_Jersey" title="Newark, New Jersey">Newark</a>. Like the New York City Subway, the PATH operates 24 hours a day; meaning three of the six rapid transit systems in the world which operate on 24-hour schedules are wholly or partly in New York (the others are a portion of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chicago_%27L%27" title="Chicago 'L'">Chicago 'L'</a>, the <a href="/wiki/PATCO_Speedline" title="PATCO Speedline">PATCO Speedline</a> serving Philadelphia, and the <a href="/wiki/Copenhagen_Metro" title="Copenhagen Metro">Copenhagen Metro</a>).</p>
<p>Multibillion-dollar <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Heavy_rail" title="Heavy rail">heavy rail</a> transit projects under construction in New York City include the <a href="/wiki/Second_Avenue_Subway" title="Second Avenue Subway">Second Avenue Subway</a>, the <a href="/wiki/East_Side_Access" title="East Side Access">East Side Access</a> project, and the <a href="/wiki/7_Subway_Extension" title="7 Subway Extension">7 Subway Extension</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-497"><a href="#cite_note-497">[495]</a></sup></p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Buses">Buses</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Port-authority-terminal.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1297" data-file-width="2173" height="131" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Port-authority-terminal.jpg/220px-Port-authority-terminal.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Port-authority-terminal.jpg/330px-Port-authority-terminal.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Port-authority-terminal.jpg/440px-Port-authority-terminal.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Port-authority-terminal.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
The <a href="/wiki/Port_Authority_Bus_Terminal" title="Port Authority Bus Terminal">Port Authority Bus Terminal</a>, the world's busiest bus station, at <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/8th_Avenue_(Manhattan)" title="8th Avenue (Manhattan)">8th Avenue</a> and <a href="/wiki/42nd_Street_(Manhattan)" title="42nd Street (Manhattan)">42nd Street</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PABT_498-0"><a href="#cite_note-PABT-498">[496]</a></sup></div>
</div>
</div>
<p>New York City's public <a href="/wiki/MTA_Regional_Bus_Operations" title="MTA Regional Bus Operations">bus fleet</a> is the largest in North America,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-499"><a href="#cite_note-499">[497]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Port_Authority_Bus_Terminal" title="Port Authority Bus Terminal">Port Authority Bus Terminal</a>, the main <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Intercity_bus" title="Intercity bus">intercity bus</a> terminal of the city, serves 7,000 buses and 200,000 commuters daily, making it the busiest bus station in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PABT_498-1"><a href="#cite_note-PABT-498">[496]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Air">Air</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:JFK_Plane_Queue.jpg"><img alt="Five jumbo airplanes wait in a line on a runway next to a small body of water. Behind them in the distance is the airport and control tower." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2414" data-file-width="3620" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/JFK_Plane_Queue.jpg/220px-JFK_Plane_Queue.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/JFK_Plane_Queue.jpg/330px-JFK_Plane_Queue.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/JFK_Plane_Queue.jpg/440px-JFK_Plane_Queue.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:JFK_Plane_Queue.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
<a href="/wiki/John_F._Kennedy_International_Airport" title="John F. Kennedy International Airport">John F. Kennedy Airport</a> in Queens, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Busiest_airports_in_the_United_States_by_international_passenger_traffic" title="Busiest airports in the United States by international passenger traffic">busiest international air passenger gateway</a> to the United States.</div>
</div>
</div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Aviation_in_the_New_York_metropolitan_area" title="Aviation in the New York metropolitan area">New York's airspace</a> is the busiest in the United States and one of the world's busiest air transportation corridors. The three busiest airports in the New York metropolitan area include <a href="/wiki/John_F._Kennedy_International_Airport" title="John F. Kennedy International Airport">John F. Kennedy International Airport</a>, <a href="/wiki/Newark_Liberty_International_Airport" title="Newark Liberty International Airport">Newark Liberty International Airport</a>, and <a href="/wiki/LaGuardia_Airport" title="LaGuardia Airport">LaGuardia Airport</a>; 130.5 million travelers used these three airports in 2016, and the city's airspace is the busiest in the nation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-500"><a href="#cite_note-500">[498]</a></sup> JFK and Newark Liberty were the <a href="/wiki/List_of_the_busiest_airports_in_the_United_States#10_busiest_US_airports_by_international_passenger_traffic_.282012.29" title="List of the busiest airports in the United States">busiest and fourth busiest U.S. gateways</a> for international air passengers, respectively, in 2012; as of 2011<sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=New_York_City&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, JFK was the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/World%27s_busiest_airports_by_international_passenger_traffic" title="World's busiest airports by international passenger traffic">busiest airport for international passengers</a> in North America.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-501"><a href="#cite_note-501">[499]</a></sup> Plans have advanced to expand passenger volume at a fourth airport, <a href="/wiki/Stewart_International_Airport" title="Stewart International Airport">Stewart International Airport</a> near <a href="/wiki/Newburgh,_New_York" title="Newburgh, New York">Newburgh, New York</a>, by the <a href="/wiki/Port_Authority_of_New_York_and_New_Jersey" title="Port Authority of New York and New Jersey">Port Authority of New York and New Jersey</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-502"><a href="#cite_note-502">[500]</a></sup> Plans were announced in July 2015 to entirely rebuild LaGuardia Airport in a multibillion-dollar project to replace its aging facilities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-503"><a href="#cite_note-503">[501]</a></sup> Other commercial airports in or serving the <a href="/wiki/New_York_metropolitan_area" title="New York metropolitan area">New York metropolitan area</a> include <a href="/wiki/Long_Island_MacArthur_Airport" title="Long Island MacArthur Airport">Long Island MacArthur Airport</a>, <a href="/wiki/Trenton%E2%80%93Mercer_Airport" title="Trenton–Mercer Airport">Trenton–Mercer Airport</a> and <a href="/wiki/Westchester_County_Airport" title="Westchester County Airport">Westchester County Airport</a>. The primary general aviation airport serving the area is <a href="/wiki/Teterboro_Airport" title="Teterboro Airport">Teterboro Airport</a>.</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Ferries">Ferries</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Spirit_of_America_-_Staten_Island_Ferry.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1009" data-file-width="1600" height="139" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/Spirit_of_America_-_Staten_Island_Ferry.jpg/220px-Spirit_of_America_-_Staten_Island_Ferry.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/Spirit_of_America_-_Staten_Island_Ferry.jpg/330px-Spirit_of_America_-_Staten_Island_Ferry.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/Spirit_of_America_-_Staten_Island_Ferry.jpg/440px-Spirit_of_America_-_Staten_Island_Ferry.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Spirit_of_America_-_Staten_Island_Ferry.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
The <a href="/wiki/Staten_Island_Ferry" title="Staten Island Ferry">Staten Island Ferry</a> shuttles <a href="/wiki/Commuting" title="Commuting">commuters</a> between Manhattan and Staten Island.</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Staten_Island_Ferry" title="Staten Island Ferry">Staten Island Ferry</a> is the world's busiest <a href="/wiki/Ferry" title="Ferry">ferry route</a>, carrying over 23 million passengers from July 2015 through June 2016 on the 5.2-mile (8.4 km) route between Staten Island and Lower Manhattan and running 24 hours a day.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-504"><a href="#cite_note-504">[502]</a></sup> Other ferry systems shuttle commuters between Manhattan and other locales within the city and the metropolitan area.</p>
<p><a href="/wiki/NYC_Ferry" title="NYC Ferry">NYC Ferry</a>, a <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Economic_Development_Corporation" title="New York City Economic Development Corporation">NYCEDC</a> initiative with routes planned to travel to all five boroughs, was launched in 2017, with <a href="/wiki/Second_grade" title="Second grade">second graders</a> choosing the names of the ferries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-505"><a href="#cite_note-505">[503]</a></sup> Meanwhile, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Seastreak_ferry" title="Seastreak ferry">Seastreak ferry</a> announced construction of a 600-passenger high-speed luxury ferry in September 2016, to shuttle riders between the <a href="/wiki/Jersey_Shore" title="Jersey Shore">Jersey Shore</a> and Manhattan, anticipated to start service in 2017; this would be the largest vessel in its class.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-506"><a href="#cite_note-506">[504]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span id="Taxis,_transport_startups,_and_trams"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Taxis.2C_transport_startups.2C_and_trams">Taxis, transport startups, and trams</span></h3>
<p>Other features of the city's transportation infrastructure encompass more than 12,000 <a href="/wiki/Taxicabs_of_New_York_City" title="Taxicabs of New York City">yellow taxicabs</a>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-507"><a href="#cite_note-507">[505]</a></sup> various competing <a href="/wiki/Startup_company" title="Startup company">startup</a> <a href="/wiki/Transportation_network_company" title="Transportation network company">transportation network companies</a>; and an <a href="/wiki/Roosevelt_Island_Tramway" title="Roosevelt Island Tramway">aerial tramway</a> that transports commuters between Roosevelt Island and Manhattan Island. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ride-sharing" title="Ride-sharing">Ride-sharing</a> services have become significant competition for cab drivers in New York.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-508"><a href="#cite_note-508">[506]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-509"><a href="#cite_note-509">[507]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Streets_and_highways">Streets and highways</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Storm_at_Manhattan.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1200" data-file-width="1600" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/Storm_at_Manhattan.jpg/220px-Storm_at_Manhattan.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/Storm_at_Manhattan.jpg/330px-Storm_at_Manhattan.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/Storm_at_Manhattan.jpg/440px-Storm_at_Manhattan.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Storm_at_Manhattan.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
8th Avenue, looking northward ("uptown"). Most streets and avenues in <a href="/wiki/Commissioners%27_Plan_of_1811" title="Commissioners' Plan of 1811">Manhattan's grid plan</a> incorporate a <a href="/wiki/One-way_traffic" title="One-way traffic">one-way traffic</a> configuration.</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Despite New York's heavy reliance on its vast public transit system, streets are a defining feature of the city. <a href="/wiki/Commissioners%27_Plan_of_1811" title="Commissioners' Plan of 1811">Manhattan's street grid plan</a> greatly influenced the city's physical development. Several of the city's streets and avenues, like <a href="/wiki/Broadway_(Manhattan)" title="Broadway (Manhattan)">Broadway</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-510"><a href="#cite_note-510">[508]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Wall_Street" title="Wall Street">Wall Street</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-511"><a href="#cite_note-511">[509]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Madison_Avenue_(Manhattan)" title="Madison Avenue (Manhattan)">Madison Avenue</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MadisonAveMetonym_326-1"><a href="#cite_note-MadisonAveMetonym-326">[324]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-512"><a href="#cite_note-512">[510]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Seventh_Avenue_(Manhattan)" title="Seventh Avenue (Manhattan)">Seventh Avenue</a> are also used as <a href="/wiki/Metonymy" title="Metonymy">metonyms</a> for national industries there: the theater, finance, advertising, and fashion organizations, respectively.</p>
<p>New York City also has an extensive web of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Freeway" title="Freeway">expressways</a> and <a href="/wiki/Parkway" title="Parkway">parkways</a>, which link the city's boroughs to each other and to <a href="/wiki/North_Jersey" title="North Jersey">northern New Jersey</a>, <a href="/wiki/Westchester_County,_New_York" title="Westchester County, New York">Westchester County</a>, <a href="/wiki/Long_Island" title="Long Island">Long Island</a>, and southwestern <a href="/wiki/Connecticut" title="Connecticut">Connecticut</a> through various <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bridges_and_tunnels_in_New_York_City" title="Bridges and tunnels in New York City">bridges and tunnels</a>. Because these highways serve millions of outer borough and suburban residents who <a href="/wiki/Commuting" title="Commuting">commute</a> into Manhattan, it is quite common for motorists to be stranded for hours in <a href="/wiki/Traffic_congestion" title="Traffic congestion">traffic jams</a> that are a daily occurrence, particularly during <a href="/wiki/Rush_hour" title="Rush hour">rush hour</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-recordonline.com_513-0"><a href="#cite_note-recordonline.com-513">[511]</a></sup></p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="River_crossings"><span id="Bridges"></span><span id="Tunnels"></span>River crossings</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tleft">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Verrazano-Narrows_Bridge_@_Night_from_Brooklyn.JPG"><img alt="A tall suspension bridge connects a distant piece of land at night." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3456" data-file-width="5184" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0f/Verrazano-Narrows_Bridge_%40_Night_from_Brooklyn.JPG/220px-Verrazano-Narrows_Bridge_%40_Night_from_Brooklyn.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0f/Verrazano-Narrows_Bridge_%40_Night_from_Brooklyn.JPG/330px-Verrazano-Narrows_Bridge_%40_Night_from_Brooklyn.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0f/Verrazano-Narrows_Bridge_%40_Night_from_Brooklyn.JPG/440px-Verrazano-Narrows_Bridge_%40_Night_from_Brooklyn.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Verrazano-Narrows_Bridge_@_Night_from_Brooklyn.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
The <a href="/wiki/Verrazano-Narrows_Bridge" title="Verrazano-Narrows Bridge">Verrazano-Narrows Bridge</a>, one of the world's longest <a href="/wiki/Suspension_bridge" title="Suspension bridge">suspension bridges</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-infoplease.com_514-0"><a href="#cite_note-infoplease.com-514">[512]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Verrazano-Narrows_Bridge_515-0"><a href="#cite_note-Verrazano-Narrows_Bridge-515">[513]</a></sup> connects <a href="/wiki/Brooklyn" title="Brooklyn">Brooklyn</a> and <a href="/wiki/Staten_Island" title="Staten Island">Staten Island</a> across <a href="/wiki/The_Narrows" title="The Narrows">The Narrows</a>.</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="thumb tleft">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:George_Washington_Bridge_from_New_Jersey-edit.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="727" data-file-width="738" height="217" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/George_Washington_Bridge_from_New_Jersey-edit.jpg/220px-George_Washington_Bridge_from_New_Jersey-edit.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/George_Washington_Bridge_from_New_Jersey-edit.jpg/330px-George_Washington_Bridge_from_New_Jersey-edit.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/George_Washington_Bridge_from_New_Jersey-edit.jpg/440px-George_Washington_Bridge_from_New_Jersey-edit.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:George_Washington_Bridge_from_New_Jersey-edit.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
The <a href="/wiki/George_Washington_Bridge" title="George Washington Bridge">George Washington Bridge</a>, connecting <a href="/wiki/Upper_Manhattan" title="Upper Manhattan">Upper Manhattan</a> (background) from <a href="/wiki/Fort_Lee,_New_Jersey" title="Fort Lee, New Jersey">Fort Lee</a>, <a href="/wiki/New_Jersey" title="New Jersey">New Jersey</a> across the <a href="/wiki/Hudson_River" title="Hudson River">Hudson River</a>, is the world's busiest motor vehicle bridge.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-panynj.gov_516-0"><a href="#cite_note-panynj.gov-516">[514]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-abcgwb_517-0"><a href="#cite_note-abcgwb-517">[515]</a></sup></div>
</div>
</div>
<p>New York City is located on one of the world's largest natural harbors,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-518"><a href="#cite_note-518">[516]</a></sup> and the boroughs of Manhattan and Staten Island are (primarily) coterminous with islands of the same names, while Queens and Brooklyn are located at the west end of the larger Long Island, and The Bronx is located at the southern tip of New York State's mainland. This situation of boroughs separated by water led to the development of an extensive infrastructure of well-known bridges and <a href="/wiki/Tunnel" title="Tunnel">tunnels</a>.</p>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/George_Washington_Bridge" title="George Washington Bridge">George Washington Bridge</a> is the world's busiest motor vehicle bridge,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-519"><a href="#cite_note-519">[517]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-520"><a href="#cite_note-520">[518]</a></sup> connecting Manhattan to <a href="/wiki/Bergen_County,_New_Jersey" title="Bergen County, New Jersey">Bergen County, New Jersey</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Verrazano-Narrows_Bridge" title="Verrazano-Narrows Bridge">Verrazano-Narrows Bridge</a> is the longest <a href="/wiki/Suspension_bridge" title="Suspension bridge">suspension bridge</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Americas" title="Americas">Americas</a> and one of the world's longest.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-infoplease.com_514-1"><a href="#cite_note-infoplease.com-514">[512]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Verrazano-Narrows_Bridge_515-1"><a href="#cite_note-Verrazano-Narrows_Bridge-515">[513]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Brooklyn_Bridge" title="Brooklyn Bridge">Brooklyn Bridge</a> is an icon of the city itself. The towers of the Brooklyn Bridge are built of <a href="/wiki/Limestone" title="Limestone">limestone</a>, <a href="/wiki/Granite" title="Granite">granite</a>, and Rosendale cement, and their architectural style is neo-Gothic, with characteristic pointed arches above the passageways through the stone towers. This bridge was also the longest suspension bridge in the world from its opening until 1903, and is the first steel-wire suspension bridge. The <a href="/wiki/Queensboro_Bridge" title="Queensboro Bridge">Queensboro Bridge</a> is an important piece of <a href="/wiki/Cantilever_bridge" title="Cantilever bridge">cantilever architecture</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Manhattan_Bridge" title="Manhattan Bridge">Manhattan Bridge</a>, opened in 1909, is considered to be the forerunner of modern <a href="/wiki/Suspension_bridge" title="Suspension bridge">suspension bridges</a>, and its design served as the model for many of the long-span suspension bridges around the world; the Manhattan Bridge, <a href="/wiki/Throgs_Neck_Bridge" title="Throgs Neck Bridge">Throgs Neck Bridge</a>, <a href="/wiki/Triborough_Bridge" title="Triborough Bridge">Triborough Bridge</a>, and Verrazano-Narrows Bridge are all examples of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Structural_Expressionism" title="Structural Expressionism">Structural Expressionism</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-521"><a href="#cite_note-521">[519]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-522"><a href="#cite_note-522">[520]</a></sup></p>
<p>Manhattan Island is linked to New York City's outer boroughs and New Jersey by several <a href="/wiki/Tunnel" title="Tunnel">tunnels</a> as well. The <a href="/wiki/Lincoln_Tunnel" title="Lincoln Tunnel">Lincoln Tunnel</a>, which carries 120,000 vehicles a day under the Hudson River between New Jersey and Midtown Manhattan, is the busiest vehicular tunnel in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-523"><a href="#cite_note-523">[521]</a></sup> The tunnel was built instead of a bridge to allow unfettered passage of large passenger and <a href="/wiki/Cargo_ship" title="Cargo ship">cargo ships</a> that sailed through New York Harbor and up the Hudson River to Manhattan's piers. The <a href="/wiki/Holland_Tunnel" title="Holland Tunnel">Holland Tunnel</a>, connecting Lower Manhattan to <a href="/wiki/Jersey_City,_New_Jersey" title="Jersey City, New Jersey">Jersey City, New Jersey</a>, was the world's first mechanically ventilated vehicular tunnel when it opened in 1927.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-524"><a href="#cite_note-524">[522]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-525"><a href="#cite_note-525">[523]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Queens-Midtown_Tunnel" title="Queens-Midtown Tunnel">Queens-Midtown Tunnel</a>, built to relieve congestion on the bridges connecting Manhattan with Queens and Brooklyn, was the largest non-federal project in its time when it was completed in 1940.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-526"><a href="#cite_note-526">[524]</a></sup> President <a href="/wiki/Franklin_D._Roosevelt" title="Franklin D. Roosevelt">Franklin D. Roosevelt</a> was the first person to drive through it.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-527"><a href="#cite_note-527">[525]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hugh_L._Carey_Tunnel" title="Hugh L. Carey Tunnel">Hugh L. Carey Tunnel</a> runs underneath <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Battery_Park" title="Battery Park">Battery Park</a> and connects the <a href="/wiki/Financial_District,_Manhattan" title="Financial District, Manhattan">Financial District</a> at the southern tip of Manhattan to <a href="/wiki/Red_Hook,_Brooklyn" title="Red Hook, Brooklyn">Red Hook</a> in Brooklyn.</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Environment"><span id="Environmental_perspectives"></span> Environment</span></h2>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Environmental_issues_in_New_York_City" title="Environmental issues in New York City">Environmental issues in New York City</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:NYC_Hybrid_Taxi.JPG"><img alt="Two yellow taxis on a narrow street lined with shops." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1200" data-file-width="1600" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/NYC_Hybrid_Taxi.JPG/220px-NYC_Hybrid_Taxi.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/NYC_Hybrid_Taxi.JPG/330px-NYC_Hybrid_Taxi.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/NYC_Hybrid_Taxi.JPG/440px-NYC_Hybrid_Taxi.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:NYC_Hybrid_Taxi.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
As of July 2010, the city had 3,715 <a href="/wiki/Hybrid_taxi" title="Hybrid taxi">hybrid taxis</a> in service, the largest number of any city in North America.</div>
</div>
</div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Environmental_impact_reduction">Environmental impact reduction</span></h3>
<p>New York City has focused on reducing its <a href="/wiki/Human_impact_on_the_environment" title="Human impact on the environment">environmental impact</a> and <a href="/wiki/Carbon_footprint" title="Carbon footprint">carbon footprint</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYCCarbonFootprint_528-0"><a href="#cite_note-NYCCarbonFootprint-528">[526]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Public_transport" title="Public transport">Mass transit</a> use in New York City is the highest in the United States. Also, by 2010, the city had 3,715 <a href="/wiki/Hybrid_electric_vehicle" title="Hybrid electric vehicle">hybrid</a> taxis and other <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Clean_diesel" title="Clean diesel">clean diesel</a> vehicles, representing around 28% of New York's taxi fleet in service, the most of any city in North America.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYT072710_529-0"><a href="#cite_note-NYT072710-529">[527]</a></sup></p>
<p>New York's high rate of <a href="/wiki/List_of_U.S._cities_with_high_transit_ridership" title="List of U.S. cities with high transit ridership">public transit use</a>, over 200,000 daily <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cyclist" title="Cyclist">cyclists</a> as of 2014<sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=New_York_City&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-530"><a href="#cite_note-530">[528]</a></sup> and many <a href="/wiki/List_of_U.S._cities_with_most_pedestrian_commuters" title="List of U.S. cities with most pedestrian commuters">pedestrian commuters</a> make it the most energy-efficient major city in the United States.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYC_energy_consumption_531-0"><a href="#cite_note-NYC_energy_consumption-531">[529]</a></sup> Walk and bicycle modes of travel account for 21% of all modes for trips in the city; nationally the rate for metro regions is about 8%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-532"><a href="#cite_note-532">[530]</a></sup> In both its 2011 and 2015 rankings, <a href="/wiki/Walk_Score" title="Walk Score">Walk Score</a> named New York City the most <a href="/wiki/Walkability" title="Walkability">walkable</a> large city in the United States.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-533"><a href="#cite_note-533">[531]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-534"><a href="#cite_note-534">[532]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-535"><a href="#cite_note-535">[533]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Citibank" title="Citibank">Citibank</a> sponsored the introduction of 10,000 public bicycles for the city's <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bike-share" title="Bike-share">bike-share</a> project in the summer of 2013.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-536"><a href="#cite_note-536">[534]</a></sup> Research conducted by <a href="/wiki/Quinnipiac_University" title="Quinnipiac University">Quinnipiac University</a> showed that a majority of New Yorkers support the initiative.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-537"><a href="#cite_note-537">[535]</a></sup> New York City's numerical "in-season cycling indicator" of bicycling in the city hit an all-time high in 2013.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-538"><a href="#cite_note-538">[536]</a></sup></p>
<p>The city government was a petitioner in the landmark <i><a href="/wiki/Massachusetts_v._Environmental_Protection_Agency" title="Massachusetts v. Environmental Protection Agency">Massachusetts v. Environmental Protection Agency</a></i> Supreme Court case forcing the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/EPA" title="EPA">EPA</a> to regulate <a href="/wiki/Greenhouse_gas" title="Greenhouse gas">greenhouse gases</a> as pollutants. The city is also a leader in the construction of energy-efficient <a href="/wiki/Green_building" title="Green building">green office buildings</a>, including the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hearst_Tower_(New_York_City)" title="Hearst Tower (New York City)">Hearst Tower</a> among others.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-greenbuilding_171-1"><a href="#cite_note-greenbuilding-171">[171]</a></sup> Mayor Bill de Blasio has committed to an 80% reduction in greenhouse gas emissions between 2014 and 2050 to reduce the city's contributions to <a href="/wiki/Climate_change" title="Climate change">climate change</a>, beginning with a comprehensive "Green Buildings" plan.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYCCarbonFootprint_528-1"><a href="#cite_note-NYCCarbonFootprint-528">[526]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Water_purity_and_availability">Water purity and availability</span></h3>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Food_and_water_in_New_York_City" title="Food and water in New York City">Food and water in New York City</a> and <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_water_supply_system" title="New York City water supply system">New York City water supply system</a></div>
<p>New York City is supplied with drinking water by the protected <a href="/wiki/Catskill_Mountains" title="Catskill Mountains">Catskill Mountains</a> <a href="/wiki/Drainage_basin" title="Drainage basin">watershed</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-539"><a href="#cite_note-539">[537]</a></sup> As a result of the watershed's integrity and undisturbed <a href="/wiki/Water_purification" title="Water purification">natural water filtration system</a>, New York is one of only four major cities in the United States the majority of whose drinking water is pure enough not to require purification by <a href="/wiki/Water_treatment" title="Water treatment">water treatment</a> plants.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-540"><a href="#cite_note-540">[538]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Croton_Falls_Reservoir" title="Croton Falls Reservoir">Croton Watershed</a> north of the city is undergoing construction of a US$3.2 billion water purification plant to augment New York City's water supply by an estimated 290 million gallons daily, representing a greater than 20% addition to the city's current availability of water.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-541"><a href="#cite_note-541">[539]</a></sup> The ongoing expansion of <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Water_Tunnel_No._3" title="New York City Water Tunnel No. 3">New York City Water Tunnel No. 3</a>, an integral part of the New York City water supply system, is the largest capital construction project in the city's history,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-542"><a href="#cite_note-542">[540]</a></sup> with segments serving Manhattan and The Bronx completed, and with segments serving Brooklyn and Queens planned for construction in 2020.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-543"><a href="#cite_note-543">[541]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Environmental_revitalization">Environmental revitalization</span></h3>
<p><a href="/wiki/Newtown_Creek" title="Newtown Creek">Newtown Creek</a>, a 3.5-mile (6-kilometer) a long <a href="/wiki/Estuary" title="Estuary">estuary</a> that forms part of the border between the boroughs of Brooklyn and Queens, has been designated a <a href="/wiki/Superfund" title="Superfund">Superfund</a> site for environmental clean-up and remediation of the waterway's <a href="/wiki/List_of_water_sports" title="List of water sports">recreational</a> and economic resources for many communities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-544"><a href="#cite_note-544">[542]</a></sup> One of the most heavily used bodies of water in the <a href="/wiki/Port_of_New_York_and_New_Jersey" title="Port of New York and New Jersey">Port of New York and New Jersey</a>, it had been one of the most <a href="/wiki/Water_pollution" title="Water pollution">contaminated</a> industrial sites in the country,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PBS_545-0"><a href="#cite_note-PBS-545">[543]</a></sup> containing years of discarded <a href="/wiki/Toxin" title="Toxin">toxins</a>, an estimated 30 million US gallons (110,000 m<sup>3</sup>) of spilled oil, including the <a href="/wiki/Greenpoint_oil_spill" title="Greenpoint oil spill">Greenpoint oil spill</a>, raw <a href="/wiki/Sewage" title="Sewage">sewage</a> from New York City's sewer system,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PBS_545-1"><a href="#cite_note-PBS-545">[543]</a></sup> and other accumulation.</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Government_and_politics">Government and politics</span></h2>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Government_of_New_York_City" title="Government of New York City">Government of New York City</a> and <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_New_York_City" title="Politics of New York City">Politics of New York City</a></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Government">Government</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:New_York_City_Hall.jpg"><img alt="A wide white building in a colonial style with a cupola in the center." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1200" data-file-width="1600" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/New_York_City_Hall.jpg/220px-New_York_City_Hall.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/New_York_City_Hall.jpg/330px-New_York_City_Hall.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/New_York_City_Hall.jpg/440px-New_York_City_Hall.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:New_York_City_Hall.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
<a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Hall" title="New York City Hall">New York City Hall</a> is the oldest City Hall in the United States that still houses its original governmental functions.</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>New York City has been a <a href="/wiki/Metropolitan_municipality" title="Metropolitan municipality">metropolitan municipality</a> with a <a href="/wiki/Mayor%E2%80%93council_government" title="Mayor–council government">mayor–council form of government</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-546"><a href="#cite_note-546">[544]</a></sup> since its consolidation in 1898. In New York City, the city government is responsible for public education, correctional institutions, public safety, recreational facilities, sanitation, water supply, and welfare services.</p>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Mayor_of_New_York_City" title="Mayor of New York City">Mayor</a> and council members are elected to four-year terms. The <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Council" title="New York City Council">City Council</a> is a <a href="/wiki/Unicameralism" title="Unicameralism">unicameral</a> body consisting of 51 council members whose districts are defined by geographic population boundaries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-547"><a href="#cite_note-547">[545]</a></sup> Each term for the mayor and council members lasts four years and has a three <a href="/wiki/Term_limit" title="Term limit">consecutive-term limit</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-548"><a href="#cite_note-548">[546]</a></sup> which is reset after a four-year break. The <i><a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Administrative_Code" title="New York City Administrative Code">New York City Administrative Code</a></i>, the <i><a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Rules" title="New York City Rules">New York City Rules</a></i>, and the <i><a href="/wiki/The_City_Record" title="The City Record">City Record</a></i> are the code of local laws, compilation of regulations, and official journal, respectively.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-549"><a href="#cite_note-549">[547]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-550"><a href="#cite_note-550">[548]</a></sup></p>
<div class="thumb tleft">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:New_York_Supreme_Court_at_60_Centre_Street.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="300" data-file-width="400" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/New_York_Supreme_Court_at_60_Centre_Street.jpg/220px-New_York_Supreme_Court_at_60_Centre_Street.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/New_York_Supreme_Court_at_60_Centre_Street.jpg/330px-New_York_Supreme_Court_at_60_Centre_Street.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/5/56/New_York_Supreme_Court_at_60_Centre_Street.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:New_York_Supreme_Court_at_60_Centre_Street.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
The <a href="/wiki/New_York_County_Courthouse" title="New York County Courthouse">New York County Courthouse</a> houses the <a href="/wiki/New_York_Supreme_Court" title="New York Supreme Court">New York Supreme Court</a> and other offices.</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Each borough is coextensive with a <a href="/wiki/Judicial_district" title="Judicial district">judicial district</a> of the state <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/New_York_State_Unified_Court_System" title="New York State Unified Court System">Unified Court System</a>, of which the <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Criminal_Court" title="New York City Criminal Court">Criminal Court</a> and the <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Civil_Court" title="New York City Civil Court">Civil Court</a> are the local courts, while the <a href="/wiki/New_York_Supreme_Court" title="New York Supreme Court">New York Supreme Court</a> conducts major trials and appeals. Manhattan hosts the First Department of the <a href="/wiki/New_York_Supreme_Court,_Appellate_Division" title="New York Supreme Court, Appellate Division">Supreme Court, Appellate Division</a> while Brooklyn hosts the Second Department. There are also several extrajudicial <a href="/wiki/Administrative_court" title="Administrative court">administrative courts</a>, which are executive agencies and not part of the state Unified Court System.</p>
<p>Uniquely among major American cities, New York is divided between, and is host to the main branches of, two different <a href="/wiki/United_States_district_court" title="United States district court">US district courts</a>: the <a href="/wiki/United_States_District_Court_for_the_Southern_District_of_New_York" title="United States District Court for the Southern District of New York">District Court for the Southern District of New York</a>, whose main courthouse is on <a href="/wiki/Foley_Square" title="Foley Square">Foley Square</a> near City Hall in Manhattan and whose jurisdiction includes Manhattan and the Bronx; and the <a href="/wiki/United_States_District_Court_for_the_Eastern_District_of_New_York" title="United States District Court for the Eastern District of New York">District Court for the Eastern District of New York</a>, whose main courthouse is in Brooklyn and whose jurisdiction includes Brooklyn, Queens, and Staten Island. The <a href="/wiki/United_States_Court_of_Appeals_for_the_Second_Circuit" title="United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit">US Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit</a> and <a href="/wiki/United_States_Court_of_International_Trade" title="United States Court of International Trade">US Court of International Trade</a> are also based in New York, also on Foley Square in Manhattan.</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Politics">Politics</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bill_de_Blasio_11-2-2013.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="445" height="229" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Bill_de_Blasio_11-2-2013.jpg/170px-Bill_de_Blasio_11-2-2013.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Bill_de_Blasio_11-2-2013.jpg/255px-Bill_de_Blasio_11-2-2013.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Bill_de_Blasio_11-2-2013.jpg/340px-Bill_de_Blasio_11-2-2013.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Bill_de_Blasio_11-2-2013.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
<a href="/wiki/Bill_de_Blasio" title="Bill de Blasio">Bill de Blasio</a>, the current and <a href="/wiki/List_of_mayors_of_New_York_City" title="List of mayors of New York City">109th</a> <a href="/wiki/Mayor_of_New_York_City" title="Mayor of New York City">Mayor of New York City</a></div>
</div>
</div>
<p>The present mayor is <a href="/wiki/Bill_de_Blasio" title="Bill de Blasio">Bill de Blasio</a>, the first Democrat since 1993.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-551"><a href="#cite_note-551">[549]</a></sup> He was elected in <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_mayoral_election,_2013" title="New York City mayoral election, 2013">2013</a> with over 73% of the vote, and assumed office on January 1, 2014.</p>
<p>The Democratic Party holds the majority of public offices. As of April 2016, 69% of registered voters in the city are Democrats and 10% are <a href="/wiki/Republican_Party_(United_States)" title="Republican Party (United States)">Republicans</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-552"><a href="#cite_note-552">[550]</a></sup> New York City has not been carried by a Republican in a statewide or presidential election since President <a href="/wiki/Calvin_Coolidge" title="Calvin Coolidge">Calvin Coolidge</a> won the five boroughs in <a href="/wiki/United_States_presidential_election_in_New_York,_1924" title="United States presidential election in New York, 1924">1924</a>. In <a href="/wiki/United_States_presidential_election_in_New_York,_2012" title="United States presidential election in New York, 2012">2012</a>, Democrat <a href="/wiki/Barack_Obama" title="Barack Obama">Barack Obama</a> became the first presidential candidate of any party to receive more than 80% of the overall vote in New York City, sweeping all five boroughs. <a href="/wiki/Party_platform" title="Party platform">Party platforms</a> center on affordable housing, education, and economic development, and labor politics are of importance in the city.</p>
<p>New York is the most important source of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Political_fundraising" title="Political fundraising">political fundraising</a> in the United States, as four of the top five ZIP codes in the nation for political contributions are in Manhattan. The top ZIP code, 10021 on the <a href="/wiki/Upper_East_Side" title="Upper East Side">Upper East Side</a>, generated the most money for the 2004 presidential campaigns of <a href="/wiki/George_W._Bush" title="George W. Bush">George W. Bush</a> and <a href="/wiki/John_Kerry" title="John Kerry">John Kerry</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-553"><a href="#cite_note-553">[551]</a></sup> The city has a strong imbalance of payments with the national and state governments. It receives 83 cents in services for every $1 it sends to the federal government in <a href="/wiki/Taxation_in_the_United_States" title="Taxation in the United States">taxes</a> (or annually sends $11.4 billion more than it receives back). City residents and businesses also spent an additional $4.1 billion in the 2009–2010 <a href="/wiki/Fiscal_year" title="Fiscal year">fiscal year</a> to the state of New York than the city received in return.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-554"><a href="#cite_note-554">[552]</a></sup></p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notable_people">Notable people</span></h2>
<div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/List_of_people_from_New_York_City" title="List of people from New York City">List of people from New York City</a></div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Global_outreach">Global outreach</span></h2>
<p>In 2006, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Twin_towns_and_sister_cities" title="Twin towns and sister cities">Sister City</a> Program of the City of New York, Inc. was restructured and renamed <i>New York City Global Partners</i>. New York City has expanded its international outreach via this program to a network of cities worldwide, promoting the exchange of ideas and <a href="/wiki/Innovation" title="Innovation">innovation</a> between their citizenry and policymakers, according to the city's website. New York's <i>historic sister cities</i> are denoted below by the year they joined New York City's partnership network.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GlobalOutreach_555-0"><a href="#cite_note-GlobalOutreach-555">[553]</a></sup></p>
<table class="wikitable collapsible collapsed">
<tr>
<th>New York City Global Partners network</th>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><b>Africa</b>
<div class="div-col columns column-width" style="-moz-column-width: 20em; -webkit-column-width: 20em; column-width: 20em; -moz-column-rule: 1px solid #AAA; -webkit-column-rule: 1px solid #AAA; column-rule: 1px solid #AAA; font-size:90%;">
<ul>
<li><a href="/wiki/Accra" title="Accra">Accra</a>, Ghana</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Addis_Ababa" title="Addis Ababa">Addis Ababa</a>, Ethiopia</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Cairo" title="Cairo">Cairo</a>, Egypt (1982)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Cape_Town" title="Cape Town">Cape Town</a>, South Africa</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Lagos" title="Lagos">Lagos</a>, Nigeria</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Libreville" title="Libreville">Libreville</a>, Gabon</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Johannesburg" title="Johannesburg">Johannesburg</a>, South Africa (2003)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Nairobi" title="Nairobi">Nairobi</a>, Kenya</li>
</ul>
</div>
<p><b>Asia</b></p>
<p><b>(<i>East</i>)</b></p>
<div class="div-col columns column-width" style="-moz-column-width: 20em; -webkit-column-width: 20em; column-width: 20em; -moz-column-rule: 1px solid #AAA; -webkit-column-rule: 1px solid #AAA; column-rule: 1px solid #AAA; font-size:90%;">
<ul>
<li><a href="/wiki/Bangkok" title="Bangkok">Bangkok</a>, Thailand</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Beijing" title="Beijing">Beijing</a>, People's Republic of China (1980)</li>
<li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bi%C3%AAn_H%C3%B2a_City" title="Biên Hòa City">Biên Hòa</a>, Vietnam</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Changwon" title="Changwon">Changwon</a>, South Korea</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Chongqing" title="Chongqing">Chongqing</a>, People's Republic of China<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-556"><a href="#cite_note-556">[554]</a></sup></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Guangzhou" title="Guangzhou">Guangzhou</a>, People's Republic of China</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Ho_Chi_Minh_City" title="Ho Chi Minh City">Ho Chi Minh City</a>, Vietnam</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Hong_Kong" title="Hong Kong">Hong Kong</a>, People's Republic of China</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Jakarta" title="Jakarta">Jakarta</a>, Indonesia</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Kuala_Lumpur" title="Kuala Lumpur">Kuala Lumpur</a>, Malaysia<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-557"><a href="#cite_note-557">[555]</a></sup></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Manila" title="Manila">Manila</a>, Philippines</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Seoul" title="Seoul">Seoul</a>, South Korea</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Shanghai" title="Shanghai">Shanghai</a>, People's Republic of China</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Shenyang" title="Shenyang">Shenyang</a>, People's Republic of China</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Singapore" title="Singapore">Singapore</a>, Singapore</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Taipei" title="Taipei">Taipei</a>, Taiwan</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Tokyo" title="Tokyo">Tokyo</a>, Japan (1960)</li>
</ul>
</div>
<p><b>(<i>South</i>)</b></p>
<div class="div-col columns column-width" style="-moz-column-width: 20em; -webkit-column-width: 20em; column-width: 20em; -moz-column-rule: 1px solid #AAA; -webkit-column-rule: 1px solid #AAA; column-rule: 1px solid #AAA; font-size:90%;">

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span></h2>
<div class="reflist" style="list-style-type: lower-alpha;">
<div class="mw-references-wrap">
<ol class="references">
<li id="cite_note-211"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-211">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Mean monthly maxima and minima (i.e. the expected highest and lowest temperature readings at any point during the year or given month) calculated based on data at said location from 1981 to 2010.</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-213"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-213">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Official weather observations for Central Park were conducted at the Arsenal at Fifth Avenue and 64th Street from 1869 to 1919, and at Belvedere Castle since 1919.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-212"><a href="#cite_note-212">[211]</a></sup></span></li>
</ol>

<li id="cite_note-19"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-19">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a class="external text" href="http://visit.un.org/content/plan-your-visit" rel="nofollow">Plan your visit</a> <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20170314234417/http://visit.un.org/content/plan-your-visit" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> March 14, 2017, at the <a href="/wiki/Wayback_Machine" title="Wayback Machine">Wayback Machine</a>., <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a>. When you pass through the gates of the United Nations visitors’ entrance, you enter an international territory. This 18-acre site does not belong to just one country, but to all countries that have joined the Organization; currently, the United Nations has 193 Member States."</span></li>

<li id="cite_note-Harris-128"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Harris_128-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Harris_128-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Harris_128-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Harris_128-3"><sup><i><b>d</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><a class="external text" href="http://www.press.uchicago.edu/Misc/Chicago/317749.html" rel="nofollow">Leslie M. Harris, "The New York City Draft Riots"</a>, excerpt from <i>In the Shadow of Slavery: African Americans in New York City, 1626–1863</i>, University of Chicago Press, 2003</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-129"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-129">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a class="external text" href="http://www.u-s-history.com/pages/h249.html" rel="nofollow">"The Draft in the Civil War"</a>, u-s-history.com.</span></li>

<li id="cite_note-149"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-149">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a class="external text" href="http://www.panynj.gov/wtcprogress/transportation-hub.html" rel="nofollow">World Trade Center Transportation Hub</a>, World Trade Center. Accessed February 9, 2017. "The state-of-the-art World Trade Center Transportation Hub, completed in 2016, serves 250,000 Port Authority Trans-Hudson (PATH) daily commuters and millions of annual visitors from around the world. At approximately 800,000 square feet, the Hub, designed by internationally acclaimed architect Santiago Calatrava, is the third largest transportation center in New York City."</span></li>

<li id="cite_note-152"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-152">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a class="external text" href="http://skyscraperpage.com/cities/?buildingID=7788" rel="nofollow">One World Trade Center</a> <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20130605115912/http://skyscraperpage.com/cities/?buildingID=7788" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> June 5, 2013, at the <a href="/wiki/Wayback_Machine" title="Wayback Machine">Wayback Machine</a>., SkyscraperPage.com. Accessed February 9, 2017. "The roof height is the same as original One World Trade Center. The building is topped out by a 124-meter (408-foot) spire. So the tower rises 1,776 feet (541-meter) which marks the year of the American declaration of Independence."</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-153"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-153">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web">Matthews, Laura (April 30, 2012). <a class="external text" href="http://www.ibtimes.com/one-world-trade-center-top-tallest-building-new-york-city-photos-700251" rel="nofollow">"One World Trade Center On Top As Tallest Building In New York City"</a>. <li id="cite_note-155"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-155">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="/wiki/Joe_Nocera" title="Joe Nocera">Nocera, Joe</a>. <a class="external text" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2012/09/15/opinion/nocera-two-days-in-september.html" rel="nofollow">"Two Days in September"</a>, <i><a href="/wiki/The_New_York_Times" title="The New York Times">The New York Times</a></i>, September 14, 2012. Thus, Anniversary No. 2: Sept. 17, 2011, was the date Occupy Wall Street took over Zuccotti Park in Lower Manhattan, which soon led to similar actions in cities across the country. The movement’s primary issue was income inequality — 'We are the 99 percent,' they used to chant."</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-156"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-156">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Washington, D.C. is 228 miles (367 km) driving distance from New York, and Boston is 217 miles (349 km) driving distance from New York. – <a class="external text" href="https://maps.google.com/" rel="nofollow">Google Maps</a></span></li>

<li id="cite_note-168"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-168">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Staff. <a class="external text" href="http://rew-online.com/2016/06/15/alchemy-borrows-220m-for-woolworth-conversion/" rel="nofollow">"Alchemy borrows $220M for Woolworth conversion"</a> <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20170211080412/http://rew-online.com/2016/06/15/alchemy-borrows-220m-for-woolworth-conversion/" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> February 11, 2017, at the <a href="/wiki/Wayback_Machine" title="Wayback Machine">Wayback Machine</a>., <i><a href="/wiki/Real_Estate_Weekly" title="Real Estate Weekly">Real Estate Weekly</a></i>, June 15, 2016. Woolworth in 1910 as his eponymous company’s new headquarters and designed by renowned architect Cass Gilbert. <li id="cite_note-221"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-221">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation news">Foderaro, Lisa W. <li id="cite_note-222"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-222">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a class="external text" href="https://www.prospectpark.org/learn-more/park-history-slideshow/" rel="nofollow">Park History</a>, Prospect Park Alliance. Accessed February 9, 2017.</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-223"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-223">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Foderaro, Lisa W. <a class="external text" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2013/06/01/nyregion/surveying-effort-alters-sizes-of-some-new-york-parks.html" rel="nofollow">"How Big Is That Park? City Now Has the Answer"</a>, <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/New_York_Times" title="New York Times">New York Times</a></i>, May 31, 2013. Accessed February 9, 2017. "But the biggest loser was clearly Flushing Meadows. Previously the third-largest park in the city, it dropped to fourth place after the new analysis put its actual acreage at 897 (897.62 to be precise), down from 1,255 acres."</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-224"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-224">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">[Flushing Meadows Corona Park World’s Fair Legacy; Celebrating the 50th &amp; 75th Anniversaries of the 1939 &amp; 1964 Fairs], <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Department_of_Parks_and_Recreation" title="New York City Department of Parks and Recreation">New York City Department of Parks and Recreation</a>. Accessed February 9, 2017.</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-225"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-225">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a class="external text" href="https://www.nycgovparks.org/park-features/fmcp/usta-ntc-strategic-vision-project" rel="nofollow">National Tennis Center Strategic Vision Project</a>, <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Department_of_Parks_and_Recreation" title="New York City Department of Parks and Recreation">New York City Department of Parks and Recreation</a>. Accessed February 9, 2017. "The 42-acre NTC is located within Flushing Meadows Corona Park on parkland leased by NYC Parks to USTA and is one of the world’s largest public recreational tennis facilities. For 11 months of the year, NTC facilities are open to the public for indoor and outdoor tennis. The NTC is also host to the US Open, one of the sport’s four Grand Slam championship tennis tournaments."</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-226"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-226">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">via <a href="/wiki/Associated_Press" title="Associated Press">Associated Press</a>. <a class="external text" href="http://www.nbcnews.com/id/25479453/ns/travel-destination_travel/t/ladies-gentlemen-bronx-blooming/" rel="nofollow">"Ladies and gentlemen, the Bronx is blooming!"</a>, <a href="/wiki/NBC_News" title="NBC News">NBC News</a>, July 2, 2008. Accessed February 9, 2017. "Despite its urban image, the Bronx has 7,000 acres of park land, about 25 percent of its total area. In addition to Yankee Stadium and the Bronx Zoo, the borough's green spaces include the New York Botanical Garden; a 19th century garden overlooking the Hudson River called Wave Hill; and Van Cortlandt and Pelham Bay parks, where you can bird-watch, play golf and ride horses."</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-227"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-227">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a class="external text" href="https://www.nycgovparks.org/parks/conference-house-park/highlights/10408" rel="nofollow">Conference House Park</a>, <a href="/wiki/New_York_City_Department_of_Parks_and_Recreation" title="New York City Department of Parks and Recreation">New York City Department of Parks and Recreation</a>. Accessed February 9, 2017. "On September 11, 1776, this house was the site of a conference between British Lord Admiral Richard Howe and Founding Fathers Benjamin Franklin, John Adams, and Edward Rutledge. The talks occurred just two months after the Declaration of Independence had been signed. With the British controlling New York City, Long Island, and Staten Island, the Americans seemed headed for defeat. Lord Howe offered to end the conflict peacefully if the American colonies would return to British control, but the Americans refused to give up their struggle for independence."</span></li>
<li id="cite_note-228"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-228">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Jerome Jacobson, Mary Harris, James V. Taylor, Albert J. Anderson, William A. Ritchie, Robert E. Funk. <a class="external text" href="http://core.tdar.org/document/159627/burial-ridge-tottenville-staten-island-n-y-archaeology-at-new-york-citys-largest-prehistoric-cemetery" rel="nofollow"><i>Burial Ridge, Tottenville, Staten Island, N. Y</i></a>, Staten Island Institute of Arts &amp; Sciences, 1980, at The Digital Archaeological Record. Accessed February 9, 2017.</span></li>

<li id="cite_note-pop-233"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-pop_233-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-pop_233-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-pop_233-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-pop_233-3"><sup><i><b>d</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><cite class="citation web"><a class="external text" href="https://www.webcitation.org/69hd5KAIE?url=http://www.census.gov/population/www/documentation/twps0076/twps0076.html" rel="nofollow">"Race and Hispanic Origin for Selected Cities and Other Places: Earliest Census to 1990"</a>.
